Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Asian American adults are more likely to use salt during cooking compared to white, Black, and Mexican American adults.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Asian American adults were more likely to add salt in cooking than white adults, Black adults and Mexican American adults."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://newsroom.heart.org/news/understanding-cultural-differences-in-salt-usage-may-help-lower-consumption

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Asian American adults are the least likely group to add salt to their food at the table.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "However, Asian Americans were the least likely group to add salt to their food at the table."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://newsroom.heart.org/news/understanding-cultural-differences-in-salt-usage-may-help-lower-consumption

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Not all Asian Americans add salt when cooking rice, contrary to prior assumptions in dietary assessments.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Culturally, not all Asians salt plain rice. If they don’t add salt to rice when cooking, then their sodium intake is among the lowest across all racial and ethnic groups."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://newsroom.heart.org/news/understanding-cultural-differences-in-salt-usage-may-help-lower-consumption

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The text does not provide any information about Korean cultural dimensions or business meeting etiquette.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

No characteristics can be extracted due to lack of relevant content.===from https://www.annieandre.com/french-business-etiquette-infographic/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.feature: Korean students are more motivated by long-term or distal goals, such as career relevance, rather than immediate outcomes.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.original:
- Quoted text "Western students are more likely to connect utility values to more current or proximal goals (e.g., solving a problem) and respond more strongly to interventions that focus on proximal goals, while East Asian students are more likely to link utility values to long-term or distal goals (e.g., career relevance) and respond more strongly to interventions that focus on these long-term goals (Harackiewicz et al. 2014; Lazowski and Hulleman 2016; Shechter et al. 2011)."  
  - Location paragraph 57===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40894-019-00124-y

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.feature: Korean students are more likely to value a subject if it is meaningful to their family or social group, rather than for personal reasons.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.original:
- Quoted text "East Asian students expressed higher motivation in a subject if they believed it would help them achieve long-term goals, whereas their Western counterparts are more motivated to achieve short-term goals. East Asian students also tend to value a subject if it is meaningful to their family, whereas Western students tend to see value in a subject that is personally meaningful to them."  
  - Location paragraph 38===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40894-019-00124-y

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.feature: In Korean students, high interest and value in a subject can drive achievement behavior even when self-concept is low, indicating a compensatory effect of task value for low ability beliefs.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.original:
- Quoted text "Lee et al. (2014a, b) also found that Korean middle school students with high interest or utility value for learning English were more likely to procrastinate and/or cheat in their English test as their self-ability beliefs decreased. This finding indicates that even if a student has low perceived ability, they will be driven to succeed and achieve (albeit through deceptive methods) if they are highly interested in and highly value the subject or task."  
  - Location paragraph 49===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40894-019-00124-y

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.feature: French organizations prefer a hierarchical structure, where employees depend heavily on leaders for constant direction.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.original:
- Quoted text "France has a power distance score of 68, which is high and indicates a preference of hierarchical structure within an organization (Hofstede Insights, n.d.). Employees have a high level of dependency on their leaders for constant direction..."  
  - Location p2===from https://sites.psu.edu/global/2020/04/20/french-contradiction-of-scores-in-power-distance-and-individualism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.feature: French managers are concerned about losing control over employees when working remotely, reflecting the challenges of maintaining authority at a distance.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.original:
- Quoted text "Micromanaging employees from a distance is a cause for great concern and is stressed as fear of 'losing control over their employees' (Forbes France, 2019)."  
  - Location p2===from https://sites.psu.edu/global/2020/04/20/french-contradiction-of-scores-in-power-distance-and-individualism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.feature: While subordinates show respect and compliance toward their bosses, they may act independently or contrary to commitments when unsupervised, believing they know better.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.original:
- Quoted text "The conflict in these scores indicates subordinates respect and show compliance to their boss’s demands, but when left to their own devices may do the opposite of what they have committed to, as they believe that they know better (Hofstede Insights, n.d.)."  
  - Location p2===from https://sites.psu.edu/global/2020/04/20/french-contradiction-of-scores-in-power-distance-and-individualism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.feature: The text does not provide specific information about France's Power Distance Index (PDI) score or cultural behaviors related to power distance in French society.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.original:
None

(Note While the text defines the Power Distance Index generally, it does not include any France-specific evidence regarding its power distance cultural characteristics. Therefore, no valid cultural rules specific to France can be extracted from the provided text.)===from https://www.internationalbusinesscenter.org/geert-hofstede/hofstede_france.shtml

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.feature: Individuals from high power distance cultures are more likely to accept and feel comfortable with hierarchical and structured power relations.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.original:
- Quoted text "The members of the high power distance cultures are more likely to be accepting of, and comfortable with, structured power relations than are members of low power distant cultures."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/power+distance+culture.html

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: In France, national identity is prioritized above social, religious, or political identities in public life.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "In France, French identity has arguably become prioritized before most other forms of identification, whether that be social, religious, or political identities."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: The principle of laïcité (secularism) reinforces collectivism by moving religion to private life and promoting collective values in public life over individual interests.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "French secularism, coined as 'laïcité', has moved religion to private life, clearing the way for Frenchness to come first in public life... secular norms have the benefit of prioritizing collective values over fragmented individual interests."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: The cultural value of “Fraternity” reflects a shared commitment among citizens to actively participate in the political community for the public interest rather than seeking recognition for isolated identity groups.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "Another French-coined term, 'Fraternity', highlights the cultural value of collective activism well. [It] comes from a common inclination of citizens to participate actively in the free political community. As [French sociologist] Laborde puts it, '[t]he bond of citizenship would be eroded if society were fragmented into a collection of identity groups seeking recognition rather than work[ing] towards the public interest'."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: A long-standing tradition of organized public protest, dating back to the 1789 Revolution, supports collective action as a normalized and culturally embedded means of expressing dissent.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "Since at least the Revolution of 1789, public displays of contestation have punctuated French life..."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: Collective strikes are carried out as "orderly disorder"—planned disruptions of public life conducted within defined boundaries to maintain legitimacy and effectiveness.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "general strikes are called with the intention of disrupting public life mass transportation is shut down, schools are closed, mail service is suspended, and so on. But such actions are carried out within a well-defined frame."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: French unions achieve success through large-scale mobilization, increasing the number of participants to strengthen bargaining power and encourage government mediation.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "French unions won strikes by increasing the number of strikers. This tactic made it harder for employers to replace strikers; it also encouraged government mediation, which in France was usually favorable to labor."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: Workers from different sectors show solidarity by joining strikes even when the initial issue does not directly affect them, reflecting a broader cultural commitment to collective rights.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "railway workers protesting a…new government measure that stripped them of the right to early retirement were joined by postal workers, schoolteachers, and many others."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: France’s ability to rapidly mobilize large segments of the population demonstrates the strength of a unified national identity in driving political change.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "France’s capacity for rapid and large-scale mobilization demonstrates the power of a unified national identity in effecting political change."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: In French culture, individuals prioritize their own interests and those of their immediate family over broader group concerns.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "French society is quite individualistic, meaning that the interests of oneself and one's immediate family take priority."
  - Location p1===from https://www.studycountry.com/wiki/is-france-an-individualistic-culture

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Appropriate social behavior in France often depends on whether a person is part of one’s inner social circle or not.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Often, appropriate interaction depends on whether a person is within one's social circle or not."
  - Location p1===from https://www.studycountry.com/wiki/is-france-an-individualistic-culture

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: France has a high individualism score of 71, indicating that it is an individualistic society where individuals are not strongly influenced by group belonging and primarily care for themselves and their families.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "French scored 71 on their individualism score. This score shown that France is an individualism society. They didn't get affected by group's belonging. This means that an individual only take care them self and their family."
  - Location p3===from https://www.studycountry.com/wiki/is-france-an-individualistic-culture

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: In French cultural context, individualism is defined as the pursuit of one’s own interests and material pleasure ("everyone for themselves"), whereas individualisation refers to the desire for personal autonomy and freedom in life choices ("to each their own").
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Individualisation is a process which can be brought to light in the main domains of life. Increasingly, people want the right to choose what they think and how they act without being hindered by others. Individualisation is therefore a process involving empowerment and distancing oneself from assigned belongings. The motto that might best sum up this attitude is 'To each their own'."
  - Location paragraph 14

- Rule Description Individualism in France is associated with egoistic and utilitarian behavior focused on self-interest, while individualisation supports autonomy without rejecting social involvement or solidarity.
- ===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/s41253-020-00139-1

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Higher levels of individualism in France are linked to lower altruism and weaker social ties, as individualists tend to prioritize self-interest over concern for others.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "In contrast, the utilitarian and egoistic individualist is opposed to altruism and solidarity. And this represents a real challenge for societies."
  - Location paragraph 15

- Rule Description Concern for others—such as neighbors, fellow countrymen, immigrants, and disabled people—is inversely related to individualism, with more individualistic individuals showing less compassion.
- ===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/s41253-020-00139-1

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Individualistic attitudes in France are associated with political apathy, low interest in politics, and disengagement from public life.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Two indicators measure the level of interest people assign to public life the importance given to politics in one’s life and interest in politics generally... One can hypothesise that a large number of individualists are depoliticised or at least not very interested in current events."
  - Location paragraph 18

- Rule Description Individualists are less likely to participate in civic actions such as signing petitions, joining boycotts, attending demonstrations, or environmental activism.
- ===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/s41253-020-00139-1

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Lower levels of education in France are associated with higher individualism, while higher education correlates with lower individualism and greater altruism.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "People who have a high level of education are very individualised but not very individualistic. It is the opposite case for those who have only been to school undereducated people are not very individualised but are often individualistic."
  - Location paragraph 25

- Rule Description Working-class individuals in France are more likely to exhibit individualistic values compared to those from privileged socioeconomic backgrounds.
- ===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/s41253-020-00139-1

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: In France, lack of trust in others is associated with higher individualism, as distrustful individuals tend to be more self-centered and suspicious.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "There is also a strong connection between individualism and trust in others. In particular, when people have no trust in others, being always suspicious of others, it is also a sign of a self-centred viewpoint."
  - Location paragraph 32===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/s41253-020-00139-1

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Support for traditional gender roles and opposition to homosexual couples in France is positively associated with individualism, indicating that individualistic individuals tend to hold more conservative social views.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "In contrast, the more people consider men and women to have specific functions, the more they are also likely to be individualistic. Again, individualism is in line with rather traditional values."
  - Location paragraph 27

- Rule Description Favoring authoritarian values and supporting the death penalty are linked to higher individualism in France, reflecting fear-based and punitive attitudes.
- ===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/s41253-020-00139-1

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Individualism in France has philosophical origins linked to key historical events such as the French Revolution, which emphasized individual rights and personal freedom.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Les Lumières ont marqué une étape cruciale dans l'évolution de l'individualisme. Des philosophes comme John Locke et Jean-Jacques Rousseau ont défendu les droits de l'individu, prônant la liberté personnelle et l'égalité. Ces idées ont influencé les révolutions sociales, notamment la Révolution française et la Révolution américaine, qui ont renforcé l'importance de l'individu dans la société."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://laurentleloup.com/la-montee-de-lindividualisme-dans-la-societe-contemporaine/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Modern French society places strong value on personal autonomy, with social structures increasingly centered on individual independence, especially in urban areas.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "La modernité a transformé les structures sociales, favorisant l'essor de l'individualisme. L'urbanisation rapide a conduit à des modes de vie plus indépendants, où l'accent est mis sur l'autonomie personnelle."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://laurentleloup.com/la-montee-de-lindividualisme-dans-la-societe-contemporaine/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Contemporary French cultural values prioritize personal freedom and individual expression, encouraging people to pursue their own interests, passions, and self-defined goals in life choices such as careers, leisure, and consumption.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Les valeurs culturelles et sociales évoluent, reflétant une tendance vers davantage de liberté personnelle. Les sociétés contemporaines valorisent l'expression individuelle, encourageant les gens à poursuivre leurs propres intérêts et passions."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://laurentleloup.com/la-montee-de-lindividualisme-dans-la-societe-contemporaine/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: French cultural movements, including surrealism and abstract expressionism, reflect individualism by emphasizing the artist’s personal vision and introspective themes over collective narratives.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "L'individualisme a profondément influencé les mouvements culturels et artistiques. Les artistes modernes privilégient souvent l'expression personnelle, explorant des thèmes introspectifs et uniques. Cette tendance se reflète dans des mouvements tels que le surréalisme et l'expressionnisme abstrait, où l'accent est mis sur la vision individuelle de l'artiste."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://laurentleloup.com/la-montee-de-lindividualisme-dans-la-societe-contemporaine/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: The cultural rule of individualism in France emphasizes that the individual holds intrinsic value above all else, with individual rights and responsibilities taking precedence over collective interests in ethical, political, and economic domains.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "le terme « individualisme » désigne la doctrine qui accorde à l'individu une valeur intrinsèquement supérieure à toute autre et ce dans tous les domaines – éthique, politique, économique –, où toujours priment les droits et les responsabilités de ce dernier."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.universalis.fr/encyclopedie/individualisme/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: In contemporary French society, there is a cultural norm favoring independence and autonomy, which aligns with the prevailing individualistic environment and contradicts conformity.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Elle y contrevient en effet à l'individualisme ambiant et à la promotion d'un idéal d'indépendance et d'autonomie."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.universalis.fr/encyclopedie/individualisme/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: French society, due to its high uncertainty avoidance, is highly rule-oriented and establishes laws, rules, regulations, and controls to minimize ambiguity and reduce uncertainty.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "This creates a highly rule-oriented society that institutes laws, rules, regulations, and controls in order to reduce the amount of uncertainty within the population."  
  - Location p2===from http://www.internationalbusinesscenter.org/geert-hofstede/hofstede_france.shtml

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: In predominantly Catholic countries like France, there is a low tolerance for ambiguity, which correlates with high uncertainty avoidance.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "we found the primary correlating Hofstede Dimension to be Uncertainty Avoidance (UAI)... have a low tolerance for ambiguity."  
  - Location p2===from http://www.internationalbusinesscenter.org/geert-hofstede/hofstede_france.shtml

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: A high uncertainty avoidance ranking reflects a society with low tolerance for uncertainty and ambiguity, leading to the creation of rule-based systems to manage unstructured situations.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "A High Uncertainty Avoidance ranking indicates the country has a low tolerance for uncertainty and ambiguity. This creates a rule-oriented society that institutes laws, rules, regulations, and controls in order to reduce the amount of uncertainty."  
  - Location p5===from http://www.internationalbusinesscenter.org/geert-hofstede/hofstede_france.shtml

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: French culture exhibits a high level of uncertainty avoidance, as indicated by its UAI score of 86, reflecting a strong preference for minimizing ambiguity and unstructured situations through structured systems and belief in absolute truth.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "France 68 71 43 86"
  - Location p5

- Rule Description High uncertainty avoidance in France is consistent with cultural patterns that seek to reduce uncertainty through strict rules, laws, and safety measures, similar to other high-scoring countries.
- ===from https://clearlycultural.com/geert-hofstede-cultural-dimensions/uncertainty-avoidance-index/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.feature: Cultures with a long-term orientation focus on future rewards by delaying short-term gratification, emphasizing persistence, perseverance, saving, long-term growth, and adaptability.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.original:
- Quoted text "The societies having a long-term orientation tend to focus on the future in a way that delays short-term success in favor of long-term success."  
  - Location paragraph 2 (under "Orientation à court terme vs. orientation à long terme")

- Rule Description Long-term oriented societies prioritize traits such as perseverance, saving, and long-term growth over immediate results.  
- ===from https://mentorshow.com/blog/theorie-exemples-dimensions-culturelles-hofstede

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.feature: There is a cultural emphasis on saving as a key trait in long-term oriented societies.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.original:
- Quoted text "Croyance dans l’épargne."
  - Location p2===from https://www.managementinterculturel.com/outils/orientation-long-terme.html

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.feature: Long-term oriented cultures demonstrate a readiness to invest for future gains.
In long-term oriented cultures, there is an acceptance that results may take time and develop progressively.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.original:
- Quoted text "Acceptation de résultats lents et progressifs."
  - Location p2===from https://www.managementinterculturel.com/outils/orientation-long-terme.html

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.feature: Individuals in long-term oriented cultures show persistence in working toward their objectives.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.original:
- Quoted text "Persévérance pour accomplir ses objectifs."
  - Location p2===from https://www.managementinterculturel.com/outils/orientation-long-terme.html

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.feature: Maintaining awareness and care for social relationships is considered important in long-term oriented cultures.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.original:
- Quoted text "Sensibilité aux relations sociales."
  - Location p2===from https://www.managementinterculturel.com/outils/orientation-long-terme.html

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.feature: Long-term oriented cultures value the ability to adapt in a practical and flexible manner.
Effective strategic planning, including clear long-term goal setting and resource allocation, is essential for long-term orientation.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.original:
- Quoted text "Pour adopter une orientation à long terme, il est impératif de mettre en place une planification stratégique efficace. Cela comprend la définition claire des objectifs à long terme, l'analyse des tendances de marché et l'allocation optimale des ressources pour atteindre ces objectifs."
  - Location p5===from https://www.managementinterculturel.com/outils/orientation-long-terme.html

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.feature: Investing in research and development is seen as crucial for sustaining long-term growth and competitiveness.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.original:
- Quoted text "L'innovation est le moteur de la croissance à long terme. Les investissements dans la recherche et le développement permettent à une entreprise de rester en avance sur les changements technologiques et de répondre efficacement aux évolutions des besoins des consommateurs."
  - Location p6===from https://www.managementinterculturel.com/outils/orientation-long-terme.html

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: The indulgence dimension reflects the extent to which a society allows relatively free gratification of desires and enjoyment of life, including leisure activities and spending on luxury goods.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Des niveaux élevés d’indulgence indiquent que la société permet une gratification relativement libre et une grande joie de vivre."
  - Location paragraph 30

- Rule Description In more indulgent societies, people tend to spend more money on luxury products and enjoy greater freedom regarding leisure activities.
- ===from https://mentorshow.com/blog/theorie-exemples-dimensions-culturelles-hofstede

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: There is an increasing trend of disaffiliation from religion in France, particularly among those without migratory background, indicating a broader process of secularization.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "En augmentation depuis dix ans, cette désaffiliation religieuse concerne 58 % des personnes sans ascendance migratoire, 19 % des immigrés arrivés après 16 ans et 26 % des descendants de deux parents immigrés."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6793308?sommaire=6793391

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Catholicism remains the largest religious affiliation in France, while Islam has become the second-largest religion, with growing numbers of adherents declaring other Christian denominations as well.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Si le catholicisme reste la première religion (29 % de la population se déclare catholique), l’islam est déclaré par un nombre croissant de fidèles (10 %) et confirme sa place de deuxième religion de France. Le nombre de personnes déclarant une autre religion chrétienne augmente également, pour atteindre 9 %."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6793308?sommaire=6793391

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: The frequency and intensity of religious practice vary significantly across religions, with Jews showing the highest rate of regular attendance at places of worship, followed by Muslims, other Christians, and Buddhists, while Catholics show low levels of attendance.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "La fréquence et l’intensité de la pratique religieuse varient en fonction de la religion déclarée  seuls 8 % des catholiques fréquentent régulièrement un lieu de culte, contre un peu plus de 20 % des autres chrétiens, des musulmans et des bouddhistes, et 34 % des juifs."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6793308?sommaire=6793391

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Religious transmission from parents to children is strongest in Muslim and Jewish families, with very high percentages of individuals continuing to identify with their family's religion into adulthood.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "91 % des personnes élevées dans une famille musulmane suivent la religion de leurs parents. Cette transmission est très forte aussi chez les juifs (84 %), elle est moindre chez les catholiques (67 %) et chez les autres chrétiens (69 %)."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6793308?sommaire=6793391

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: The level of religiosity in adulthood is strongly influenced by the importance of religion during childhood upbringing, with Muslim and Jewish individuals more likely to report that religion was highly significant in their family environment.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "La socialisation religieuse parentale est nettement plus consistante pour les musulmans et les juifs, dont près des trois quarts disent qu’elle a eu assez ou beaucoup d’importance."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6793308?sommaire=6793391

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Having parents with different religious affiliations or one parent without religion significantly increases the likelihood of secularization among descendants of immigrants.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "À caractéristiques identiques, le fait d’avoir grandi dans une famille d’ascendance religieuse mixte ou catholique est déterminant dans le processus de sécularisation des descendants d’immigrés."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6793308?sommaire=6793391

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Religion is considered a cultural production rather than a natural or faith-based phenomenon when studied scientifically, and must be analyzed as part of human cultural output.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Ce qu'on appelle « culture » par opposition à « nature » est précisément constitué par l'ensemble des productions humaines, parmi lesquelles il faut compter les religions, entendues selon l'acception scientifique du terme et non du point de vue de la foi."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.universalis.fr/encyclopedie/religion-l-histoire-des-religions/3-la-religion-comme-fait-de-culture/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: The study of religion in Western academic culture adopts a methodological disinterest toward elements that cannot be reduced to historical knowledge, focusing instead on historical and cultural analysis.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Le désintérêt méthodique vis-à-vis de ce qui est irréductible à une connaissance de type historique, avant même de pouvoir être formulé théoriquement, est inscrit dans les faits mêmes qui marquent le développement de la recherche historico-religieuse."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.universalis.fr/encyclopedie/religion-l-histoire-des-religions/3-la-religion-comme-fait-de-culture/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Religious groups are prohibited from hosting political meetings or distributing electoral propaganda in places of worship or their associated premises.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Il est interdit, en revanche, de tenir des réunions politiques dans les locaux servant à l'exercice d'un culte ou dans leurs dépendances qui constituent un accessoire indissociable. Il est également interdit d'y afficher, d'y distribuer ou d'y diffuser de la propagande électorale (article 35-1 de la loi de 1905 modifiée par la loi du 24 août 2021 confortant les principes de la République)."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/publications/titre-vii/religion-et-politique-l-influence-de-la-religion-dans-les-debats-de-societe

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: There is no legal right for religious authorities to be consulted before parliamentary debates, even on matters affecting religious freedoms, as such consultations depend solely on the discretion of parliamentary committee leaders.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Il n'y a donc pas un droit à être auditionné, y compris sur des questions en lien avec les activités cultuelles et donc susceptibles d'affecter les libertés des groupements religieux."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/publications/titre-vii/religion-et-politique-l-influence-de-la-religion-dans-les-debats-de-societe

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Members of parliament may freely express their religious convictions during legislative debates due to parliamentary inviolability, and regulations on secularism do not restrict their speech, only their religious attire.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Les restrictions à la liberté d'expression religieuse des parlementaires semblent donc limitées au port de signes religieux et ne pas concerner les propos."  
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/publications/titre-vii/religion-et-politique-l-influence-de-la-religion-dans-les-debats-de-societe

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: Arriving 10 to 15 minutes after the scheduled time is culturally accepted and seen as a gesture of conviviality, especially for informal dinners, as it gives the host extra time to prepare.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "En France, arriver 10 à 15 minutes après l'heure du rendez-vous quand on est invité à dîner peut être un petit geste de convivialité. Cela donne à l'hôte un peu de temps supplémentaire pour peaufiner les derniers détails, et ça évite d'être trop pressé ou stressé."
  - Location paragraph 37===from https://www.novexpat.com/fr/culture-francaise/etiquette-a-la-francaise-et-savoir-vivre-a-table

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: The apéro-dînatoire is an informal way of gathering where guests eat small savory bites while standing or mingling, without formal seating or strict rules, emphasizing relaxed interaction over structured dining.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "L'apéro-dînatoire, c'est parfait pour passer une soirée entre amis ou en famille sans trop s'organiser... Pas de règles strictes, hormis celle de passer un bon moment, de papoter et de grignoter ensemble."
  - Location paragraph 24===from https://www.novexpat.com/fr/culture-francaise/etiquette-a-la-francaise-et-savoir-vivre-a-table

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: A “bonne franquette” meal, such as a raclette night, is intentionally informal and emphasizes shared participation rather than formal preparation by the host, fostering a convivial and relaxed atmosphere.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "La raclette incarne vraiment l'esprit à la bonne franquette. C'est-à-dire que ce n'est pas un repas formel, mais plutôt un moment de partage et de convivialité, où chacun participe à sa manière, sans que tout repose sur la préparation de l'hôte."
  - Location paragraph 28===from https://www.novexpat.com/fr/culture-francaise/etiquette-a-la-francaise-et-savoir-vivre-a-table

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: For casual dinners, guests are encouraged to dress comfortably, and hosts may explicitly signal informality by saying things like “viens comme tu es” (come as you are).
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "C'est plutôt décontracté ce soir, alors viens comme tu es !"
  - Location paragraph 33===from https://www.novexpat.com/fr/culture-francaise/etiquette-a-la-francaise-et-savoir-vivre-a-table

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: Compliments in French culture must be sincere and authentic, as fake or exaggerated compliments are easily detected and not appreciated.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "Les Français peuvent facilement repérer les compliments faux ou exagérés."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://imagyna.fr/culture/compliment-en-e/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: Compliments should be specific rather than generic, highlighting particular qualities or actions instead of using vague praise.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "Ne vous contentez pas de dire « Tu es beau » ou « Tu es belle ». Soyez précis et dites à la personne ce que vous aimez chez elle."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://imagyna.fr/culture/compliment-en-e/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: Compliments should be given at the appropriate moment; delaying too long may reduce their impact because the person might no longer remember the context.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "Les compliments doivent être faits au bon moment. Si vous attendez trop longtemps, la personne risque d’oublier ce que vous avez apprécié."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://imagyna.fr/culture/compliment-en-e/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: Compliments should be positive and encouraging, avoiding any negative or critical undertones.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "Les compliments doivent être positifs et encourageants. Évitez de faire des compliments négatifs ou critiques."
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://imagyna.fr/culture/compliment-en-e/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: The choice between "tu es" and "vous êtes" in French compliments depends on the level of formality and the relationship with the person being addressed. "Tu es" is used for informal situations with friends, family, children, or those younger or of equal/lower status, while "vous êtes" is used in formal contexts, with strangers, elders, authority figures, or people of higher status.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "The 'Tu es' is the French singular form of 'You are.' You can use it to describe someone or something. The only catch is that you should use it with people you have friendly or informal relationships with. A friend, family member, and a child are perfect examples of using this expression."
  - Location paragraph 10

- ===from https://www.ccubeacademy.com/compliments-in-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: When receiving a compliment in French, one should respond politely and graciously without dismissing or minimizing it, using expressions such as "merci" (thank you) and acknowledging the kindness of the gesture.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "While Receiving compliments • Accept the compliment graciously Say 'thank you' and acknowledge the person’s kind words. • Don’t deflect or minimize the compliment Avoid saying things like 'it was nothing' or 'I could have done better.'"
  - Location paragraph 28===from https://www.ccubeacademy.com/compliments-in-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: In professional settings, French cultural norms favor sincere, specific, timely, and professionally worded compliments that focus on positive achievements rather than general praise.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "While Giving compliments • Be sincere Make sure your compliment is genuine and specific to the person and their work. • Focus on the positive Instead of criticizing what a person did wrong, focus on what they did right. • Be specific The more specific your compliment is, the more meaningful it will be. Instead of saying, 'good job,' say, 'I really appreciate how you handled that difficult situation.' • Be timely Don’t wait too long to give a compliment. Try to give it as soon as possible after the person has done something noteworthy. • Use appropriate language Keep your language professional and appropriate for the workplace."
  - Location paragraph 27===from https://www.ccubeacademy.com/compliments-in-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: When praised for a group achievement, it is culturally appropriate to accept the compliment while sharing credit with others who contributed, especially in a work environment.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "However, you should always give credit where it is due and accept the compliment while sharing the credit. For example, you successfully got a new project at work. So, when everyone around is congratulating & praising you, it would be right if you share the credit with your team or contributors. You can say 'Rien de tout ça n’aurait été possible sans mon équipe' which means 'None of this would have been possible without my team.'"
  - Location paragraph 29===from https://www.ccubeacademy.com/compliments-in-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: In French culture, complimenting food is an essential part of etiquette, especially when dining at someone’s home or in a restaurant, and should include praise for taste, presentation, ingredients, and the chef’s skill.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "French language and French people are all about etiquette. Complimenting the host when invited to dinner is one of the most crucial parts of French etiquette. So, whether dining out in a restaurant or at someone’s house, you should compliment the chef or the host if you like the food."
  - Location paragraph 25===from https://www.ccubeacademy.com/compliments-in-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: The French education system is highly centralized, with the national government playing a strong role in organizing and funding education through the Ministry of National Education and the Ministry of Higher Education, Research, and Innovation.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "Le système éducatif français se caractérise par une forte présence de l’État dans l’organisation et le financement de l’éducation. Il est gouverné au niveau national par le ministère de l’Éducation nationale et le ministère de l’Enseignement supérieur, de la Recherche et de l’Innovation dans le cadre général fixé par le législateur..."  
  - Location p2===from https://www.france-education-international.fr/article/le-systeme-educatif-francais

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: The official language used in all educational instruction in France is French.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "La langue officielle dans l'enseignement est le français."  
  - Location p2===from https://www.france-education-international.fr/article/le-systeme-educatif-francais

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: Public education in France is free and secular (laïc).
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "L’enseignement public est gratuit et laïc."  
  - Location p2===from https://www.france-education-international.fr/article/le-systeme-educatif-francais

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: Education is compulsory for all children in France from the age of 3 to 16.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "Selon le Code de l’éducation, l’instruction est obligatoire pour chaque enfant entre l’âge de 3 ans et l’âge de 16 ans."  
  - Location p2===from https://www.france-education-international.fr/article/le-systeme-educatif-francais

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: Admission to higher education in France requires obtaining the national baccalauréat diploma.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "L’accès à l’enseignement supérieur est conditionné par l’obtention d’un diplôme national, le baccalauréat."  
  - Location p1===from https://www.france-education-international.fr/article/le-systeme-educatif-francais

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: The baccalauréat is considered the first university degree in the French education system.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "Celui-ci ouvre l’accès à l’enseignement supérieur, il constitue le premier grade universitaire."  
  - Location p5===from https://www.france-education-international.fr/article/le-systeme-educatif-francais

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: Insults in French should be used responsibly and only in appropriate situations, as they can be offensive.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Be warned, though—some expressions in this list might be offensive, so make sure you use them responsibly and in appropriate situations."
  - Location p2===from https://frenchlanguagebasics.com/common-french-phrases-insults-swearing

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: Polite and respectful language is preferred over the use of insults or vulgar expressions in French culture.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Although we always encourage using polite and respectful language, understanding these phrases can be beneficial..."
  - Location p2===from https://frenchlanguagebasics.com/common-french-phrases-insults-swearing

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: There is a cultural recognition that language can be powerful, and individuals are encouraged to use it responsibly.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Remember, language can be powerful, and it’s essential to use it responsibly. It’s always better to communicate politely and respectfully with others."
  - Location p3===from https://frenchlanguagebasics.com/common-french-phrases-insults-swearing

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: The most frequently used insults among French people include "connard/connasse," "con/conne," "abruti," "enculé," and "bouffon" or "salaud/salope," according to survey data.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Un rapport sur les violences verbales, publié par la Fondation Jean-Jaurès et la Macif, a identifié onze injures souvent proférées par les Français."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.leparisien.fr/societe/con-bouffon-abruti-quelles-sont-les-insultes-que-les-francais-utilisent-le-plus-20-09-2024-YPTWKY2GGFAW3BOZCICYJSJE6A.php

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: "Connard" or "connasse" is the most commonly cited insult, used by 48% of respondents, and it is the first one that comes to mind for 27% of them.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Cette insulte est la plus citée par les répondants (48 %) et dans 27 % des cas, c’est celle qui sort en premier."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.leparisien.fr/societe/con-bouffon-abruti-quelles-sont-les-insultes-que-les-francais-utilisent-le-plus-20-09-2024-YPTWKY2GGFAW3BOZCICYJSJE6A.php

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: "Con" or "conne" is a slightly milder variant of "connard/connasse" and is used by 43% of respondents, with 23% reporting it as their go-to insult.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Une légère variante de l’injure en tête du classement vient juste après. Elle est employée par 43 % des personnes interrogées, et pour 23 %, en premier."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.leparisien.fr/societe/con-bouffon-abruti-quelles-sont-les-insultes-que-les-francais-utilisent-le-plus-20-09-2024-YPTWKY2GGFAW3BOZCICYJSJE6A.php

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: "Abruti" is used by 31% of respondents, with 11% citing it as their first choice; it is more common among those over 50 years old (39%) compared to those under 35 (19%).
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "31 % des répondants ont confié avoir recours à cette insulte, et ils sont 11 % à la citer en premier. À noter qu’elle est davantage employée par les plus de 50 ans (39 %). Les moins de 35 ans ne sont que 19 % à la prononcer."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.leparisien.fr/societe/con-bouffon-abruti-quelles-sont-les-insultes-que-les-francais-utilisent-le-plus-20-09-2024-YPTWKY2GGFAW3BOZCICYJSJE6A.php

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: Despite being both homophobic and sexist, "enculé" is still used by 13% of French respondents overall and by 19% of men specifically.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Bien qu’homophobe et sexiste, cette insulte est encore utilisée par 13 % des Français. Le sondage précise que chez les hommes, l’emploi de cette injure grimpe à 19 %."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.leparisien.fr/societe/con-bouffon-abruti-quelles-sont-les-insultes-que-les-francais-utilisent-le-plus-20-09-2024-YPTWKY2GGFAW3BOZCICYJSJE6A.php

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: "Bouffon" and "salaud/salope" are tied in usage, each reported by 11% of respondents; "salope" is admitted to be used by 13% of men and 14% of people under 35.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "On retrouve ces deux insultes à ex aequo, utilisées par 11 % des personnes interrogées. Dans le cas de « salope », 13 % d’hommes ont admis l’utiliser, et 14 % des moins de 35 ans."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.leparisien.fr/societe/con-bouffon-abruti-quelles-sont-les-insultes-que-les-francais-utilisent-le-plus-20-09-2024-YPTWKY2GGFAW3BOZCICYJSJE6A.php

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: Insults can lead to legal penalties, especially if they are public or discriminatory; for example, a public homophobic and sexist insult like "enculé" can result in up to one year in prison and a €45,000 fine.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Ainsi, une injure sexiste et homophobe comme « enculé », qui arrive en 4e place du classement, est passible d’un an d’emprisonnement et de 45 000 euros d’amende si elle est publique, et d’une amende de 1 500 euros si ce n’est pas le cas."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.leparisien.fr/societe/con-bouffon-abruti-quelles-sont-les-insultes-que-les-francais-utilisent-le-plus-20-09-2024-YPTWKY2GGFAW3BOZCICYJSJE6A.php

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: The most common situation in which French people use insults is while driving or cycling, particularly when reacting to other drivers’ behavior on the road.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "D’après un rapport sur les violences verbales de la Fondation Jean-Jaurès et de la Macif, 67 % des Français déclarent proférer des insultes sur la route principalement."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.20minutes.fr/societe/4111040-20240919-devoile-classement-insultes-plus-proferees-francais-mal

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: Insults like “connard/connasse” and “con/conne” are among the most frequently used by French individuals, with nearly half of respondents admitting to using them, indicating a cultural tendency toward gendered derogatory language in moments of anger.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Pour 48 % des personnes interrogées, l’insulte « connard/connasse » est utilisée, pour 27 % d’entre elles, c’est même la première à sortir. Un peu dans le même genre, « con/conne » est utilisé par 43 % des personnes interrogées et pour 23 %, en premier."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.20minutes.fr/societe/4111040-20240919-devoile-classement-insultes-plus-proferees-francais-mal

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: The insult “abruti” is more commonly used by individuals over 50 years old, suggesting generational differences in preferred forms of verbal offense.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Utilisée par 31 % des Français, et surtout par les plus de 50 ans (39 % des interrogés), l’insulte « abruti » se glisse juste après les incontournables cités plus haut."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.20minutes.fr/societe/4111040-20240919-devoile-classement-insultes-plus-proferees-francais-mal

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: The use of the insult “enculé” is recognized as homophobic and sexist, constitutes a verbal aggression under French law, and may lead to legal action.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Ainsi, l’utilisation de cette expression « constitue une agression verbale homophobe, peut faire l’objet d’un dépôt de plainte et est punie par la loi »."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.20minutes.fr/societe/4111040-20240919-devoile-classement-insultes-plus-proferees-francais-mal

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: There is public awareness that certain insults such as “salope” or “fils de pute” carry deep ethical and sexual connotations, reinforcing gender stereotypes and shifting moral judgment onto women.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Quand le salaud se ment à lui-même et nie sa propre liberté, avec une inauthenticité coupable. Au féminin, la salope quitte le terrain de l’éthique, de la grande morale qui brasse les concepts de bien et de mal, pour entrer dans celui de la perversion sexuelle."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.20minutes.fr/societe/4111040-20240919-devoile-classement-insultes-plus-proferees-francais-mal

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: The term “tocard” is more commonly used by individuals under 35 years old, reflecting age-based variation in slang usage during verbal conflicts.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "« Tocard », par 7 %, surtout par les moins de 35 ans."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.20minutes.fr/societe/4111040-20240919-devoile-classement-insultes-plus-proferees-francais-mal

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.feature: Stereotypes are characteristics—real or imagined—assigned to a group of people perceived as homogeneous and uniform, often based on national or cultural identity.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.original:
- Quoted text "Les stéréotypes sont des caractéristiques réelles ou imaginaires, attribuées à un certain groupe de personnes que l’on considère de manière homogène et uniforme."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/stereotypes-frequents-sur-les-francais/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.feature: While shared cultural values, traditions, and beliefs may give rise to stereotypes, individuals within a culture vary significantly due to unique life experiences, and thus should not be generalized.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.original:
- Quoted text "La vérité est que chaque pays et chaque culture crée et promeut un ensemble de valeurs morales, de traditions et de croyances chez ses citoyens, et c’est de là que naissent les stéréotypes. Toutefois, il est important de se rappeler que, bien que nous venions du même pays, nous sommes tous différents et avons chacun des expériences de vie uniques qui nous façonnent tous différemment."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/stereotypes-frequents-sur-les-francais/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.feature: It is essential to remain open-minded when encountering cultural stereotypes because what may be true for one individual may not apply to another, even within the same cultural group.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.original:
- Quoted text "C’est pourquoi il est essentiel de faire preuve d’ouverture d’esprit et de se souvenir que ce qui est vrai pour une personne peut ne pas l’être pour une autre."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/stereotypes-frequents-sur-les-francais/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: French traffic rules may differ from other EU countries in areas such as permitted blood alcohol levels, speed limits depending on road and vehicle types, required safety equipment for cyclists and drivers, mandatory daytime headlight use and/or winter tires, and driving on the left side of the road (which does not apply in France but is noted as an example of national variation).
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Les pays de l’UE peuvent appliquer des règles différentes dans de nombreux domaines, telles que le taux d'alcoolémie autorisé (certains pays appliquent une tolérance zéro); les limites de vitesse selon le type de routes et de véhicules; les équipements de sécurité requis pour les cyclistes et les automobilistes; l'utilisation obligatoire des phares en plein jour et/ou des pneus d'hiver; la conduite à gauche (à Chypre, en Irlande et à Malte)."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://europa.eu/youreurope/citizens/travel/driving-abroad/road-rules-and-safety/index_fr.htm

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In France, wearing seat belts is mandatory in all vehicles, including buses and minibuses.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "le port de la ceinture de sécurité est obligatoire dans tous les véhicules, y compris les autocars et les minibus;"
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://europa.eu/youreurope/citizens/travel/driving-abroad/road-rules-and-safety/index_fr.htm

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Vehicles in France must be equipped with appropriate child restraint devices for children.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "les voitures et les poids-lourds (et, si possible les autres véhicules) doivent être équipés de dispositifs adéquats de retenue pour enfants;"
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://europa.eu/youreurope/citizens/travel/driving-abroad/road-rules-and-safety/index_fr.htm

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Using a handheld mobile phone while driving is prohibited in France unless a hands-free kit is used.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "l'utilisation d'un téléphone portable au volant sans kit «mains libres» est interdite."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://europa.eu/youreurope/citizens/travel/driving-abroad/road-rules-and-safety/index_fr.htm

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In the absence of traffic signs, vehicles coming from the right have priority, which is a unique rule in Europe.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In the absence of signage, any vehicle coming from the right has priority. This rule, unique in Europe, applies even in unmarked roundabouts and in most urban intersections."
  - Location p13===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: A complete stop is required at a STOP sign, regardless of traffic presence, and drivers must yield to all other vehicles.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Required action Complete stop required" and "Respect the stop even without traffic"
  - Location p10===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: At a Yield sign, drivers must give way but are not required to stop if the road is clear.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Triangle pointing down with red border" and "Give way without stopping if road is clear"
  - Location p11===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: A yellow diamond sign indicates a priority road where the driver has right of way, but must remain cautious at intersections.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Yellow diamond indicating a priority route" and "You have priority"
  - Location p12===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: A crossed yellow diamond sign indicates the end of a priority road, after which standard right-of-way rules apply.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Crossed yellow diamond indicating end of priority road" and "No more automatic priority"
  - Location p14===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: French direction signs use specific colors to indicate road types blue for highways, green for national roads, white for departmental roads, and yellow for temporary diversions.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "The French directional system uses a strict color code allowing immediate identification of road type and associated services."
  - Location p15===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Blue direction signs specifically indicate access to toll highways, where the speed limit is typically 130 km/h (reduced in rain).
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Blue Color... Access to toll highways" and "Speed limit 130 km/h (110 in rain)"
  - Location p16===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Prohibition signs, marked by a red circle, are strictly enforced with automated systems and carry high fines for violations.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "French prohibition signs are particularly strictly enforced, with an automated ticketing system expanding rapidly."
  - Location p19===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Obligation signs with a blue background require drivers to follow specific instructions, such as mandatory directions or minimum speeds, and non-compliance is considered an infraction.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Obligation signs, recognizable by their blue background and white border, impose specific behaviors on drivers. Their non-compliance constitutes an infraction just like crossing a prohibition."
  - Location p22===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Triangular warning signs alert drivers to upcoming dangers such as weather conditions, road configuration issues, or special situations like wildlife crossings.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Triangular warning signs alert about upcoming dangers. France uses many specific signs related to its geography and climate particularities that should be well known."
  - Location p25===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In France, warning signs are typically red or yellow to signal potential hazards ahead.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Warning signs in France are often red or yellow to advise of potential danger."
  - Location p6===from https://www.rhinocarhire.com/France/France-Road-Signs.aspx

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: French warning signs provide advance notice of specific dangers such as pedestrian crossings, animals on the road, or road conditions.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "You should take note of any warning signs in France as they are designed to alert you of possible dangers ahead."
  - Location p6===from https://www.rhinocarhire.com/France/France-Road-Signs.aspx

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In France, mandatory signs must be strictly followed, as they require drivers to perform specific actions rather than offering suggestions.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Mandatory road signs in France are used where you are required to carry out a specific task, they are not suggestions, information or advisory signs, they must be adhered to..."
  - Location p10===from https://www.rhinocarhire.com/France/France-Road-Signs.aspx

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Prohibitory signs in France are used to restrict certain vehicle types or driving actions, such as banning overtaking or setting speed limits.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Prohibitory road signs in France are used on all road types in France, often to restrict certain types of vehicles and certain manoeuvres such as prohibiting u-turns or setting maximum speeds."
  - Location p14===from https://www.rhinocarhire.com/France/France-Road-Signs.aspx

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Priority signs in France indicate which traffic has the right-of-way at intersections or narrow roads.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Priority road signs in France are designed to clarify who has priority at the junction / road ahead."
  - Location p12===from https://www.rhinocarhire.com/France/France-Road-Signs.aspx

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The term "Rappel" under a speed indicator sign means that the current speed limit remains in effect both before and after the sign; it serves as a reminder rather than indicating a change in speed limit.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "It means that you are still in that speed zone both before and after the sign so it’s just reminding you of the limit not informing you that it is changing to a new limit."
  - Location p5===from https://www.drive-france.com/faqs/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: A yield sign in France requires drivers to give way to traffic approaching from both the left and right, though stopping is not mandatory if no vehicles are coming.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "At a yield sign in France, you must yield to traffic from the left and right, but don't have to stop if there is no one coming."
  - Location p7===from https://www.drive-france.com/faqs/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Stop signs in France use the word “Stop” and have the same meaning as in English, requiring drivers to come to a complete stop.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Fortunately, 'Stop' means the same in English as French so you should have no trouble spotting these."
  - Location p8===from https://www.drive-france.com/faqs/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: At certain junctions, the road turning right may have priority over the road continuing straight ahead, which requires cautious approach.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Approach junctions with these signs on with caution as it isn’t always the road going straight on that has priority. See the example below it’s the road turning right that has priority."
  - Location p9===from https://www.drive-france.com/faqs/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Triangular road signs in France, with the point facing downward and thick red edges, are used to warn drivers of upcoming conditions or hazards.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "These are warning signs, and many are self-explanatory and some you will be familiar with."
  - Location p10===from https://www.drive-france.com/faqs/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Directional signs in France use specific colors to indicate the type of road blue for autoroutes, green for major roads, yellow for temporary routes or detours, and white for local roads.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Directional road signs in France are colour coded Blue indicates Autoroute. Green indicates 'important' or major roads. Yellow indicates temporary roads - often with déviations – detours. White indicates local roads."
  - Location p11===from https://www.drive-france.com/faqs/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Signs that indicate mandatory actions are circular with a white border and blue background, signaling what drivers must do.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "These show what you must do. They are circular with a white edge and a blue background and regulate what you must do."
  - Location p13===from https://www.drive-france.com/faqs/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In cities across France, low emission zones require all vehicles to display a Crit’Air sticker indicating their emissions level; failure to comply results in a fine.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In a bid to reduce air pollution in Paris and many other cities in France they have introduced a 'Low Emission Zone' scheme whereby all vehicles must display a Crit Air sticker determining its carbon emissions. Failure to do so will result in a fine."
  - Location p14===from https://www.drive-france.com/faqs/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The "Verglas Frequent" sign warns that ice and snow are common on the road, indicating possible need for winter tires or snow chains.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Verglas Frequent in English means that there is often ice and snow on this particular road. The word Verglas is 'Ice' basically. So you may need winter tyres and in some areas even snow chains."
  - Location p15===from https://www.drive-france.com/faqs/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Carpool lanes in France are restricted to vehicles with two or more occupants; solo drivers using them face a €135 fine, and usage is monitored by cameras.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "The fine for using the lanes if driving on your own is 135 euros. They do have cameras to monitor the lanes so you must have 2 or more people in the vehicle."
  - Location p16===from https://www.drive-france.com/faqs/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: At a French stop sign, drivers must come to a complete stop with wheels fully stopped just before the bold solid white line painted across the road.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "At a French Stop sign, your vehicle must come to a total stop (wheels should stop turning) just before the solid white line."
  - Location p7===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Failing to make a complete stop at a stop sign in France results in a €135 fine and the loss of four points on the driver’s license.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "The fine for not completely stopping at a stop sign is €135 along with four points withdrawal on your French driver’s license."
  - Location p7===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers in France must follow speed limits indicated by road markings on the pavement, even if there is no corresponding traffic sign.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "You must follow speed limit pavement markings in France, even when there is no speed limit traffic sign."
  - Location p18===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: French traffic signs primarily use symbols rather than words to communicate their meaning.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Compared to the United States, traffic signs in France use symbols rather than words to convey their message."
  - Location p2===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In France, certain traffic rules apply to entire zones that may include multiple streets, and these zones are entered and exited based on specific signage.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Whereas a traffic sign is valid until another sign changes the rule, French road signage also uses the concept of zone. A zone usually includes multiple streets."
  - Location p16===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Certain streets and neighborhoods in Paris are permanently pedestrianized, prohibiting motorized vehicles year-round to create a traffic-free environment for walking and leisure.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "One hundred or so streets, including the Rue Cler, Rue de Lévis, Rue de Lutèce, and Rue des Barres, are pedestrianized in Paris! Each arrondissement has some and it is a pleasure to stroll through them."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://parisjetaime.com/eng/article/pedestrianized-areas-of-paris-a002

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The central Les Halles district is reserved exclusively for pedestrians every day of the year, allowing visitors to walk freely without encountering motorized traffic.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Every day of the year, the central Les Halles district is reserved just for pedestrians go for a stroll in the area after a visit to the Centre Pompidou, pick up souvenirs with the family under the Canopée des Halles and have a drink on a cafe terrace in Rue Montorgueil without being bothered by traffic … What a luxury!"
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://parisjetaime.com/eng/article/pedestrianized-areas-of-paris-a002

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Several historic streets near Notre-Dame and the Luxembourg Gardens are pedestrianized, offering access to cultural and gastronomic experiences without motor vehicle interference.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Around Notre-Dame and the Luxembourg Gardens, several pedestrianized streets are full of history Rue de la Huchette with its restaurants and jazz clubs, and notably Rue Mouffetard with its many local food stores, ideal for discovering French gastronomy."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://parisjetaime.com/eng/article/pedestrianized-areas-of-paris-a002

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Cour Saint-Emilion is a pedestrian-only elongated courtyard lined with shops, cafes, and restaurants, designed to provide a shopping and dining experience away from busy roads.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Beside Bercy Park, the Cour Saint-Emilion is a pedestrianized elongated courtyard lined with former wine warehouses converted into boutiques, cafes and restaurants. A perfect place to shop away from busy roads."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://parisjetaime.com/eng/article/pedestrianized-areas-of-paris-a002

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Rue Daguerre is a pedestrianized street known for its village-like atmosphere, featuring local food shops and cafes accessible only to walkers.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Another pedestrianized typically-Parisian street for a stroll is the Rue Daguerre. Close to Denfert-Rochereau, this bustling village-like street has local bakers, cheesemongers, and typical cafes with a relaxed atmosphere."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://parisjetaime.com/eng/article/pedestrianized-areas-of-paris-a002

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Key public squares such as Place de la République and Place de la Bastille have been successfully transformed into pedestrian zones, enhancing accessibility and urban comfort.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Finally, Paris’s many splendid covered passages are of architectural interest and reserved for pedestrians. Real gems to discover, anytime."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://parisjetaime.com/eng/article/pedestrianized-areas-of-paris-a002

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Paris’s covered passages are architecturally significant areas that are exclusively reserved for pedestrian use at all times.
