  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.momentslog.com/culture/how-traditional-french-festivals-celebrate-regional-culture-and-heritage

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: The Fête de la Gastronomie celebrates regional culinary diversity by highlighting local specialties, ingredients, and cooking techniques that vary across regions, thus honoring France’s regional gastronomic heritage.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "This annual event... is a heartfelt homage to the rich tapestry of French cuisine that varies from region to region."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.momentslog.com/culture/how-traditional-french-festivals-celebrate-regional-culture-and-heritage

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: Les Fêtes de Bayonne serve as a tribute to Basque cultural identity by emphasizing traditional clothing, music, food, and communal values specific to the Basque region within France.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Les Fêtes de Bayonne is a vibrant celebration that encapsulates the essence of Basque culture... a heartfelt tribute to the rich heritage of the Basque people."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.momentslog.com/culture/how-traditional-french-festivals-celebrate-regional-culture-and-heritage

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: The French celebrate the New Year on January 1st with greetings of "Bonne Année" at midnight, typically among family and friends.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Le « Nouvel an » est fêté à 00H00, entre amis et/ou famille. Et on se dit “Bonne Année”."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: On May 1st, it is customary to give lily of the valley (muguet) to loved ones as a symbol of spring.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "En général, le 1er mai, on offre du muguet à ses proches, puisque cette plante symbolise le printemps."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: On the evening of July 14th, people across France attend fireworks displays and military parades to commemorate the national holiday.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "C’est pourquoi aujourd’hui, le soir du 14 juillet, on assiste à des feux d’artifice et défilés militaires partout en France."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: During Easter celebrations, children participate in chocolate egg hunts in gardens, and people give chocolates to their relatives.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Lors de cette fête, les enfants participent à des chasses aux oeufs (en chocolat) dans les jardins et l’on offre des chocolats à ses proches."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: In some cities in France, fireworks are held on the evening of August 15th to mark the Assumption.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Dans certaines villes de France, le soir du 15 août on peut assister à des feux d’artifice."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: French families celebrate Christmas either on the evening of December 24th or on December 25th, often exchanging gifts and eating traditional foods such as oysters, foie gras, and Yule log cake.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Certaines familles fêtent Noël le soir du 24 (le « réveillon de Noël ») en ouvrant les cadeaux uniquement à minuit ou le lendemain matin et certaines familles fêtent Noël le 25 décembre."  
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: Couples in France celebrate Valentine’s Day by going to restaurants, giving flowers, or sharing time together, especially in Paris, known as the "city of lovers."
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Mais vous pouvez aller au restaurant, avec votre amoureux.euse, offrir des fleurs à votre douce ou à votre amoureux!"  
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: Grandmothers are honored on this day through handmade gifts, family meals, and intergenerational activities organized by schools and nurseries.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "C’est une fête non officielle mais largement reconnue... aux petits-enfants de rendre hommage à leurs grands-mères avec des dessins, des poèmes, ou un petit cadeau, aux familles de partager un repas, passer un moment ensemble, aux écoles et crèches d’organiser des ateliers intergénérationnels..."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: Children give handmade poems, drawings, or crafts to their mothers, especially in preschools and primary schools, while adults may offer flowers, gifts, or organize family meals.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Les enfants offrent souvent des poèmes, dessins ou objets faits main à leur maman, surtout dans les écoles maternelles et primaires. Les adultes offrent plutôt des fleurs, des cadeaux, un repas au restaurant, ou un moment en famille."  
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: Not enough explicit evidence provided about specific cultural practices related to Father's Day beyond its date.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text None  
  - Location Not applicable===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: On June 21st, music becomes a shared public experience with free concerts in streets, parks, bars, and museums, open to both amateur and professional musicians.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Des concerts gratuits partout  dans les rues, les bars, les parcs, les musées, les gares… Des groupes amateurs jouent aux côtés d’artistes confirmés."  
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://absolutelyfrench.com/la-culture-francaise-les-fetes-en-france/

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: The military parade on the Champs-Élysées and fireworks in Paris are key symbols of Bastille Day, representing national pride and patriotism.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "This day is marked by a number of important symbols such as the military parade on the Champs-Élysées and the fireworks that illuminate the Parisian sky."  
  - Location p3===from https://www.startfrenchnow.com/blog/post/les-fetes-traditionnelles-francaises-celebrations-et-coutumes-uniques?postLang=en

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: Preparing and eating crêpes is the central tradition of La Chandeleur, a festival celebrated on February 2nd, bringing families and friends together for a shared meal.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Today, 'la Chandeleur' is mostly known for its culinary tradition, crêpes! This delicious feast is highly appreciated in France and allows families and friends to gather around a friendly meal."  
  - Location p6===from https://www.startfrenchnow.com/blog/post/les-fetes-traditionnelles-francaises-celebrations-et-coutumes-uniques?postLang=en

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: A popular ritual during La Chandeleur involves flipping crêpes while holding a coin, believed to bring prosperity in the coming year.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "One of the most popular rituals is to flip the pancakes with a coin in hand, hoping for a prosperous year."  
  - Location p8===from https://www.startfrenchnow.com/blog/post/les-fetes-traditionnelles-francaises-celebrations-et-coutumes-uniques?postLang=en

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: The nativity scene and decorated Christmas trees are important symbols of Christmas in France, reflecting its religious significance and home traditions.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "The nativity scene is an important symbol of Christmas in France, representing the scene of Jesus' birth. The French decorate their homes with Christmas trees, garlands, and ornaments."  
  - Location p10===from https://www.startfrenchnow.com/blog/post/les-fetes-traditionnelles-francaises-celebrations-et-coutumes-uniques?postLang=en

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: On Christmas Eve, families gather for a festive meal called le Réveillon, followed by gift exchanges around the Christmas tree, emphasizing family togetherness.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Christmas Eve is an important moment in France, where families gather to share a festive meal called le Réveillon... After the meal, gifts are exchanged around the Christmas tree."  
  - Location p11===from https://www.startfrenchnow.com/blog/post/les-fetes-traditionnelles-francaises-celebrations-et-coutumes-uniques?postLang=en

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: La Fête de la Musique, held on June 21st, features free musical performances in public spaces, promoting artistic expression and public participation.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "La fête de la musique is an artistic celebration that takes place on June 21st, the day of the summer solstice in France... offering free performances accessible to all."  
  - Location p12===from https://www.startfrenchnow.com/blog/post/les-fetes-traditionnelles-francaises-celebrations-et-coutumes-uniques?postLang=en

Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.feature: The festival includes widespread musical events in streets, parks, and cafes, involving amateur and professional musicians and creating a nationwide festive atmosphere.
Geography_and_Customs-Dates of Significa.original:
- Quoted text "Outdoor concerts are organized in the streets and squares, showcasing the musical diversity of the country... Every year, the Music Festival brings together thousands of people who come to enjoy music and the festive atmosphere that prevails throughout the country."  
  - Location p14===from https://www.startfrenchnow.com/blog/post/les-fetes-traditionnelles-francaises-celebrations-et-coutumes-uniques?postLang=en

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: French consumers are increasingly using card and mobile payments, leading to a significant decline in cash usage for point-of-sale transactions, with card payments surpassing cash payments for the first time in 2024.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "The number of card payments at local points of sale exceeded cash payments for the first time in France in 2024."  
  - Location p1===from https://www.banque-france.fr/en/publications-and-statistics/publications/french-people-still-value-cash-despite-using-it-less-and-increasingly-turning-cards-and-mobile

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Despite using cash less frequently, the majority of French people still value cash and recognize its advantages, including its accessibility and acceptance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Nevertheless, the vast majority of French people continue to value cash and recognise its many advantages. Lastly, they also consider cash accessibility and acceptance to be very satisfactory."  
  - Location p1===from https://www.banque-france.fr/en/publications-and-statistics/publications/french-people-still-value-cash-despite-using-it-less-and-increasingly-turning-cards-and-mobile

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: The growth in online payments has contributed to the decline in cash usage, as non-cash methods like cards and digital wallets dominate online transactions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "The growth in online payments is also contributing to the decline in the use of cash. Indeed, non-cash payments have now captured almost all of this market in 2024, as in 2022, cards remained the most common payment instrument for online transactions with a 53% share..."  
  - Location p2===from https://www.banque-france.fr/en/publications-and-statistics/publications/french-people-still-value-cash-despite-using-it-less-and-increasingly-turning-cards-and-mobile

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: For online purchases, French consumers primarily use cards and electronic wallets such as PayPal, which together account for the vast majority of payment methods used.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "In 2024, online payment solutions accounted for almost one third (27%) of the payment methods used for online purchases. This figure includes the PayPal digital wallet, which alone accounted for almost 18%."  
  - Location p2===from https://www.banque-france.fr/en/publications-and-statistics/publications/french-people-still-value-cash-despite-using-it-less-and-increasingly-turning-cards-and-mobile

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: In the 19th and early 20th centuries, many people in France did not wash regularly, with peasants viewing dirt as protective and body odor as a sign of health and sexual vitality.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "In nineteenth- and early twentieth-century France, Zdatny writes, many people simply never washed. Peasants often considered dirt protective and sweat cleansing, and they viewed strong body odor as a sign of health and sexual vitality."
  - Location p3===from https://daily.jstor.org/bringing-personal-hygiene-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Urban and suburban residents often lacked practical means to bathe, even if they wanted to, due to absence of plumbing and sanitary waste disposal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "In cities and suburbs, there was rarely an easy way to wash, even if you were so inclined, and no way at all to dispose of human waste in a sanitary fashion."
  - Location p3===from https://daily.jstor.org/bringing-personal-hygiene-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Some religious communities regarded full-body washing beyond hands, face, and feet as morally wrong, even sinful.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "One woman explained that, living in a Carmelite convent even as late as the 1930s, washing any part of the body besides the hands, face, and feet was viewed as 'mortal sin.'"
  - Location p3===from https://daily.jstor.org/bringing-personal-hygiene-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: The French military promoted bathing by installing showers in barracks and training soldiers in personal hygiene practices such as regular bathing and changing underwear.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "After France’s defeat in the Franco-German war of 1870–71, the army stepped up its efforts to address this, installing plumbing for toilets and showers in its barracks, ridding the beds of lice, and training soldiers in the use of toothbrushes and the regular changing of underwear."
  - Location p4===from https://daily.jstor.org/bringing-personal-hygiene-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Government investment in sewer systems and running water in homes enabled more widespread bathing practices over time.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "So officials began building sewer systems, cleaning dirty canals, and insisting that landlords connect their buildings with water and sewer systems... But, gradually, millions of French families gained access to running water."
  - Location p5===from https://daily.jstor.org/bringing-personal-hygiene-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: After World War II, new housing with bathrooms, consumer advertising, and appliances like washing machines contributed to increased bathing and hygiene practices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "After World War II, a variety of forces pushed for greater cleanliness. A boom in residential construction meant more new houses with bathrooms... And growing access to consumer credit encouraged the purchase of washing machines and other labor-saving appliances."
  - Location p6===from https://daily.jstor.org/bringing-personal-hygiene-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: In many French homes, the toilet is located in a separate room from the bathing area, which contains the shower or bathtub and sink.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Thus, in many French apartments Toilettes → Small room with just a toilet (and maybe a tiny sink). Salle de bains → Room with bath/shower and sink, no toilet."  
  - Location p8===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/21/the-french-bathroom-situation-explained-with-useful-vocabulary

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: French people culturally regard using the toilet and bathing as two separate functions, which contributes to the physical separation of these facilities in homes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Cultural habits French people view bathing and toilet functions as distinctly separate."  
  - Location p8===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/21/the-french-bathroom-situation-explained-with-useful-vocabulary

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Before using the restroom in a café or restaurant, it is expected to order something; otherwise, it may be seen as impolite.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "In cafés or restaurants Order something first before using the bathroom. Walking straight in to use the toilet can seem rude."  
  - Location p12===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/21/the-french-bathroom-situation-explained-with-useful-vocabulary

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Discussions about bodily functions and bathroom use are generally avoided or kept brief and polite due to cultural norms of discretion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "The French are discreet about bathroom topics. Keep requests polite and brief."  
  - Location p14===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/21/the-french-bathroom-situation-explained-with-useful-vocabulary

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Travelers should carry their own tissues or toilet paper, as some public restrooms do not supply it.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Carry tissues or small packs of toilet paper when out and about. Some public toilets do not provide paper."  
  - Location p13===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/21/the-french-bathroom-situation-explained-with-useful-vocabulary

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Even when no one is present, it is considered polite and respectful of privacy to keep the toilet door closed in private homes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "In homes, always close the toilet door—even if no one’s home. It’s considered polite and private."  
  - Location p13===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/21/the-french-bathroom-situation-explained-with-useful-vocabulary

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Taking a bath or shower was traditionally practiced on a weekly basis, particularly in public bathhouses, and was considered a family ritual, especially during the 20th century when private bathrooms were small or inadequate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "C’était un rituel hérité de l’enfance de mes parents, se souvient-il. On habitait en HLM et notre salle de bain était très petite alors une fois par semaine, on allait tous se laver aux bains douches de Fives."
  - Location p7===from https://www.caminteresse.fr/histoire/la-spectaculaire-evolution-de-lhygiene-en-france-grace-aux-bains-douches-11189229/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Public bathhouses (bains-douches) are used by individuals and families, including working-class populations and those with limited access to private bathing facilities, to maintain personal hygiene.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "A l’ouverture, ce sont des gens travaillant dans l’hôtellerie et le bâtiment qui viennent se laver ici car ils vivent souvent dans de petites chambres sans douche"
  - Location p1===from https://www.caminteresse.fr/histoire/la-spectaculaire-evolution-de-lhygiene-en-france-grace-aux-bains-douches-11189229/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: In Paris, access to public bathhouses (bains-douches) has been free since 2000, supporting hygiene practices among vulnerable and low-income populations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "A Paris la gratuité est la règle depuis 2000 et la crise sanitaire en paupérisant les travailleurs précaires, a accru la fréquentation de ses 17 bains-douches."
  - Location p1===from https://www.caminteresse.fr/histoire/la-spectaculaire-evolution-de-lhygiene-en-france-grace-aux-bains-douches-11189229/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Bathing was uncommon among French kings and palace inhabitants, who instead cleaned themselves using a towel soaked in alcohol and perfume due to fears about the dangers of water.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "To shower, the inhabitants of the palace, including the king, wash themselves with a simple towel soaked in alcohol and perfume."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://francaiseasy.com/en/cleanliness-in-france-at-the-time-of-the-kings-why-didnt-they-wash-wigs-and-perfume-etc/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Marie Antoinette introduced a shift toward better hygiene by regularly bathing in a tub, even while clothed, which influenced King Louis XVI to gradually adopt cleaner habits.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Despite the perfumes and wigs, Marie Antoinette loved to bathe in a tub. Even if she was clothed, she loved to lounge for long hours in her bath. Inspired by the Queen, the King gradually learned cleanliness."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://francaiseasy.com/en/cleanliness-in-france-at-the-time-of-the-kings-why-didnt-they-wash-wigs-and-perfume-etc/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Private messaging is the most common activity among French social media users, indicating a preference for direct communication over other forms of engagement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Private messaging remains the most common activity, highlighting social media’s role in daily communication and entertainment."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.statista.com/topics/6278/social-media-usage-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: A significant majority of French social media users access platforms on a daily basis.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "French users who access social media platforms daily 69%"
  - Location paragraph 3 (Key insights section)===from https://www.statista.com/topics/6278/social-media-usage-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Facebook is predominantly used by individuals aged 25 to 34 in France, countering the perception that it is mainly popular with older generations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Facebook was favored by those aged 25 to 34, countering the idea that it is mainly for older generations."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.statista.com/topics/6278/social-media-usage-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Instagram is especially popular among users aged 18 to 34 in France, with its appeal decreasing among older age groups.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Instagram was especially popular with those aged 18 to 34, with its appeal declining among older users."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.statista.com/topics/6278/social-media-usage-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Social media platforms in France show an essentially equal distribution of male and female users across most platforms.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "On most social platforms, gender distribution was essentially equal."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.statista.com/topics/6278/social-media-usage-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: A large majority of French social media users trust product or service recommendations made by influencers.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Overall, 72 percent of social media users trusted influencer recommendations."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.statista.com/topics/6278/social-media-usage-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: The primary ethical concern for French social media users is the prevention of scams on social platforms.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "The most important ethical concern for French online users was banning scams on social platforms."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.statista.com/topics/6278/social-media-usage-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Social media are used by a minority of the French population as a source of news, with most people relying on traditional media like television; however, social media play a more prominent role among younger demographics.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "En 2018, seuls 2 % de la population (mais 10 % des 15-24 ans) s’informent exclusivement par les réseaux sociaux"
  - Location p6===from https://www.culture.gouv.fr/espace-documentation/statistiques-ministerielles-de-la-culture2/publications/collections-de-synthese/culture-etudes-2007-2025/s-informer-a-l-ere-du-numerique-ce-2023-4

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Younger individuals, particularly those aged 15–24, are significantly more likely to use social media exclusively for information compared to the general population.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "En 2018, seuls 2 % de la population (mais 10 % des 15-24 ans) s’informent exclusivement par les réseaux sociaux"
  - Location p6===from https://www.culture.gouv.fr/espace-documentation/statistiques-ministerielles-de-la-culture2/publications/collections-de-synthese/culture-etudes-2007-2025/s-informer-a-l-ere-du-numerique-ce-2023-4

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: The use of social media for information is more common among people with higher education degrees, intermediate professionals, and residents of Paris.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Leur utilisation est plus importante chez les jeunes, les diplômés d’études supérieures, les cadres et les professions intermédiaires, et les Parisiens."
  - Location p6===from https://www.culture.gouv.fr/espace-documentation/statistiques-ministerielles-de-la-culture2/publications/collections-de-synthese/culture-etudes-2007-2025/s-informer-a-l-ere-du-numerique-ce-2023-4

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: French adolescents (13–17 years) predominantly use TikTok, Snapchat, Instagram, and YouTube, with a growing trend toward virtual worlds and AI tools to personalize their social media experience.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Les adolescents adoptent de plus en plus les mondes virtuels et les outils d’intelligence artificielle pour personnaliser leur expérience."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://e-commerce-concept.eu/rapport-reseaux-sociaux-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Young adults (18–24 years) are the most active social media users in terms of time spent and engagement, particularly using Instagram, TikTok, YouTube, Snapchat, and LinkedIn, with notable participation in professional and creative activities such as social commerce.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Les jeunes adultes sont les plus actifs sur le plan professionnel et créatif, notamment via les outils de social commerce."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://e-commerce-concept.eu/rapport-reseaux-sociaux-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Adults aged 25–34 use social media to share personal life content while actively managing their professional careers, primarily through platforms like Instagram, Facebook, LinkedIn, YouTube, and TikTok.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Ils utilisent les réseaux sociaux pour partager leur quotidien tout en gérant activement leur carrière."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://e-commerce-concept.eu/rapport-reseaux-sociaux-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Adults aged 35–44 increasingly use social media for family-related and informational purposes, showing increased caution regarding personal data.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Usage familial et informationnel en hausse, avec une prudence accrue quant aux données personnelles."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://e-commerce-concept.eu/rapport-reseaux-sociaux-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Adults aged 45–54 maintain a loyal but passive presence on social media, focusing on practical and reliable content across platforms like Facebook, YouTube, LinkedIn, and Pinterest.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Présence fidèle mais passive, centrée sur les contenus pratiques et fiables."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://e-commerce-concept.eu/rapport-reseaux-sociaux-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Seniors aged 55–64 progressively adopt social media to stay connected with others and to learn new things, primarily using Facebook and YouTube.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Les seniors adoptent progressivement les réseaux pour rester connectés et apprendre."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://e-commerce-concept.eu/rapport-reseaux-sociaux-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Individuals aged 65 and older show moderate but steady adoption of social media, often supported by local digital workshops, with primary use of Facebook and YouTube.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Cette tranche connaît une adoption modérée mais constante, souvent facilitée par des ateliers numériques locaux."
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://e-commerce-concept.eu/rapport-reseaux-sociaux-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: YouTube is used by all age groups in France and remains a central platform regardless of generation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "YouTube reste incontournable pour tous les publics."
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://e-commerce-concept.eu/rapport-reseaux-sociaux-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: There is a clear generational difference in platform preferences, with TikTok and Instagram dominating among users under 35, while Facebook remains important for older generations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Les différences générationnelles restent marquées  TikTok et Instagram dominent chez les moins de 35 ans, tandis que Facebook conserve une place importante chez les générations plus âgées."
  - Location paragraph 19===from https://e-commerce-concept.eu/rapport-reseaux-sociaux-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: TikTok is the most time-consuming social media platform in France, with users spending an average of 32 hours and 48 minutes per month on the app, which is twice as much as the time spent on YouTube, the second-ranked platform.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "En 2024, le temps moyen mensuel passé par utilisateur atteint 32h48, soit tout de même 4 heures de moins que l’année dernière, mais deux fois plus que YouTube, deuxième du classement."
  - Location p7===from https://www.blogdumoderateur.com/internet-reseaux-sociaux-france-chiffres-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: The main reasons French social media users engage with these platforms are to stay in contact with family, pass time, and keep up with current events.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Les trois principaux motifs d’utilisation des réseaux sociaux sont  rester en contact avec sa famille (54 %), passer le temps (46,6 %) et rester au courant de l’actualité (30,4 %)."
  - Location p9===from https://www.blogdumoderateur.com/internet-reseaux-sociaux-france-chiffres-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Facebook is the most preferred social media platform in France, with 21.3% of internet users identifying it as their favorite.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "21,3 % des internautes français déclarent que Facebook est leur réseau social préféré, ce qui en fait le premier du classement."
  - Location p9===from https://www.blogdumoderateur.com/internet-reseaux-sociaux-france-chiffres-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: The most used social media platforms in France are Facebook, WhatsApp, Instagram, Messenger, Snapchat, TikTok, Pinterest, iMessage, LinkedIn, and X, in that order.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Voici les 10 réseaux sociaux les plus utilisés en France en 2024  Facebook (70,4 % des internautes), WhatsApp (66,6 %), Instagram (60,7 %), Messenger (53,9 %), Snapchat (42,3 %), TikTok (41 %), Pinterest (29,2 %), iMessage (27,2 %), LinkedIn (26,5 %), X (26,2 %)"
  - Location p6===from https://www.blogdumoderateur.com/internet-reseaux-sociaux-france-chiffres-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: On average, French social media users spend 1 hour and 48 minutes per day on social networks.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Le temps moyen quotidien passé sur les réseaux sociaux est de 1h48."
  - Location p9===from https://www.blogdumoderateur.com/internet-reseaux-sociaux-france-chiffres-2025/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: French social media users primarily access platforms via smartphones, making mobile-optimized experiences essential.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Une des tendances notables est l’augmentation de l’accès aux médias sociaux via les appareils mobiles. Selon l’INSEE, plus de 75% des utilisateurs se connectent principalement depuis leur smartphone."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://tonagencedigitale.com/statistique-utilisation-medias-sociaux-insee/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Younger users in France are shifting toward visually oriented platforms like Instagram and TikTok, while older users prefer Facebook and LinkedIn.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Les jeunes adultes de 18 à 24 ans sont souvent plus actifs sur des plateformes comme Instagram et TikTok. Les utilisateurs plus âgés peuvent favoriser Facebook pour rester en contact avec la famille et les amis."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://tonagencedigitale.com/statistique-utilisation-medias-sociaux-insee/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: A large majority of French social media users engage with platforms on a daily basis.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Fréquence d’utilisation  80% des utilisateurs se connectent quotidiennement"  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://tonagencedigitale.com/statistique-utilisation-medias-sociaux-insee/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Residents of major French cities use social media more frequently and diversely compared to those in rural areas.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Les habitants des grandes villes, comme Paris, Marseille et Lyon, sont nettement plus enclins à utiliser des médias sociaux variés par rapport à ceux vivant dans des zones rurales. Par exemple, presque 75% des Parisiens déclarent utiliser quotidiennement les médias sociaux, contre seulement 50% pour ceux situés dans des régions moins urbanisées."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://tonagencedigitale.com/statistique-utilisation-medias-sociaux-insee/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: French social media users increasingly favor visual content such as short videos and impactful images, influencing engagement strategies.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "L’INSEE a observé une croissance significative du contenu visuel sur les réseaux sociaux. Les utilisateurs privilégient désormais les vidéos courtes et les images percutantes, rendant le contenu visuel essentiel pour engager les audiences."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://tonagencedigitale.com/statistique-utilisation-medias-sociaux-insee/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: In France, the bride’s wedding dress is traditionally white, symbolizing style and sophistication, often featuring minimalist cuts, delicate embroidery, and a subtle veil.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "En France, la robe de mariée blanche est bien plus qu’une simple tenue  c’est une déclaration de style. Les grandes maisons de mode parisiennes ainsi que les nombreuses créatrices de robes de mariée françaises revisitent ce classique avec des coupes épurées, des broderies délicates et une touche d’audace bien dosée. Sans oublier le voile, subtilement posé, qui ajoute ce je-ne-sais-quoi de mystère."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.vogue.fr/article/traditions-mariage-france-incontournables-histoire

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: The vin d’honneur is a key part of French wedding celebrations, reflecting French hospitality and showcasing local products, where guests toast with champagne and enjoy small delicacies like oysters, foie gras, or gougères.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Le vin d’honneur, c’est la quintessence de l'hospitalité toute française tout en sublimant des bons produits locaux. Une coupe de champagne à la main, on trinque sous une guirlande lumineuse en dégustant des bouchées délicates—huîtres, foie gras ou gougères dorées à souhait."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.vogue.fr/article/traditions-mariage-france-incontournables-histoire

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: A champagne fountain made of crystal glasses is a traditional centerpiece at French weddings, symbolizing elegance and celebration, and is considered a highly photogenic moment.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "La fontaine de champagne est LA tradition qui allie élégance et spectacle. Un instant féerique qui capte tous les regards et célèbre le mariage avec une effervescence très française."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.vogue.fr/article/traditions-mariage-france-incontournables-histoire

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: While the bouquet toss is a classic tradition, some French brides modify it by incorporating ribbons attached to the bouquet, cutting them one by one until only one woman remains eligible to catch it, adding suspense and originality.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Certaines mariées troquent le lancer traditionnel contre une version plus originale  une danse autour du bouquet attaché à plusieurs rubans, chacun étant coupé par la mariée jusqu’à ce qu’il ne reste qu’une seule élue. Une touche de suspense pour cette ancienne tradition."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.vogue.fr/article/traditions-mariage-france-incontournables-histoire

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Instead of typical sweet wedding cakes, French weddings traditionally feature a croquembouche—a tower of cream-filled choux pastries bound with caramel—and its cutting is often accompanied by sparks for dramatic effect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Ici, exit les wedding cakes ultra-sucrés  en France, on mise traditionnellement sur la pièce montée en choux caramélisés, le fameux croquembouche. Entre tradition et artisanat, c’est un incontournable qui fait toujours son petit effet. Bonus  la découpe se fait souvent sous des étincelles, pour une touche de spectacle à la française."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.vogue.fr/article/traditions-mariage-france-incontournables-histoire

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: After the wedding night festivities, a relaxed brunch is commonly held the next day, featuring fresh bread, pastries, coffee, and juice, sometimes including onion soup as a nod to tradition to revive partygoers.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Après une nuit de fête, quoi de mieux qu’un brunch décontracté pour prolonger le plaisir ? Pain frais, viennoiseries, café fumant et jus pressé—une manière douce (et gourmande) de conclure un week-end de célébrations. Certains couples osent même la soupe à l’oignon au petit matin, un clin d’œil aux traditions d’antan pour rebooster les noctambules."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.vogue.fr/article/traditions-mariage-france-incontournables-histoire

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Throwing rice on newlyweds after the ceremony was a common French wedding tradition symbolizing prosperity, luck, and fertility, but it has been largely replaced by eco-friendly alternatives like petals, bubbles, or leaf confetti due to municipal bans.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Historiquement, lancer du riz sur les tous jeunes mariés sortant de la mairie ou de l'église était une tradition de mariage en France assez courante, héritée d'un rite païen. Symbolisant Demeter, la déesse grecque des cultures, le riz devait amener prospérité, chance et fertilité dans le nouveau foyer. Interdite par de nombreuses villes, la céréale peut être remplacée par des pétales, des bulles, des confettis faits en feuilles, ou autres alternatives plus écologiques et moins salissantes."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.vogue.fr/article/traditions-mariage-france-incontournables-histoire

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: In France, the arrival of the newlyweds is often marked by a festive car procession with honking vehicles, creating a cinematic and joyful entrance that signals the beginning of the celebration.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Oubliez les mariages trop sages  en France, l’arrivée des mariés se fait souvent en fanfare, avec un cortège de voitures klaxonnant. Un joyeux bazar qui annonce la couleur  la fête ne fait que commencer…"
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.vogue.fr/article/traditions-mariage-france-incontournables-histoire

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: French couples typically have two wedding ceremonies a civil ceremony that legally formalizes the marriage, followed by a symbolic or religious ceremony the next day that holds greater emotional or cultural significance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "French couples have two ceremonies—a civil and a symbolic service—over the course of two days. 'The civil ceremony is still very important in the French spirit,' Mylène and Geoffrey explain, 'because it’s the only ceremony that makes the marriage official.' Often, the civil ceremony is held the day before the wedding celebration with only close family and witnesses attending. 'The 'real' wedding is the day after and has more meaning, whether it's at a church or just a more symbolic, secular ceremony,' they add."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.brides.com/french-wedding-traditions-4795874

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Upon marriage, French couples receive a livret de famille, an official booklet issued by the mayor that legally formalizes the union and serves as a lifelong family record where children’s names and identities are later added.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "The livret de famille booklet is a civil registry that a mayor issues to a couple upon their betrothal. Used for legal purposes, it contains the couple's marriage certificate, birth certificate, passports, and other documents. The livret de famille is what legalizes the marriage, and is both 'mandatory' and a 'strong symbol that literally shows you're now creating your own family', according to Mylène and Geoffrey. 'It's used your whole life, and your children's names and identities will be added to it,' they note."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.brides.com/french-wedding-traditions-4795874

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: French weddings traditionally include témoins (witnesses) who stand with the couple during the ceremonies and sign the wedding registry; these witnesses can be of any age or gender and dress casually, though some modern couples are adopting Western-style bridesmaids and groomsmen.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Instead of bridesmaids and groomsmen, French couples have témoins or 'witnesses' that stand next to them during the ceremonies and sign the wedding registry. They can be any age or gender, and usually wear what they please. That said, Mylène and Geoffrey say more couples are opting to have bridesmaids and groomsmen in the more Westernized sense these days."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.brides.com/french-wedding-traditions-4795874

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: The civil ceremony at the town hall is the official legal act that formalizes the marriage, conducted by the mayor and including key steps such as reading articles of the civil code, obtaining spousal consent, and signing the registry.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Acte légal officiel, la cérémonie civile à la mairie est menée par le maire. La lecture des articles du code civil, les consentements des époux et la signature du registre sont des étapes clés."
  - Location p7===from https://www.le-mariage.info/traditions-mariage-francais-rituels-et-coutumes-a-connaitre/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Exchanging wedding rings is an important and emotional moment during the French civil wedding ceremony.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "L’échange des alliances est un moment fort et émotionnel."
  - Location p7===from https://www.le-mariage.info/traditions-mariage-francais-rituels-et-coutumes-a-connaitre/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: For religious couples, a religious wedding ceremony provides a spiritual aspect to the union, emphasizing divine blessing and mutual commitment through rituals like exchanging rings, reading epistles, and prayers.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Pour les couples croyants, la cérémonie religieuse ajoute une dimension spirituelle. Les rituels (catholiques, protestants, etc.) varient, mais tous mettent l’accent sur la bénédiction divine et l’engagement mutuel. L’échange des alliances, la lecture des épîtres et les prières sont des moments fondamentaux."
  - Location p8===from https://www.le-mariage.info/traditions-mariage-francais-rituels-et-coutumes-a-connaitre/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Many couples incorporate regional cultural elements from their place of origin into their wedding celebrations, reflecting France’s cultural diversity through traditional dances, costumes, and regional foods.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "La France, pays riche en diversité culturelle, présente des traditions régionales distinctes. En Provence, on trouve des danses traditionnelles et des sachets de lavande. En Bretagne, les costumes traditionnels et les fest-noz sont importants. En Alsace, les gâteaux et les costumes régionaux marquent la célébration. Plus de 80% des couples intègrent des éléments de leurs régions d’origine dans le mariage."
  - Location p9===from https://www.le-mariage.info/traditions-mariage-francais-rituels-et-coutumes-a-connaitre/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Meals are treated as special moments meant to be enjoyed mindfully, without distractions such as TV or phones, allowing individuals to savor each bite and avoid overeating.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "In France, we know how important it is to savor every mouthful, without distractions like TV or phones."
  - Location p5===from https://lacuisinedegeraldine.fr/en/eating-habits-of-the-french-eat-with-a-conscience

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: The French follow a strict daily schedule for meals—breakfast between 7 and 8 am, lunch between 12 and 1 pm, and dinner between 7 and 830 pm—and rarely skip meals, which helps prevent snacking and overeating.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Breakfast is between 7 and 8 am, lunch between 12 and 1 pm, and dinner between 7 and 830 pm. These times can be quite strict."
  - Location p6===from https://lacuisinedegeraldine.fr/en/eating-habits-of-the-french-eat-with-a-conscience

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Smaller portion sizes are standard in France, with an emphasis on quality over quantity; meals may include multiple courses like a starter to maintain balance despite smaller main dishes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "In France, quality is always preferred to quantity... it’s true that at home, dishes are smaller, but we often add a starter, such as raw vegetables, to balance the meal."
  - Location p7===from https://lacuisinedegeraldine.fr/en/eating-habits-of-the-french-eat-with-a-conscience

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Eating together with family or friends is a valued tradition that enhances enjoyment, encourages slower eating, and creates a relaxing, connected atmosphere during meals.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Sharing a meal with others makes the moment more enjoyable and encourages slower eating. Mealtime isn’t just a time to eat. It’s a special time of the day, to spend time together, talk about the day and reconnect."
  - Location p8===from https://lacuisinedegeraldine.fr/en/eating-habits-of-the-french-eat-with-a-conscience

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: There is a strong preference for fresh, seasonal, and locally sourced ingredients, with avoidance of processed or industrial ready-made meals to ensure nutritious and high-quality food.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "The French are often renowned for their love of fresh, quality ingredients... By avoiding processed foods and choosing fresh, seasonal ingredients, we naturally eat a diet rich in nutrients and low in harmful substances."
  - Location p9===from https://lacuisinedegeraldine.fr/en/eating-habits-of-the-french-eat-with-a-conscience

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Lunch is highly valued in French culture, while breakfast is often skipped and dinner can last for hours.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Breakfasts skipped, lunches revered, dinners that last hours."  
  - Location p2===from https://eatlikethefrench.com/how-the-french-eat/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: There is a customary pre-dinner social period called apéro, during which people relax, drink, and slow down before eating.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "That magical hour before dinner when time slows and drinks flow."  
  - Location p3===from https://eatlikethefrench.com/how-the-french-eat/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: The French emphasize honoring the dining moment through table etiquette and presence, rather than focusing on formality or luxury.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "It’s not about being fancy. It’s about honouring the moment."  
  - Location p4===from https://eatlikethefrench.com/how-the-french-eat/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: The French do not snack between meals but instead focus on savoring their food; they also avoid multitasking during meals, choosing instead to sit, chew, talk, and engage fully.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "The French don’t snack. They savour. They don’t multitask at the table. They sit, chew, talk, and refill your glass when"  
  - Location p5===from https://eatlikethefrench.com/how-the-french-eat/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: The French typically eat dinner later than people in some other European countries, usually around 2000 or even as late as 2100 for families with young children.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "In fact, they typically don’t sit at the dining table until around 2000 or even later. Families with young children might even start tucking into their evening meal as late as 2100."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/food-drink/french-eating-habits-608388/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Eating while walking or on public transport is highly frowned upon in France; people are expected to eat only while seated at a table.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "This is because French people never eat in transit. Therefore, munching on anything while walking around in public places is highly frowned upon. This applies to public transport, too."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/food-drink/french-eating-habits-608388/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Snacking between meals is uncommon in France and not part of typical French eating habits.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "After all, the French are almost famous for not snacking, which perhaps explains how they manage to stay so slim."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/food-drink/french-eating-habits-608388/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Lunch is considered the largest and most substantial meal of the day in France, often including multiple courses such as salad, bread, a main dish, and dessert.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "This is because lunch is known to be the biggest and most indulgent meal of the day in France... This often consists of a salad, bread, a main dish, and a dessert."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/food-drink/french-eating-habits-608388/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: French people generally serve and consume smaller portions, both at home and in restaurants, as part of their eating habits.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Whether they are eating at home or at a restaurant, French people generally opt for smaller portions."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/food-drink/french-eating-habits-608388/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: French people typically prefer cooking at home rather than eating out regularly, reserving restaurant visits for special occasions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "In fact, generally speaking, they tend to prefer cooking at home rather than eating out on a regular basis. Furthermore, reservations at restaurants are usually only made for special occasions."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/food-drink/french-eating-habits-608388/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Bread is placed directly on the tablecloth, not on a plate, as it is considered a basic necessity that should always be accessible during the meal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Visitors often look around confused when they realize there’s no bread plate at French tables, because bread goes directly on the tablecloth instead."
  - Location p2===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: It is considered improper to cut salad greens with a knife; instead, diners fold the leaves with a fork or use bread to assist, avoiding metal contact due to taste and tradition.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Using a knife to cut lettuce leaves is considered a major dining mistake in France... French diners fold their lettuce leaves with their fork, sometimes using a piece of bread to help guide the process, but they never slice through the greens."
  - Location p3===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Cheese is served after the main course and before dessert, acting as a savory transition that allows for continued red wine consumption.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "After finishing your main course in France, don’t expect dessert to arrive next—cheese comes first... The cheese course provides a savory bridge between the heartier main course and the lighter dessert that follows."
  - Location p4===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Lunch breaks typically last two hours, allowing time for multi-course meals, socializing, and relaxation as part of daily work life.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Office workers in France disappear from their desks for two full hours during lunch... This extended break allows time for a proper sit-down meal with multiple courses, social conversation, and genuine relaxation in the middle of the workday."
  - Location p5===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Eating is restricted to designated meal times; snacking between meals is avoided to preserve appetite and maintain structured eating habits.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Designated meal times rule everything in France, with people avoiding snacks between breakfast, lunch, and dinner... constant eating dulls your appetite for proper meals and prevents you from fully enjoying food when you sit down to eat."
  - Location p6===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Both hands must remain visible on the table during a meal as a sign of politeness and engagement; hiding a hand is considered impolite.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Hiding one hand in your lap during a meal breaks a fundamental rule of French dining etiquette, as both hands must remain visible above the table throughout the entire meal."
  - Location p7===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Restaurant bills are not divided evenly among diners; instead, one person pays entirely, usually the host, reflecting values of generosity and social bonding.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Restaurant bills in France belong to one person entirely, never split evenly among the group... The person who initiated the dinner invitation typically pays, or the group might take turns paying for different meals over time."
  - Location p8===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: The fork remains in the left hand throughout the meal while cutting and eating, consistent with the European style of dining without switching utensils.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Switching your fork from left hand to right hand marks you immediately as a foreigner in France, where the fork remains in the left hand throughout the entire meal."
  - Location p9===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Meals follow a strict sequence aperitif, starter, main course, cheese, dessert, and coffee, with no deviation expected.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Every meal follows the same precise order aperitif, starter, main course, cheese, dessert, and coffee. This structure creates a meal that can last several hours..."
  - Location p10===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Water and wine are not drunk simultaneously during a meal, as mixing them is believed to interfere with wine tasting and shows disrespect for pairings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Reaching for your water glass while actively drinking wine will earn you puzzled looks in France, where these two beverages never share the same moment during a meal."
  - Location p11===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Taking leftovers home from a restaurant is socially awkward and uncommon, as portions are expected to be appropriate and food should be consumed fresh.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Asking for a doggy bag in France creates immediate awkwardness, as diners never request take-home containers for unfinished food."
  - Location p12===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Coffee is served after dessert, never during the meal, and only black after 11 AM; milk-based coffee after dinner is considered harmful to digestion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Ordering coffee with milk after 11 AM breaks a sacred French rule, and coffee always appears after dessert, never during the meal or alongside it. Coffee with milk during or after dinner is considered a digestive disaster..."
  - Location p13===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Pastries like croissants are eaten with a fork and knife at the table to avoid mess and show respect for dining etiquette, though handheld consumption is acceptable when eating on the go.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Picking up a croissant with your hands at a French breakfast table would horrify other diners, as proper etiquette demands using a fork and knife for most pastries."
  - Location p14===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Every formal meal begins with an aperitif—a drink with light snacks—to stimulate appetite and encourage conversation before the meal starts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "The aperitif course starts every proper French meal, featuring light alcoholic drinks and small snacks designed to stimulate appetite and encourage conversation."
  - Location p15===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Meals are taken slowly and without rush, emphasizing enjoyment of food and social interaction, with fast eating seen as disrespectful.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Speed-eating your way through a French meal shows disrespect to both the chef and your dining companions, as taking time with food remains a cornerstone of the culture."
  - Location p16===from https://travelculturelife.com/15-french-dining-habits-that-baffle-foreigners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Aging is viewed negatively in Western cultures, often seen as an undesirable process that people try to resist by preserving youth.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Much of Western culture, however, views aging as an unfortunate aspect of life, taking extreme measures to retain youth for as long as possible."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://online.aging.ufl.edu/2024/09/23/cultural-perspectives-on-aging-how-the-experience-of-aging-differs-around-the-world/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Due to cultural emphasis on individualism, older adults in Western societies often live separately and rely on institutional care such as nursing homes rather than family-based support.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "For many, it means that older adults rely on retirement communities and nursing homes for long-term care."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://online.aging.ufl.edu/2024/09/23/cultural-perspectives-on-aging-how-the-experience-of-aging-differs-around-the-world/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Western societies prioritize individual independence, which can result in social isolation for the elderly as younger generations focus on personal goals.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "This emphasis on independence can lead to feelings of isolation among the elderly, as younger family members focus on raising their own families and achieving personal and professional goals."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://online.aging.ufl.edu/2024/09/23/cultural-perspectives-on-aging-how-the-experience-of-aging-differs-around-the-world/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: In many Asian cultures, elders are integrated into family life through multigenerational households, which provide emotional support and shared caregiving responsibilities.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "In 2021, approximately 24% of Asian Americans lived in multigenerational households in the U.S., compared to only 13% of Caucasian households. These homes benefit from increased emotional support, shared expenses and a more even distribution of caregiving responsibilities."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://online.aging.ufl.edu/2024/09/23/cultural-perspectives-on-aging-how-the-experience-of-aging-differs-around-the-world/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Older family members are respected through inclusion in important decisions, roles in religious ceremonies, and everyday courtesy that acknowledges their status.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Generally, it involves including older family members in important family decisions, giving them roles in religious ceremonies to highlight their seniority in the community and showing courtesy in everyday interactions, such as taking the time to include them in conversations and ensuring their comfort."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://online.aging.ufl.edu/2024/09/23/cultural-perspectives-on-aging-how-the-experience-of-aging-differs-around-the-world/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Many Hispanic adults view aging positively, believing life becomes more meaningful at age 50 and considering 50 to still be young.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Additionally, according to research from the AARP, many Hispanic adults are optimistic about aging, with 70% of participants stating that they feel life is more meaningful at 50. Furthermore, 57% believe that 50 is still young, proving that age is indeed just a number."  
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://online.aging.ufl.edu/2024/09/23/cultural-perspectives-on-aging-how-the-experience-of-aging-differs-around-the-world/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: In France, increased life expectancy is recognized as a major factor in population aging, with efforts being made to improve healthy aging and extend independent living through public health initiatives.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "In France, as in other countries, an increase in life expectancy is the other major factor in population aging."  
  - Location paragraph 2 (Population Trends section)===from https://academic.oup.com/gerontologist/article/53/2/191/563876

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: The death of 15,000 older people during the 2003 heat wave was attributed to environmental factors like lack of air conditioning and pollution, as well as social isolation, leading to policy changes aimed at protecting the elderly during extreme weather.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "In 2003, the heat wave created a major political shockwave in France, as it resulted in the death of 15,000 older persons. Limited access to air conditioning, as well as urban pollution, social isolation, and a lack of experience in handling such heat waves, led to dehydration and excessive sun exposure, which largely accounted for the high number of casualties."  
  - Location paragraph 1 (Health, Long-Term Care, and Well-Being section)===from https://academic.oup.com/gerontologist/article/53/2/191/563876

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: France has implemented national public health plans addressing illness and end-of-life care, including initiatives for Alzheimer’s disease, pain management, palliative care, and suicide prevention, reflecting a structured approach to managing illness and improving quality of life in old age.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "A 5-year Alzheimer Plan (2008–2012) was launched to support research, improve care, and both inform and mobilize citizens regarding this issue... Additionally, the French state has launched other public health initiatives that can directly affect older people, although without necessarily targeting them directly. These initiatives include a plan against pain (Plan Douleur, 2006–2010), a plan for palliative care (2008–2012) and a plan for suicide prevention (2011–2014)."  
  - Location paragraph 2 (Health, Long-Term Care, and Well-Being section)===from https://academic.oup.com/gerontologist/article/53/2/191/563876

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Old age is culturally defined primarily in terms of biological deterioration, including the weakening of physiological functions and mental faculties, as well as tissue and organ atrophy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Vieillesse dernière période de la vie qui succède à la maturité, caractérisée par un affaiblissement global des fonctions physiologiques et des facultés mentales et par des modifications atrophiques des tissus et organes."  
  - Location p1===from https://muse.jhu.edu/article/909327/summary

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Old age is frequently misunderstood, feared, and surrounded by negative cultural assumptions that contribute to its marginalization in society.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Finally, 'old age', while still a relative term — not least given the greater longevity and youthfulness which are facets of ageing in many contemporary societies — refers to a state of being in late life that is often poorly understood, feared, occluded, and characterized by a raft of negative cultural expectations."  
  - Location p3===from https://muse.jhu.edu/article/909327/summary

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Ageism is deeply embedded in social structures, language habits, and everyday life, shaping how ageing and old age are perceived and represented, often leading to inequality and harm to well-being.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Because it is systemic, embedded in many features of everyday life, from overarching social and economic structures to the casual habits of language, ageism is hard to make visible and to eradicate."  
  - Location p2===from https://muse.jhu.edu/article/909327/summary

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Increasing longevity and an ageing population are often portrayed as societal burdens or threats, such as through the term “silver tsunami,” reflecting collective anxieties about ageing.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "a societal context where our attention is frequently drawn to the consequences of increasing longevity, where socio-political and economic problems are often presented as bound up with the 'threat' of a 'silver tsunami', where collective anxieties cast ageing in a negative light..."  
  - Location p3===from https://muse.jhu.edu/article/909327/summary

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: In African communities, traditional and modern medicine are viewed as complementary systems that can work together to improve health outcomes, especially when modern medicine alone is insufficient.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Toutefois, nous remarquons des cas de maladies où l’intervention de la médecine moderne semble insuffisante et nécessite l’apport de la médecine traditionnelle."  
  - Location p1===from https://rightforeducation.org/fr/2025/03/05/medecine-traditionnelle-et-moderne-vers-une-integration-harmonieuse/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Traditional African medicine treats the individual as a whole, integrating physical, spiritual, and social dimensions, and emphasizes balance between humans and their environment.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "La médecine traditionnelle africaine considère l’être humain comme un tout indivisible, en équilibre avec l’environnement. Toute perturbation de cet équilibre peut entraîner des maladies. Sur ce, la dimension spirituelle est essentielle."  
  - Location p3===from https://rightforeducation.org/fr/2025/03/05/medecine-traditionnelle-et-moderne-vers-une-integration-harmonieuse/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Traditional healers use natural elements such as plants, water, and earth, along with spiritual rituals, to treat diseases, reflecting a cultural integration of nature and spirituality in healing practices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Les guérisseurs, pour faire le traitement de plusieurs maladies, utilisent des éléments naturels comme les plantes, l’eau, la terre et des rituels spirituels."  
  - Location p3===from https://rightforeducation.org/fr/2025/03/05/medecine-traditionnelle-et-moderne-vers-une-integration-harmonieuse/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Diagnosis in traditional medicine includes not only observation of physical symptoms but also interpretation of dreams and consultation with spirits, indicating culturally specific diagnostic practices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Les méthodes de diagnostic incluent l’observation des symptômes physiques, l’interprétation des rêves et la consultation des esprits."  
  - Location p3===from https://rightforeducation.org/fr/2025/03/05/medecine-traditionnelle-et-moderne-vers-une-integration-harmonieuse/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Traditional medicine is seen as culturally adapted and accessible, particularly in regions where modern medicine may be costly or unavailable.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "La médecine traditionnelle, avec ses pratiques ancestrales et sa compréhension holistique de l’être humain, apporte des solutions accessibles et culturellement adaptées."  
  - Location p5===from https://rightforeducation.org/fr/2025/03/05/medecine-traditionnelle-et-moderne-vers-une-integration-harmonieuse/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Modern medicine is culturally recognized for its evidence-based approach and standardized treatments, which are valued for their precision and technological advancement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Si la médecine traditionnelle se base sur des faits holistiques pour guérir, la médecine moderne utilise des fondements sur des preuves scientifiques pour le faire."  
  - Location p1===from https://rightforeducation.org/fr/2025/03/05/medecine-traditionnelle-et-moderne-vers-une-integration-harmonieuse/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Traditional medicine complements biomedical care by offering holistic, person-centered, and culturally adapted approaches that emphasize prevention and balance between body, mind, and environment, and is increasingly used alongside biomedical interventions to manage chronic diseases, reduce side effects, and improve quality of life.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "La médecine traditionnelle complète la biomédecine en proposant des soins holistiques, centrés sur la personne et adaptés aux différentes cultures. Elle met l’accent sur la prévention et l’équilibre – entre le corps, l’esprit et l’environnement – tout en permettant d’appréhender le mode de vie et des facteurs psychosociaux souvent négligés dans le cadre d’une prise en charge conventionnelle. Des thérapies comme l’acupuncture, la phytothérapie et le yoga sont de plus en plus utilisées en complément d’interventions biomédicales pour soulager la douleur, réduire les effets secondaires et améliorer la qualité de vie des personnes présentant des maladies chroniques."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.who.int/fr/news-room/questions-and-answers/item/traditional-medicine
