- Quoted text "Après une soirée ou une invitation à dîner, c'est une bonne chose de remercier chaleureusement l'hôte pour son accueil. Un message de remerciement le lendemain, que ce soit par téléphone, par message ou même par écrit, montre que vous avez apprécié le moment passé ensemble."
  - Location p37===from https://www.novexpat.com/fr/culture-francaise/etiquette-a-la-francaise-et-savoir-vivre-a-table

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French culture, first names are often selected based on family traditions, reflecting cultural identity and ancestral values.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Les prénoms sont souvent choisis en fonction de traditions familiales et peuvent refléter l’identité culturelle d’une personne."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://afcformation.fr/comprendre-limportance-du-nom-et-du-prenom-dans-la-culture-francaise/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Names with historical significance, such as "Louis" or "Marie," are used to connect individuals to France’s cultural and historical heritage, reinforcing a sense of identity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Par exemple, des prénoms comme « Louis » ou « Marie » sont souvent associés à une longue tradition historique et peuvent évoquer des figures emblématiques de la culture française."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://afcformation.fr/comprendre-limportance-du-nom-et-du-prenom-dans-la-culture-francaise/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: There is a growing use of foreign-origin first names in France, reflecting the country's cultural openness and the impact of migration on naming practices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "De nombreux prénoms italiens, espagnols ou arabes font leur apparition dans la liste des prénoms populaires, témoignant ainsi de la mosaïque culturelle française."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://afcformation.fr/comprendre-limportance-du-nom-et-du-prenom-dans-la-culture-francaise/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Some first names in France are increasingly used for both boys and girls, reflecting evolving societal views on gender.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Les prénoms traditionnellement masculins et féminins sont de plus en plus souvent mélangés, brouillant ainsi les frontières entre les genres. Les tendances des prénoms tels que « Camille » ou « Sacha » illustrent cela, car ils peuvent être portés aussi bien par des garçons que par des filles."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://afcformation.fr/comprendre-limportance-du-nom-et-du-prenom-dans-la-culture-francaise/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Recent trends show a shift away from traditional names toward modern names influenced by popular culture, music, and contemporary values.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Dans les années récentes, il est possible d’observer un rejet des prénoms qui évoquent des valeurs traditionnelles ou désuètes, au profit de noms plus modernes et souvent influencés par la culture pop. [...] comme par exemple « Luna » ou « Noah », qui sont des noms à forte résonance musicale."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://afcformation.fr/comprendre-limportance-du-nom-et-du-prenom-dans-la-culture-francaise/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French language supports the use of feminine forms for professional titles, ranks, and functions, and such feminization is considered a matter of practice rather than grammatical or lexical transformation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La féminisation de la langue française est plus une question de pratique que de transformation. Notre langue dispose des mots féminins nécessaires et des règles pour forger aisément ceux qui manqueraient."  
  - Location paragraph 3  

- Rule Description Feminine job titles and function names exist and are often historically attested; their underuse stems from lack of habit rather than linguistic deficiency.  
- ===from https://www.culture.gouv.fr/thematiques/langue-francaise-et-langues-de-france/agir-pour-les-langues/moderniser-et-enrichir-la-langue-francaise/feminiser-la-langue-francaise

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French surnames are often derived from the first name of an ancestor, typically the father, with suffixes added to indicate filiation (e.g., "Martin" becoming "Martinez" or "Martins" meaning "son of Martin").
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ces noms sont souvent formés en ajoutant un suffixe au prénom du père, ce qui permet d’identifier la filiation. Par exemple, le nom « Martin » peut donner naissance à « Martinez » ou « Martins », signifiant « fils de Martin »."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://apprendre-la-genealogie.fr/lorigine-des-noms-de-famille-francais-un-voyage-dans-le-temps/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Many French surnames originate from geographical locations, indicating where an ancestor lived, such as near a bridge ("Dupont") or referencing natural features like rivers or forests.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "De nombreux noms de famille proviennent de toponymes, c’est-à-dire de noms de lieux spécifiques. Par exemple, le nom « Dupont » signifie littéralement « du pont », indiquant que l’ancêtre porteur de ce nom vivait près d’un pont."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://apprendre-la-genealogie.fr/lorigine-des-noms-de-famille-francais-un-voyage-dans-le-temps/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French surnames frequently derive from ancestral occupations, reflecting the profession of a family member, such as "Boulanger" for baker or "Charpentier" for carpenter.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Les noms de famille en France peuvent également être dérivés de métiers ou de professions exercés par vos ancêtres. [...] Par exemple, le nom « Boulanger » indique qu’un membre de la famille était boulanger, tandis que « Charpentier » fait référence à un artisan du bois."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://apprendre-la-genealogie.fr/lorigine-des-noms-de-famille-francais-un-voyage-dans-le-temps/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French culture, surnames are considered a valuable inheritance passed down through generations, often reinforcing familial bonds and identity by carrying the name of a parent, usually the father.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Les noms de famille sont souvent considérés comme un héritage précieux transmis par les ancêtres. [...] Dans beaucoup de cultures françaises, il est courant que les enfants portent le nom du père ou parfois celui de la mère, renforçant ainsi le lien entre les générations."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://apprendre-la-genealogie.fr/lorigine-des-noms-de-famille-francais-un-voyage-dans-le-temps/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Many French surnames originated as given names (prénoms), particularly from the Middle Ages, and were later passed down through generations as family names.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "les noms de famille qui sont, en réalité, des prénoms"
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.rtl.fr/culture/culture-generale/langue-francaise-d-ou-viennent-nos-noms-de-famille-7900529164

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A common practice in medieval France was to use the father’s given name as a surname, such as "Paul Martin" meaning "son of Martin", which contributed to the formation of hereditary surnames.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "l’usage du prénom du père comme surnom. Ainsi, 'Paul Martin' devient 'le fils de Martin', 'Paul François' devient 'le fils de François', et ainsi de suite."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.rtl.fr/culture/culture-generale/langue-francaise-d-ou-viennent-nos-noms-de-famille-7900529164

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Some medieval given names have disappeared from common use but survive today only as surnames, with most people unaware that their family name was once a personal given name.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Certains prénoms issus du Moyen Âge ont aujourd’hui disparu, mais ont laissé des traces durables à travers les noms de famille."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.rtl.fr/culture/culture-generale/langue-francaise-d-ou-viennent-nos-noms-de-famille-7900529164

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Many of the most common surnames in France today, such as Martin, Bernard, and Thomas, were originally popular given names, especially those rooted in Christianity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Un nom comme 'Martin', par exemple, a des racines profondes dans le christianisme et a été transmis sous forme de prénom avant de devenir un patronyme. En France, c’est d’ailleurs l’un des trois noms les plus courants, suivi de Bernard et Thomas. Ces trois noms étaient, à l’origine, des prénoms populaires."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.rtl.fr/culture/culture-generale/langue-francaise-d-ou-viennent-nos-noms-de-famille-7900529164

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Several surnames derive from medieval given names that are now obsolete, such as Mauger, Évrard, Garnier, and Blanchard, which were once personal names linked to saints or Germanic origins.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Mauger, par exemple, était un prénom courant dans le nord de la France... De même, Évrard était un prénom d’origine germanique... Garnier, dérivé du prénom allemand Werner, ou encore Blanchard, qui provient d’un ancien saint chrétien."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.rtl.fr/culture/culture-generale/langue-francaise-d-ou-viennent-nos-noms-de-famille-7900529164

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In medieval France, surnames emerged due to increasing population and the repetition of first names, leading to the use of nicknames to distinguish individuals, which eventually became hereditary family names.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "L’origine des noms de famille remonte au Moyen Âge, où l’on constate une nécessité croissante de différencier les individus. À cette époque, les populations augmentent et les noms de baptême se répètent souvent. Pour éviter les confusions, on attribue progressivement des surnoms aux individus, qui deviendront les premiers noms de famille."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://originenom.com/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Many French surnames are derived from the occupations of ancestors, such as baking, milling, or blacksmithing.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Parmi les noms de famille les plus courants, on trouve ceux qui sont liés aux métiers exercés par les ancêtres. Par exemple, les noms comme Boulanger, Meunier ou Forgeron reflètent les professions de leurs ancêtres."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://originenom.com/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Many French surnames originate from the geographical locations where ancestors lived, such as villages, regions, or physical landscape features like bridges or forests.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Beaucoup de noms de famille trouvent leur origine dans l’emplacement où vivaient les ancêtres. Ces patronymes peuvent dériver de noms de villages, de régions ou de traits géographiques. Par exemple, le nom Dupont pourrait indiquer une personne vivant à proximité d’un pont, tandis que Lefèvre pourrait se traduire par ”celui qui habite près d’une forêt”."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://originenom.com/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Some French surnames originated as nicknames based on ancestors' physical characteristics or personality traits, such as size or hair color.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Certains noms de famille trouvent leur origine dans des surnoms associés à l’apparence physique ou aux traits de caractère des ancêtres. Par exemple, des noms comme Petit, Legrand, ou Lebrun illustrent bien ce phénomène."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://originenom.com/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Since a 2002 law effective in 2005, French parents may choose to pass on the mother’s surname, the father’s surname, or a combination of both to their children, promoting equality and flexibility.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "En France, la loi du 4 mars 2002, publiée au Journal officiel du 5 mars 2002 et entrée en vigueur le 1er janvier 2005, a réformé la transmission des noms de famille. Cette loi permet désormais de transmettre le nom de la mère, du père, ou une combinaison des deux, offrant ainsi une plus grande flexibilité et égalité dans le choix des noms de famille."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://originenom.com/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When attending a casual social gathering, such as a dinner party at a friend’s home, it is considered polite to arrive 10 to 15 minutes late, as this allows the host time for final preparations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "For casual gatherings – like a dinner party at a friend’s home – arriving 10 to 15 minutes late is often considered polite, as it gives your host some final prep time."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Arriving punctually is essential when visiting someone in France, but arriving early is considered inappropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Arriving punctually, but never early, is also vital in most aspects of etiquette in France."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/living/integration/french-etiquette-101246/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Arriving exactly on time or early is considered impolite; it is preferable to arrive 10–15 minutes late to respect the host’s preparation time.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Aim to arrive 10-15 minutes late. This slight delay is polite tardiness."
  - Location paragraph 2 (under "Arriving Timing Is Everything")===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Arriving too early is a social faux pas because hosts may still be preparing, such as getting dressed or setting the table.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Arriving early is a faux pas. Your hosts may still be getting dressed or setting the table."
  - Location paragraph 1 (under "Arriving Timing Is Everything")===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Upon receiving guests, the French host typically initiates the encounter with a handshake or cheek kiss (bise), accompanied by a sincere "Bonjour," and immediately offers a refreshment.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La poignée de main ou la bise, accompagnées d'un « Bonjour » sincère, marquent le début de toute rencontre. L'hôte français accorde une attention particulière à la présentation de sa maison, au dress code adapté et propose systématiquement un rafraîchissement à ses invités, perpétuant ainsi une tradition séculaire d'hospitalité."
  - Location p4===from https://www.diggfrance.com/laccueil-a-la-francaise-les-secrets-dune-hospitalite-culturelle-reussie/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The host carefully prepares the living space for guests by thoughtfully arranging furniture to encourage conversation, ensuring comfortable seating, and using soft lighting or candles to create an intimate atmosphere.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La réussite d'un accueil commence par l'organisation réfléchie des espaces de réception. Une attention particulière est accordée à la disposition des meubles, favorisant la circulation et les échanges entre les convives. Le salon devient un lieu convivial avec des assises confortables placées de manière à faciliter les conversations. L'éclairage joue aussi un rôle essentiel  des lumières tamisées ou des bougies créent une ambiance intime et apaisante."
  - Location p9===from https://www.diggfrance.com/laccueil-a-la-francaise-les-secrets-dune-hospitalite-culturelle-reussie/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Small personalized touches such as beautifully set tables with fine china, sparkling glasses, elegantly folded napkins, fresh flowers, and appropriate background music are essential elements that elevate the guest experience.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La réception à la française se distingue par ses délicates attentions. Une table joliment dressée avec une belle vaisselle, des verres étincelants et des serviettes élégamment pliées marque le respect porté aux invités. La préparation d'un plateau apéritif original, l'agencement des fleurs fraîches dans un vase ou la diffusion d'un fond musical approprié constituent des éléments significatifs."
  - Location p10===from https://www.diggfrance.com/laccueil-a-la-francaise-les-secrets-dune-hospitalite-culturelle-reussie/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Receiving guests often centers around a shared meal, which is treated as a structured social ritual involving careful table setting, attention to food presentation, and sufficient time for meaningful interaction.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Le repas à la française s'organise comme un véritable rituel social. Les convives se rassemblent autour d'une table dressée avec soin, où la présentation des mets fait l'objet d'une attention particulière. Le temps consacré au repas permet des échanges riches et authentiques entre les participants."
  - Location p6===from https://www.diggfrance.com/laccueil-a-la-francaise-les-secrets-dune-hospitalite-culturelle-reussie/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The host is expected to follow established codes of table service and actively ensure guest comfort by anticipating needs and maintaining a warm atmosphere throughout the meal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "L'art de la table à la française suit des codes précis qui structurent le repas. [...] Le maître de maison veille au confort de ses invités, anticipe leurs besoins et maintient une ambiance chaleureuse tout au long du repas."
  - Location p7===from https://www.diggfrance.com/laccueil-a-la-francaise-les-secrets-dune-hospitalite-culturelle-reussie/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Invitations should be crafted with care, using high-quality materials and personalized wording to convey respect and anticipation for the guest’s presence.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In French entertaining traditions, crafting the perfect invitation is an art form, where every detail conveys respect and anticipation for the guest’s presence."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Hosts should use high-quality table linens that reflect the care put into the evening, enhancing the overall dining experience.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Selecting the right table linens is a critical step in creating an elegant table setting that will impress your guests."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Cutlery must be placed according to traditional etiquette, with utensils arranged from the outside in by course, forks on the left, knives and spoons on the right, and dessert utensils above the plate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Start with the outermost utensils for the first courses, working inward with each subsequent course. Forks sit to the left of the plate, while knives (blade facing in) and spoons rest to the right. The dessert spoon or fork is placed above the plate, pointing left or right respectively."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Floral arrangements should enhance the table setting without obstructing guest interaction, matching the color scheme and maintaining appropriate scale.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ensure your arrangements don’t overpower the table. They should enhance, not obstruct, guest interaction."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests are welcomed with an apéritif, a drink served before the meal to set a convivial atmosphere and transition into the evening’s gathering.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Before diving into the heart of French entertaining, one must appreciate the tradition of the apéritif, a welcoming drink that sets the tone for the evening."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The cheese course is a pivotal part of the meal, offering a curated selection of cheeses presented from mildest to strongest, accompanied by bread, fruit, or nuts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Understanding these essentials equips you to present a cheese course that’s not merely a dish but a journey through France’s culinary heritage."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wine should be carefully selected to complement the meal, considering weight, flavor balance, acidity, and regional pairings, and served at the correct temperature.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Selecting the perfect wine is an art form, integral to elevating your French entertaining experience to its pinnacle."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The main course emphasizes high-quality, local, and seasonal ingredients, focusing on simplicity and purity of flavor rather than complexity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French cuisine emphasizes the importance of using ingredients that are local and in season. This ensures the freshest and most flavorful dishes."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Desserts are treated as a significant, carefully crafted part of the meal, featuring classic French pastries and sweets that provide a memorable conclusion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, desserts are not just an afterthought; they’re an art form."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Digestifs such as cognac, Armagnac, or Chartreuse are served after dessert to aid digestion and conclude the dining experience on a sophisticated note.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "As the laughter and conversation continue to flow, the evening gently eases into the tradition of digestifs. These are not merely drinks but a sophisticated way to aid digestion and conclude the dining experience."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Hosts should initiate conversations with sincerity, using genuine compliments, curious inquiries, and modest personal sharing to create comfort and engagement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Mastering the art of initiating conversations gracefully is a cornerstone of French entertaining traditions, and it’s essential to approach this skill with finesse and confidence."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Conversations should avoid controversial or overly personal topics, favoring culturally engaging subjects like art, cuisine, and travel to maintain harmony.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Avoid controversial or overly personal subjects, which can disrupt the harmony of the gathering. Instead, opt for universally engaging topics like art, cuisine, and travel, which often hold a special place in French culture."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Effective conversation includes attentive listening demonstrated through eye contact, nodding, smiling, and asking open-ended questions to make guests feel valued.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "engaging genuinely with guests isn’t just about talking; it’s about showing respect through attentive listening and thoughtful replies."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests are given thoughtful, non-extravagant parting gifts that reflect personal attention, such as homemade preserves or a miniature bottle of wine, elegantly presented.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "offering parting gifts to guests is a cherished tradition that adds a final touch of hospitality to any gathering... It’s not about extravagance but rather thoughtfulness."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Hosts should follow up after the event with personalized handwritten notes, shared memories such as photos, and suggestions for future gatherings to strengthen relationships.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "After ensuring your guests leave with a personal token of appreciation, don’t overlook the significance of reaching out to them post-event to truly complete the French entertaining experience."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://entertainingguests.com/10-classic-french-traditions-when-entertaining-guests/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When invited to a meal at someone’s home, guests are expected to arrive approximately 15 to 20 minutes after the scheduled time, rather than arriving exactly on time.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If someone is invited to a restaurant or a business function, it is acceptable to arrive at the specific time. However, when invited for a meal at someone’s house, one is expected not to arrive à l’heure (on time). It is best to arrive about 15 to 20 minutes after the set time."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Visiting someone without prior invitation or announcement is considered impolite in French culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French people tend not to visit unannounced or uninvited. To do so is considered rude."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests invited to a dinner are often expected to bring something, such as a bottle of wine or dessert, and may even ask the host beforehand if they should bring an item.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When invited to a dinner, it is common for guests to ask their hosts if they are required to bring something on the day. Guests may also bring a bottle of wine or dessert."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: If invited to an apéro (a pre-dinner drink event with food), guests should bring gourmet items such as tapenade, olives, fresh bread, or cheese, rather than casual snacks like chips.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you are invited to an apéro, it is best to bring something gourmet (rather than a bag of chips/crisps). For example, tapenade, olives, fresh bread, or cheese would be appropriate."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A small, high-quality gift—typically a good bottle of wine—is customary when visiting someone’s home, and all wine bottles brought by guests are placed on the table for shared consumption.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When invited to someone’s home, try to bring a small, good-quality gift for the host. Usually one will bring a bottle of wine. Everyone will put the bottles of wine on the table and will freely drink what they choose."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The wine brought as a gift should be of the highest quality the guest can afford, as French people value wine and appreciate its quality.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you give wine, ensure it is of the highest quality you can offer. French people appreciate their wines."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is considered impolite not to personally greet every person present upon arrival and departure, regardless of the number of guests.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is seen as rude if you do not greet everyone when arriving and leaving, regardless of how many people are present."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests are generally expected to dress well when visiting someone’s home.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Guests are usually expected to dress well."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is uncommon and socially discouraged to arrive empty-handed when invited to a French home, especially for meals or social gatherings like apéritifs.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "it is uncommon to arrive at someone’s home empty-handed, especially if you’ve been invited for a meal."
  - Location p3===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests are expected to bring a small gift even for casual invitations such as an apéritif or relaxed lunch, as there is an unspoken assumption of contribution.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Even casual invitations such as a shared apéritif or a relaxed lunch, often come with the unspoken assumption that the guest will bring a small token of appreciation."
  - Location p4===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Common and appropriate gifts for hosts include wine, flowers, homemade treats, or regional gourmet specialties.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Wine remains the classic and most frequently cited option... A good bottle of red, white, or sparkling wine is always welcome..."
  - Location p6
  - Quoted text "Flowers are also a common choice... opt for neutral, cheerful bouquets."
  - Location p7
  - Quoted text "Some guests like to prepare something at home to bring with them a cake, a tart, or another dessert."
  - Location p8
  - Quoted text "A thoughtful option mentioned by several respondents is to bring a specialty from one’s own region. This could be artisanal jam, biscuits, olive oil, or other gourmet items..."
  - Location p9===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should avoid bringing exceptionally expensive bottles of wine, as they may make the host feel uncomfortable.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "some care should be taken not to bring an exceptionally expensive bottle, which could make the host feel uncomfortable."
  - Location p6===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: For apéritif events, guests are expected to bring something to contribute, such as snacks or drinks, to participate in the shared experience.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "guests are still expected to bring something to contribute, even if it’s just a bag of crisps or a bottle of wine... The idea is to show that you are not simply there to consume but to participate in the shared experience."
  - Location p10===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When staying at someone’s home for a weekend or holiday period, it is customary to bring a more generous gift such as gift baskets, chocolates, liqueur, books, or decorative items.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you are invited to spend the weekend at someone’s home, or to stay for a holiday period, it is customary to bring something more generous."
  - Location p11
  - Quoted text "Respondents to the survey mentioned Gift baskets with a mix of food and drink, Boxes of chocolates or sweets..., Bottles of liqueur or champagne, Books, flowers, or even small decorative items for the home."
  - Location p11===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is not common to include a card with a gift when giving it in person; verbal expressions of goodwill are considered sufficient.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Most respondents said they do not include a card when offering a gift in person. A simple 'joyeux anniversaire' or 'merci encore' spoken aloud is considered sufficient."
  - Location p12===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: While handwritten cards are increasingly rare, especially when sent by post, they are still valued and can have a strong emotional impact when received.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "handwritten cards are becoming increasingly rare, though they are still valued."
  - Location p13
  - Quoted text "When received, they are often kept and appreciated especially when written with care. In other words, while not expected, a thoughtful card can still have a powerful impact."
  - Location p15===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts given to hosts are offered freely, without the expectation that the host will return the gesture with a gift of their own.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Gifts are given freely and without the expectation of reciprocation."
  - Location p17===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is expected that guests bring a gift when invited to a French home for a meal or party, as being welcomed into a home is considered a rare honour.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When you are invited to a French home for a meal or a party, it’s expected that you’ll bring a gift."
  - Location p5===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The most appropriate gifts for a host in France are high-quality flowers, chocolates, or liqueur; giving cheap items is considered insulting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The most commonly gifted items to a host are flowers, chocolates, or liqueur in French culture. Whichever you choose, make sure that it is a high-quality item. Giving something cheap is considered an insult."
  - Location p6===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should present their gift to the host before the party or event begins.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You’ll want to give your gift to the host before the party or event begins."
  - Location p5===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Chrysanthemums should not be given as gifts because they are associated with funerals, and red roses and carnations should be avoided as they symbolize romantic interest and bad luck, respectively.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Chrysanthemums are given at funerals, while red roses are given to romantic interests. Carnations often symbolize bad luck."
  - Location p7===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Flowers should be given in odd numbers, following an old European tradition, rather than even numbers such as a dozen.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "An old European tradition says that flowers should be gifted in odd numbers. In other words, skip a dozen roses and go for a baker’s dozen to make a better impression."
  - Location p7===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wine is generally not recommended as a host gift because the host typically selects the wine; however, after-dinner drinks like dessert wine, liqueur, or port are safe alcohol choices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "While wine is commonly given as a gift to the host in the US, this isn’t always a good idea or proper etiquette in France. In France, the host will typically make the wine selection... If you want to give alcohol, a safe choice is a bottle of something meant to drink after the meal, an after-dinner digestif dessert wine or liqueur, port etc."
  - Location p8===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Bringing a bottle of good-quality red or white wine is considered a safe and appropriate gift when visiting a French friend’s home, but cheap supermarket wine should be avoided.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A bottle of good red or white wine is a safe bet. Don’t bring cheap supermarket wine."
  - Location p14===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is best not to bring wine if the host is known to be a wine enthusiast, as the guest's choice might be inferior and could reflect poorly.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Avoid bringing wine if your host is a known wine enthusiast—your choice might pale in comparison!"
  - Location p14===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A bouquet of flowers is a suitable gift, but chrysanthemums should be avoided due to their association with funerals; roses are acceptable, while lilies may be seen as somber.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A bouquet is lovely. Avoid chrysanthemums (associated with funerals). Roses are safe. Lilies can be considered somber."
  - Location p15===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: High-quality chocolates or pastries from a reputable pâtisserie are appropriate gifts, unless the host has already prepared dessert.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A box of high-quality chocolates. Pastries from a reputable pâtisserie (but not if your host has already planned dessert)."
  - Location p16===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A small gift from the guest’s home country, such as specialty food, tea, or an artisanal craft, is an acceptable gesture of appreciation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A specialty food item, tea, or artisanal craft."
  - Location p17===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should not bring food dishes unless specifically asked to contribute, as it may be inappropriate or duplicative.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t bring food dishes unless invited to contribute."
  - Location p18===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Perfume or personal items should not be brought as gifts unless the guest knows the host well.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t bring perfume or personal items unless you know the person well."
  - Location p18===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Even if the host says not to bring anything, it is still polite to bring a small gift as a gesture of respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Yes! It’s polite to bring a small gesture, even if they insist otherwise."
  - Location p37===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Bringing high-quality chocolates from a reputable chocolatier is a safe and appropriate hostess gift in France.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s hard to go wrong with this one. As long as you bring along a box of high-quality chocolates, preferably from a good chocolatier, you’ll be fine."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Giving flowers is generally acceptable, but certain types and arrangements should be avoided to prevent offense.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Again, this is usually a safe choice. But France has some do’s and don’ts when it comes to flowers (mostly don’ts) that you should be aware of."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Chrysanthemums should not be brought as they are associated with funerals.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t bring chrysanthemums they’re for funerals."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A bouquet of red carnations should be avoided because it signals dislike for the host.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t bring a bouquet of red carnations that means you don’t like the host."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: An all-white bouquet should not be given because it is reserved for weddings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t bring an all-white bouquet they’re just for weddings."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: An all-yellow bouquet should be avoided because it symbolizes unfaithfulness.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t bring an all-yellow bouquet that means unfaithfulness."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Red roses should not be brought unless the giver is romantically involved with the host.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t bring red roses (unless you’re in love with the host)."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is preferred to bring an odd number of flowers, excluding 13 which is considered bad luck.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Do bring an odd-number of flowers (except 13, which is bad luck.) For some reason, bringing an even numbers of flowers is bad."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: If bringing flowers, it is advisable to arrive early to allow the host time to arrange them without disruption during the main arrival of guests.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Do arrive on the early side if you’re going to a big dinner party. You don’t want to make the host hunt for a vase at the same time everyone else is arriving."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Liqueurs such as cognac or calvados, and real Champagne from the Champagne region, are welcome gifts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Liqueurs are great, like a bottle of cognac or calvados. The same is true of Champagne (real Champagne, from Champagne), which is always a welcome gift."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Bringing wine may be seen as an insult by some hosts, who might interpret it as a lack of trust in their wine selection.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "But some hosts see a gift of wine as an insult. They think you don’t trust their taste, so you’ve brought a bottle you think is better."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wine brought as a gift is usually not opened during the dinner but is instead stored by the host for later consumption.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "So if you bring a bottle of wine, the host will typically thank you and then put it in their cave to drink another time."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://frenchly.us/french-gift-giving-keith/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should sit with proper posture, keeping their legs crossed at the knee or knees together, as sitting with legs spread apart is considered rude unless in a relaxed context.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is rude to sit with one’s legs spread apart unless in a relaxed context. Rather, sit straight with your legs crossed at the knee or knees together."  
  - Location paragraph 3 (p3)  

(Note No other seating-related rules involving host-guest positioning, assigned seats, or placement at the table are mentioned in the text.)===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should not choose their own seats at a French dinner; instead, they must wait for the hostess to assign seating.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "At a French dinner, don’t just choose your own seat — wait for the hostess to show you where to sit."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.frenchlearner.com/culture/french-table-manners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The hostess traditionally places important or older guests closer to the hosts, indicating preferential seating based on status or age.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Traditionally, the hostess assigns seats, placing important or older guests closer to the hosts and younger guests farther away."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.frenchlearner.com/culture/french-table-manners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Men and women are typically seated alternately around the table when possible, as part of traditional French seating etiquette.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When possible, men and women are seated alternately, and the host and hostess typically sit at opposite ends of the table."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.frenchlearner.com/culture/french-table-manners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary for the host and hostess to sit at opposite ends of the dining table during a formal meal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When possible, men and women are seated alternately, and the host and hostess typically sit at opposite ends of the table."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.frenchlearner.com/culture/french-table-manners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: At events such as weddings or engagement dinners, the honored couple is usually seated at the head of the table.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "At weddings or engagement dinners, the honored couple may sit at the head."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.frenchlearner.com/culture/french-table-manners/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should not sit down immediately upon arrival, as the host may have a predetermined seating plan indicated by place cards or verbal direction.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you are at someone’s home for a dinner party, the host/hostess likely has a seating plan for where everyone should sit. So don’t just grab a seat. There may be place cards on the table, or the host will just indicate where to sit once everyone is gathered around the table."
  - Location p10===from https://snippetsofparis.com/french-dining-etiquette-the-dos-and-donts/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When a large group is invited to a restaurant, the person who issued the invitation may suggest seating positions, and guests should follow these suggestions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The same rule applies if you are a large group invited to a restaurant. The person issuing the invitation, may suggest where everyone should sit."
  - Location p11===from https://snippetsofparis.com/french-dining-etiquette-the-dos-and-donts/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests must wait for the host or hostess to begin eating before starting their meal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "if you’ve been invited to a restaurant or you’re at someone’s house for dinner, you should never start to eat before your host or hostess."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/guide-to-french-etiquette-everything-you-should-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is impolite to begin drinking before a toast; one must look others in the eye while raising their glass and say “santé.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "it’s considered impolite to begin drinking before a toast – and you should look the person in the eye when you’re raising your glass to them and say “santé” – good health – or else you might get 7 years of bad luck."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/guide-to-french-etiquette-everything-you-should-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: One should always say “bon appétit” before beginning a meal as a polite gesture toward fellow diners.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "First and foremost, always say ‘bon appétit’ before starting to eat. It’s a polite way to signal the start of a meal and shows you’re considerate of your fellow diners."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/guide-to-french-etiquette-everything-you-should-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should offer to bring something when invited to a dinner, such as wine, sparkling drinks, or dessert, especially for informal gatherings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Offer to bring something  wine, sparkling, dessert."  
  - Location paragraph 5  

- Rule Description Even if the host says not to bring anything to a more conservative dinner party, guests are still expected to bring a small gift such as chocolates or flowers.  
- ===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should not start eating until the host or hostess begins, especially when dining at someone’s home.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t start eating until everyone has their meal. [...] If the meal is at someone’s home, don’t start eating until the host/hostess does."  
  - Location paragraph 15  

- Rule Description Guests must not leave the table before the host finishes their meal; only small children may ask for permission to leave early.  
- ===from https://snippetsofparis.com/french-dining-etiquette-the-dos-and-donts/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary to clink glasses and make eye contact before drinking, as a sign of respect and conviviality; crossing glasses should be avoided.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Pour trinquer, il faut regarder l'autre dans les yeux et ne pas croiser les verres !"  
  - Location p1===from https://www.novexpat.com/fr/culture-francaise/etiquette-a-la-francaise-et-savoir-vivre-a-table

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should wait for the host to begin eating or drinking before they serve themselves, as a gesture of respect and to maintain conviviality.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Il est courant, en France, d'attendre que l'hôte commence à manger ou à boire avant de se servir à table, par respect pour lui et pour instaurer une certaine convivialité."  
  - Location p1===from https://www.novexpat.com/fr/culture-francaise/etiquette-a-la-francaise-et-savoir-vivre-a-table

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Arriving on time or no more than 15 minutes late is important when attending a party or dinner in France.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you are invited to a party or a dinner, it’s important to arrive on time or no more than 15 minutes late."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://frenchlanguagebasics.com/french-etiquette-rules-dos-and-donts-in-france

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is considered impolite to eat with your hands unless eating a sandwich or a piece of fruit; utensils should be used for all other foods, even in casual settings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Unless you are eating a sandwich or a piece of fruit, it’s important to use utensils when eating in France. It’s considered impolite to eat with your hands, even if you are at a casual restaurant."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://frenchlanguagebasics.com/french-etiquette-rules-dos-and-donts-in-france

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Tipping is not required because service charge is included in the meal price, though it is common to round up the bill to the nearest euro.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, the service charge is included in the price of the meal, so leaving a tip at the table is not necessary. However, it’s common to round up the total amount to the nearest euro."  
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://frenchlanguagebasics.com/french-etiquette-rules-dos-and-donts-in-france

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Meals are considered an important social event and should not be rushed; one should take time to enjoy food, wine, and conversation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Meals in France are considered an important social event and should not be rushed. It’s important to take time to enjoy the food, wine, and conversation."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://frenchlanguagebasics.com/french-etiquette-rules-dos-and-donts-in-france

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, it is customary to hold the knife in the right hand and the fork in the left while eating, reflecting a traditional dining posture associated with precision and elegance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, holding a knife in the right hand and a fork in the left is a bit like following a classical choreography."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.france-hotel-guide.com/en/blog/french-dining-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Alcohol is commonly integrated into family rituals and meals in France, often introduced during childhood through practices like chabrot, dipping sugar in alcohol ("petit canaud"), or sipping champagne at celebrations, despite legal restrictions on underage consumption.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Le chabrot sur les tables familiales, le « petit canard » (sucre trempé dans de l’alcool) en fin de repas, ou encore le verre de champagne pour « juste » tremper les lèvres lors d’une fête  ces traditions sont fréquentes dans de nombreuses familles françaises."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://kepsmag.fr/articles/culture/lalcool-en-france-entre-culture-addiction-et-tabou/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Consuming alcohol is culturally perceived as a rite of passage into adulthood, associated with social integration, freedom, and identity formation, particularly during youth gatherings, parties, and binge drinking events.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Toustes s’accordent à dire que, dans l’intimité comme dans le regard social, l’alcool fait partie d’un rite de passage vers l’âge adulte  jeux d’alcool, soirées, binge drinking."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://kepsmag.fr/articles/culture/lalcool-en-france-entre-culture-addiction-et-tabou/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: There is strong social pressure to drink alcohol in French society, where abstaining is often met with questioning and judgment, making sobriety a socially challenging choice.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Tous et toutes sont sobres aujourd’hui, depuis quelques mois ou plusieurs années. Iels évoquent la difficulté de ne plus boire dans une société où l’alcool est omniprésent, et où son absence est toujours questionnée  « T’es sûr·e que tu ne veux pas un petit verre de vin, plutôt ? »"  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://kepsmag.fr/articles/culture/lalcool-en-france-entre-culture-addiction-et-tabou/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French culture, alcohol consumption is tied to social performance, confidence, and masculinity; being able to drink heavily ("faire une descente") is valorized and seen as a sign of respect and strength.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Il faut être fier·e de sa descente, elle est valorisée. En effet, la consommation d’alcool est étroitement liée à l’idée de performance et à la notion de virilité, boire c’est aussi être respecté·e."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://kepsmag.fr/articles/culture/lalcool-en-france-entre-culture-addiction-et-tabou/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Drinking alcohol in the evening is culturally normalized as a way to relax and decompress, reinforced by popular media portrayals of characters regularly consuming wine or cocktails after work.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ce plaisir est légitimé par la culture populaire  Sex & The City, où boire un « cosmo » est tendance ; Bree Van de Kamp dans Desperate Housewives, toujours accompagnée d’un verre de vin ; Sue Ellen dans Dallas, noyant son chagrin dans l’alcool. Ces images populaires banalisent l’alcool, normalisent le verre du soir, censé aider à la décompression."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://kepsmag.fr/articles/culture/lalcool-en-france-entre-culture-addiction-et-tabou/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Alcohol is widely used as a social tool to facilitate dating, boost self-confidence, reduce anxiety, and overcome emotional barriers in social interactions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Boire, c’est pour s’aider à draguer, se sentir beau/belle, affronter ses peurs. Baptiste et Charlotte parlent de l’alcool comme d’une béquille pour s’émanciper ou prendre confiance."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://kepsmag.fr/articles/culture/lalcool-en-france-entre-culture-addiction-et-tabou/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Women who do not drink are often stigmatized as boring or uptight ("la reloue"), while women who drink face negative judgments about their behavior and morality, reflecting a double standard based on gender.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Une femme qui boit trop n’est plus « mignonne », mais une femme qui ne boit pas est « coincée ». [...] Lou témoigne, pour les autres, son refus de boire, c’est pas fun, c’est « la reloue »."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://kepsmag.fr/articles/culture/lalcool-en-france-entre-culture-addiction-et-tabou/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The consumption of wine is culturally framed by some political groups, particularly the far right, as a symbol of French national identity, tradition, and resistance to globalization.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Lors des dernières décennies, l’extrême droite française a souvent utilisé l’alcool, en particulier le vin, comme un symbole de l’identité culturelle française."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://infosplus.fr/la-culture-francaise-entre-alcool-et-alcoolisme-un-paradoxe-a-decrypter/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wine, as a product of French land, is viewed by certain groups as representing authenticity, pride, and national sovereignty, serving as a cultural defense against cultural homogenization.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Pour ces groupes, la consommation de vin est perçue à la fois comme une pratique traditionnelle, et comme un élément essentiel de la souveraineté nationale. Ils soutiennent que le vin, produit emblématique de la terre française, incarne des valeurs telles que l’authenticité, la fierté et le patrimoine."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://infosplus.fr/la-culture-francaise-entre-alcool-et-alcoolisme-un-paradoxe-a-decrypter/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Alcohol, especially wine, is integrated into French social and familial rituals, associated with conviviality and shared cultural moments, reinforcing collective identity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ils mettent en avant l’importance des traditions viticoles qui font partie du tissu social français, reliant la consommation de vin à des moments de partage et de convivialité."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://infosplus.fr/la-culture-francaise-entre-alcool-et-alcoolisme-un-paradoxe-a-decrypter/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The far right uses alcohol, particularly wine, as a political instrument to promote a traditionalist, rural-based vision of France and mobilize support around cultural belonging.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ainsi, l’alcool se transforme en un outil de mobilisation politique, revendiquant un ancrage rural et traditionnel dans un paysage politique en mutation."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://infosplus.fr/la-culture-francaise-entre-alcool-et-alcoolisme-un-paradoxe-a-decrypter/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French society, alcohol is celebrated as part of gastronomy, festive occasions, and national celebrations, contributing to a positive cultural image.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Dans la société française, l’alcool est souvent célébré pour son rôle dans la gastronomie, la convivialité et les célébrations. Depuis des siècles, il est intégré dans des rituels sociaux, des dîners familiaux aux fêtes nationales, contribuant ainsi à une image positive au sein de la culture locale."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://infosplus.fr/la-culture-francaise-entre-alcool-et-alcoolisme-un-paradoxe-a-decrypter/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Sharing a drink, especially wine, is a ritualized practice that enhances social bonding and is commonly integrated into festive and family gatherings, such as apéritifs or formal dinners.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Boire ensemble confère une dimension rituelle aux réunions. Le vin accompagne les rituels festifs et familiaux. Cette pratique se retrouve à chaque réunion conviviale, que ce soit lors d’un apéritif ou d’un dîner formel."
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://www.recette-de-cuisine.fr/boisson-rituels-sociaux-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Refusing a drink can lead to social isolation, and there is implicit pressure to participate in toasting rituals to fit in socially, particularly during events like parties.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Il n’existe pas de reproche à un toast partagé. Le refus d’un verre peut isoler. Une jeune consommatrice relate  « J’ai ressenti une véritable pression lors d’une soirée, obligée de trinquer pour m’intégrer. »"
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://www.recette-de-cuisine.fr/boisson-rituels-sociaux-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Alcohol, particularly wine, is deeply embedded in daily routines and special occasions, including family meals, business meetings, regional celebrations, and intergenerational gatherings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Le vin et autres alcools s’intègrent dans le quotidien. Les repas en famille, rendez-vous entre amis ou apéritifs festifs témoignent de ce lien indéfectible."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://www.recette-de-cuisine.fr/boisson-rituels-sociaux-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The act of sharing a drink serves as a notable marker of social interaction in France, reinforcing interpersonal connections through established rituals involving alcohol.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Le partage d’un verre reste un repère notable des échanges sociaux. Les rituels, incorporant l’alcool, renforcent le lien entre les individus."
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://www.recette-de-cuisine.fr/boisson-rituels-sociaux-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The pig holds contrasting symbolic meanings across cultures, being associated with both positive attributes like fertility and nourishment, and negative connotations such as impurity, especially in Hebrew and Muslim civilizations where contact with pigs is prohibited.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Véritable nourriture spirituelle, le cochon trouve sa place dans la majorité des cultures où les diverses symboliques qui lui sont attribuées restent très manichéennes."
  - Location paragraph 1

- Rule Description In Greek mythology, the pig is linked to deities of fertility and agriculture, and it is said that Zeus was nursed by a sow, highlighting its sacred and nurturing role.
- ===from https://www.la-viande.fr/culture-societe/viande-histoire-enjeux-sociaux/cochon-travers-histoire

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In historical French practice, no part of the pig was wasted—every portion was used for food or other purposes, reflecting the principle that “everything is good in the pig.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "rien ne se perd dans le cochon, tout est découpé, haché, apprêté, salé dans la journée même, des meilleurs morceaux aux moins bons."
  - Location paragraph 6

- Rule Description Non-edible parts of the pig were repurposed for practical uses, such as using the dried bladder to store tobacco and rendering pork fat into remedies or soap.
- ===from https://www.la-viande.fr/culture-societe/viande-histoire-enjeux-sociaux/cochon-travers-histoire

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pork is the most consumed meat in France, reflecting its central role in the national diet.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "la viande porcine reste la viande la plus consommée en France, avec une moyenne de 32 kg par habitant."
  - Location p1===from https://aubret.com/tendances/consommation-de-porc-en-france-en-2024-un-etat-des-lieux-complet-et-les-perspectives-davenir/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The majority of pork consumption in France involves processed products such as charcuterie, rather than fresh cuts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Il est à noter que la majorité (75 %) de cette consommation concerne des produits transformés comme la charcuterie, alors que les achats de viande fraîche sont en retrait."
  - Location p1===from https://aubret.com/tendances/consommation-de-porc-en-france-en-2024-un-etat-des-lieux-complet-et-les-perspectives-davenir/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Charcuterie production and consumption represent a key traditional strength of the French pork industry.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "la production de charcuterie de qualité, qui constitue une force essentielle du secteur."
  - Location p4===from https://aubret.com/tendances/consommation-de-porc-en-france-en-2024-un-etat-des-lieux-complet-et-les-perspectives-davenir/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pork remains a central component of French eating habits, indicating its deep integration into the country's food culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La viande de porc demeure centrale dans l’alimentation française..."
  - Location p5===from https://aubret.com/tendances/consommation-de-porc-en-france-en-2024-un-etat-des-lieux-complet-et-les-perspectives-davenir/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When invited to a French home for a meal or party, it is expected that guests bring a gift and present it to the host before the event begins.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When you are invited to a French home for a meal or a party, it’s expected that you’ll bring a gift. You’ll want to give your gift to the host before the party or event begins."
  - Location p4===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The most appropriate gifts for a host in France are high-quality flowers, chocolates, or liqueur; giving low-quality items is considered insulting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The most commonly gifted items to a host are flowers, chocolates, or liqueur in French culture. Whichever you choose, make sure that it is a high-quality item. Giving something cheap is considered an insult."
  - Location p5===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Certain types of flowers carry specific meanings and should be avoided chrysanthemums are associated with funerals, red roses with romantic interests, and carnations with bad luck.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Chrysanthemums are given at funerals, while red roses are given to romantic interests. Carnations often symbolize bad luck."
  - Location p6===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Flowers should be given in odd numbers according to an old European tradition, rather than even numbers such as a dozen.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "An old European tradition says that flowers should be gifted in odd numbers. In other words, skip a dozen roses and go for a baker’s dozen to make a better impression."
  - Location p6===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wine is not typically recommended as a host gift in France because the host usually selects the wine; instead, after-dinner drinks like dessert wine, liqueur, or port are safer choices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "While wine is commonly given as a gift to the host in the US, this isn’t always a good idea or proper etiquette in France. [...] If you want to give alcohol, a safe choice is a bottle of something meant to drink after the meal, an after-dinner digestif dessert wine or liqueur, port etc."
  - Location p7===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Corporate gift-giving is not expected in France, and if done, should avoid company-branded items, which are considered vulgar.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Corporate gift-giving in France, this is not something that’s expected. [...] In France, however, this is considered vulgar. Skip the company logo gifts and instead opt for something personal."
  - Location p9, p10===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Including a business card with a gift is against French business etiquette and should be avoided.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Another American tradition is to throw in your business card with the gift you’re giving. It’s a way of showing who the gift is from and reminding them of your interaction. In France, this goes against proper business etiquette, so make sure to leave your business card out."
  - Location p11===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts should always be given in person; sending a gift to someone’s home may be perceived as inappropriate or creepy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "While sending a gift to someone’s home in the United States may be considered okay, this is not okay in France. In fact, it could come across as creepy. Always make sure to give gifts in person to avoid an awkward situation."
  - Location p12===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: After attending a dinner or event at a French person's home, it is customary to send a handwritten thank-you note the following day, optionally accompanied by flowers or fruit.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Make sure that you send a note after being invited to a dinner party or other event at the home of a Frenchman. These should be sent the next day and should always be handwritten. You can send the note by messenger or accompany it with fruit or flowers to add a special touch."
  - Location p13===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: New Year’s cards are the most common type of holiday greeting in France, appropriate for both friends and business associates, and should be sent during January only.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The most common type of holiday card in France, whether you’re sending it to a friend or to a business associate, is a New Year’s card. You’re free to send New Year’s greetings throughout the entire month of January. However, as soon as February begins, sending New Year’s cards becomes inappropriate."
  - Location p14===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts in French culture should be elegantly wrapped, as the manner of presentation is considered crucial and reflects respect and thoughtfulness.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s also important to remember that the manner of presenting a gift is crucial. Gifts should be elegantly wrapped, and it’s common for the offering to be accompanied by a personal note."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/
