Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A gift should be accompanied by a personal note or card with a heartfelt message to enhance its emotional impact and show genuine sentiment.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A simple card with a heartfelt message can make your gift stand out and truly touch the recipient."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary to bring a gift when invited to someone’s home for a meal, particularly dinner, as a gesture of appreciation for hospitality.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, bringing a gift to someone’s home when you are invited for a meal is a common practice."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When attending a dinner party, the gift should be offered to the hostess upon arrival.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When attending a dinner party, it’s polite to offer the gift to the hostess upon arrival."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Chrysanthemums should be avoided as gifts because they are associated with mourning; red roses should also be avoided unless expressing romantic feelings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Avoid chrysanthemums, which are typically associated with mourning. It might also be wise to steer clear of red roses unless there’s a romantic sentiment you wish to express."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French value modest, tasteful, and thoughtful gifts over very expensive ones, which may be seen as an attempt to outshine others and are generally frowned upon.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Gifting etiquette in France dictates that some gifts can send the wrong message. For example, giving someone very expensive gifts can feel like an attempt to outshine, which is often frowned upon. Aiming for something modest and tasteful is usually the safer bet."
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Overly practical gifts, such as domestic appliances or utilitarian items, are not well-received in social contexts as they may imply domestic duty and blur personal boundaries.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Avoiding overly practical gifts for social occasions is also wise. The French tend to separate the personal and domestic spheres, so domestic appliances or overly utilitarian items might not be well-received as they could imply domestic duty."
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts should reflect the recipient’s individual tastes and interests, demonstrating care and consideration rather than assuming shared preferences.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Take care not to assume that one’s personal tastes will align with those of the recipient. Taking the time to learn about the person’s preferences demonstrates care and consideration, which are at the heart of the French approach to gifting."
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Giving gifts to school teachers is not obligatory, but if done, a box of chocolates or a thoughtful card is appreciated; however, some schools may have traditions where more valuable gifts like scarves or wine are given, influenced by peer practices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You’re under absolutely no obligation to give a present. If your kids insist, a box of chocolates or a thoughtful card will be appreciated. But talk to other parents at your kids’ school – we’ve heard of some teachers receiving things like scarves and bottles of wine for the holidays. If gift giving is a tradition at your particular school, you may feel compelled to fall in line."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is thoughtful but not required to give a small gift to extra-curricular instructors such as sports coaches or private tutors, especially if they have organized a performance, with acceptable gifts including flowers, a handwritten note, or a small present.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s thoughtful, though not necessary, to offer a little something to your kids’ soccer coach, ballet teacher or private tutors. If the teacher has produced a December recital, concert or performance, you may want to present the teacher with flowers, a handwritten note or card, or another small gift at that time."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts for building concierges or janitors typically range from 5% to 10% of monthly rent or mortgage, or commonly between €50 and €300, reflecting their role in building maintenance and personal services.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The going price is – gasp – 5% to 10% of your monthly rent or mortgage. If that seems too steep, ask others in your building but typically, apartment dwellers give anything from €50 to €300 at Christmas."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: For house cleaners and babysitters, a cash gift is customary, ranging from one month’s salary or €50–€100; additional personal gifts like flowers, chocolates, or a scarf may be included if there is a close relationship or knowledge of their preferences.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Some say offer a month’s salary to your femme de ménage (cleaning person); other says that €50 – €100 is sufficient. If you feel close to her or know her tastes, a gift of flowers, chocolates, or a scarf – in addition to cash – is also acceptable. The same works for babysitters (nounous) too."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary to tip public service workers such as garbage collectors and firefighters in cash, placed in an envelope, typically between €5 and €25, with potential for more if they provided personal assistance during the year; firefighters often give a calendar in return.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Be aware that the French usually tip public workers for their service. The tip must always be in cash, and placed in an envelope. If you’re going to be away for the holidays, give the gift before you leave. Typically, these workers get between €5 and €25 – possibly more if they have helped you personally during the year. Usually, the firefighters will give you a calendar in exchange."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A cash gift of €5 to €25 is customary for postal delivery personnel in exchange for the calendar they offer, with the implication that generosity may improve service.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Give €5 to €25 in exchange for the calendar they’ll inevitably offer. You’re free to buy it or not, but service may improve if you’re generous."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: For a formal meal, especially in Paris, it is considered good form to send the gift (such as flowers) the day before the event so it can be used as decoration during or after the meal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you are invited to a French home this holiday season for a formal meal, it is considered good form (especially in Paris) to send them over the day before to be used as decoration for the meal or in the days following the meal, along with a thank you card."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.clefrance.co.uk/18-blog/living-in-france/429-etiquette-for-gift-giving-in-france

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It may be seen as unnecessary or slightly presumptuous to bring wine to a dinner because the host likely already selected a specific bottle, though most hosts today would not take offense.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "I’ve often heard that it can be insulting to your French host to bring a bottle of wine with you when invited to a dinner. The idea behind this is that wine plays such an important role in a French dinner that your host has probably already selected the perfect bottle for your table. This is an “old society” rule and, frankly, most French hosts would take this rule with a grain of salt..."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.clefrance.co.uk/18-blog/living-in-france/429-etiquette-for-gift-giving-in-france

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: There is a traditional rule about including an odd number of flowers in a bouquet, but in practice, recipients tend to appreciate the gesture more than the number of flowers.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The same goes for the rule that, when offering a bouquet, you must include an odd number of flowers in it; I’ve never seen someone count the number of flowers they have just received. Rather, most of the time, they are impressed with the generous gesture and will thank you by kissing your cheeks."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.clefrance.co.uk/18-blog/living-in-france/429-etiquette-for-gift-giving-in-france

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts for children in France can include educational toys and wooden balance bikes (draisennes), with options specifically categorized by age groups such as under 3 years and 3 years and older.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Pour les enfants, vous trouverez des articles pour les moins de 3 ans et de 3 ans à 7 ans et plus. Vous avez le choix entre des vêtements pour enfant de la marque Les Petites Epopées. Vous préférez offrir des jouets ? On vous comprend ! C’est pourquoi vous pourrez opter pour des draisiennes en bois ou des jouets éducatifs proposés par Topla, Kojo, etc."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.marques-de-france.fr/idees-cadeaux-made-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Sophie the Giraffe is a well-known and traditional French toy for babies, often passed down through generations and considered a trusted product of French craftsmanship.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Plus connue des jouets français pour enfants, Sophie la Petite Girafe s’est invitée de génération en génération dans les landaus de nombreux bébés aux quatre coins du globe."
  - Location paragraph 21===from https://french-iceberg.com/fr/idees-cadeaux-francais/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Appointments must be arranged before any business meeting and are typically made via telephone or email.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Appointments are necessary prior to any meeting, and can be made either by telephone or email."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is preferable to schedule appointments at least two weeks in advance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is preferable to make appointments at least two weeks in advance and to avoid the months of July and August, as that is the most common vacation period."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Meetings should be scheduled approximately two weeks ahead of time.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Meetings should be scheduled about two weeks in advance."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business appointments in France should be scheduled at least two weeks in advance as a sign of proper business etiquette.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "appointments should be arranged a couple of weeks in advance and confirmed before their scheduled day as a gesture of good business etiquette."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is considered good business etiquette to confirm appointments before the scheduled meeting day.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "appointments should be arranged a couple of weeks in advance and confirmed before their scheduled day as a gesture of good business etiquette."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Appointments can be made either in writing or by telephone, and are often managed by a secretary depending on the rank of the person being met.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Appointments may be made in writing or by telephone and, depending upon the position of the person you are meeting, are often handled by a secretary."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is culturally appropriate to use a polite conditional form when asking about someone’s availability for a business meeting, as it softens the tone and shows respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Seriez-vous disponible pour … ? is a polite expression meaning 'Would you be available for …?'"
  - Location p9===from https://french-grammar.com/en/negotiation-adjustment/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In business contexts or when speaking with someone for the first time, the conditional form “Seriez-vous…?” is preferred over the more direct “Êtes-vous disponible…?”.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Although 'Êtes-vous disponible… ?' conveys the same meaning, it sounds more direct. In business or when speaking to someone for the first time, the conditional form 'Seriez-vous… ?' is more suitable."
  - Location p10===from https://french-grammar.com/en/negotiation-adjustment/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business cards should be presented and received with both hands as a sign of respect during business interactions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Exchanging business cards is common practice, and present and receive them with both hands as a sign of respect."
  - Location paragraph 13

(Note The rule is explicitly stated in the text, but no specific mention is made of exchanging cards before the meeting; only that exchange occurs and how it should be done. Therefore, timing relative to the meeting start is not supported by the text.)===from https://executiveplanet.com/french-business-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary to give your business card to the secretary upon arrival at your French counterpart’s office as a way to log your arrival.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Once you arrive in your French counterpart’s office it is good practice to give your business card to their secretary so that they can log your arrival."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business cards should ideally be printed in both English and French to demonstrate attention to detail, with specific inclusion of one's position and academic qualifications in French.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Your business cards should ideally be printed in both English and French. Attention to detail is generally much appreciated in France and having a dual language business card is a great opportunity for you to show your attention to detail too. Once you have exchanged business cards with your counterpart, you should examine their card carefully, before you put it away. If you are considering printing your business cards in French, make sure that you state a) your position within your organisation in French and b) your university degree, for example if it is at masters or doctoral level."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: After exchanging business cards, it is expected to examine the received card carefully before putting it away.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Once you have exchanged business cards with your counterpart, you should examine their card carefully, before you put it away."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business cards exchanged in French business meetings should be bilingual, with one side in English and the other in French, and should include the individual’s university degree and job title on the French side.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Your business card should be two-sided, one in English and the other in French. The French side should show your university degree and the position you hold."
  - Location paragraph 4 (section "4. Business cards")===from https://excellentetiquette.com/business-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, it is common for business cards to display the family name in capital letters, and visitors are advised to follow this practice when designing their own cards.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Most business cards in France have the family name in capital letters. It’s advisable to follow this practice when designing your cards."
  - Location paragraph 4 (section "4. Business cards")===from https://excellentetiquette.com/business-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When receiving a business card in a French business setting, it is considered polite to examine the card before putting it away.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When receiving a card, it’s polite to study it before putting it away."
  - Location paragraph 4 (section "4. Business cards")===from https://excellentetiquette.com/business-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business cards should not be exchanged with small gifts during the first meeting, and it is best to avoid giving business cards alongside presents.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Presents should be treated with discretion – small gifts may be exchanged, but not at the first meeting and definitely not with your business card."
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://www.todaytranslations.com/consultancy-services/business-culture-and-etiquette/doing-business-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Networking separately with individuals outside of formal meetings is necessary to obtain honest input, especially from junior attendees who may withhold opinions during meetings to avoid losing face or challenging superiors.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If it’s important to solicit input, then you need to network separately with individuals outside of the meeting place. This will enable you to gain any necessary feedback in a more relaxed way."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Building a strong network of personal business connections is essential in French business culture, with an emphasis on establishing long-term partnerships through regular face-to-face interactions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Creating a wide network of close personal business connections is considerably important for the French. They are interested in long-term partnerships that are maintained through regular face-to-face visits."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Trust in French business relationships is earned by demonstrating courtesy, formality, and appropriate professional behavior rather than informality or attempts at personal friendship.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Mutual trust and respect is seen as necessary in order to establish a strong relationship. Trust is earned through proper behaviour and demonstration of courtesy and formality."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French professionals keep a clear separation between their business and personal lives, so being overly friendly may be misinterpreted as an attempt to create a personal friendship, which should be avoided.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "However, French people tend to maintain a clear distinction between their business lives and personal lives. Thus, avoid attempting to be overly friendly as your French counterpart may interpret this as an attempt to develop a friendship."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French executives prioritize building long-term business relationships and value having an extensive network of close personal business connections, which requires establishing mutual trust and respect before engaging in business discussions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French executives tend to focus on building long-term business relationships, and it is considered important to have a wide network of close personal business connections. In order to establish and maintain those relationships, mutual trust and respect are paramount, and are usually earned through proper behaviour and formality."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Trust and respect in French business culture are developed through formal and proper behavior, indicating that relationship-building efforts must adhere to cultural norms before business meetings can progress.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In order to establish and maintain those relationships, mutual trust and respect are paramount, and are usually earned through proper behaviour and formality."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French business culture, hierarchy is important, and attendees are typically introduced at the beginning of a meeting to clarify their roles and positions within the organizational structure. This reflects a cultural emphasis on recognizing experience and seniority before engaging in business discussions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "As such, you’ll probably find that a little time is spent at the outset of the meeting introducing attendees and their roles. It’s important to take heed of this information so that you understand people’s positions within both the hierarchy and the decision-making process."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Junior participants may withhold opinions during meetings if their managers are present, out of respect for hierarchy and to avoid losing face, indicating that age and experience influence participation dynamics before and during meetings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You may find that more junior meeting attendees are reluctant to offer opinions if their managers are present. They may also fail to speak up due to concerns over maintaining face."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Appointments should be scheduled at least two weeks in advance and punctuality is highly valued in French business culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Appointments are necessary and should be made at least two weeks in advance."  
  - Location paragraph 1 (p1)  
  - Quoted text "Punctuality is valued and appreciated in French business culture."  
  - Location paragraph 1 (p1)===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French professionals expect the use of formal titles and inclusion of academic degrees on business cards, reflecting respect for experience and status.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Print business cards in either English or French and be sure to include your academic degree and/or title."  
  - Location paragraph 1 (p1)  
  - Quoted text "Titles should be used in both correspondence and in face-to-face meetings."  
  - Location paragraph 1 (p1)===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Rank determines the order of entry into meeting rooms and seating arrangements, emphasizing respect for hierarchy and experience.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The order in which people enter a room is based on rank."  
  - Location paragraph 1 (p1)  
  - Quoted text "Wait to be told where to sit, as seating arrangements are in order of ranking."  
  - Location paragraph 1 (p1)===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business decisions are made by top-level management, reflecting a cultural preference for authority and experience in leadership roles.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Decisions are made at the top of the company."  
  - Location paragraph 2 (p2)  
  - Quoted text "The boss of the company will be authoritative."  
  - Location paragraph 2 (p2)===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meals in France are primarily seen as opportunities to build relationships rather than to discuss business directly, and engaging in light conversation before transitioning to business topics is common.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Business meals are seen as opportunities to build relationships rather than just discuss business."  
  - Location p10  

- Rule Description During business lunches, it is typical to engage in light conversation and bond over topics like food and wine before discussing business, helping to create a relaxed atmosphere and rapport.  
- ===from https://executiveplanet.com/french-business-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Informal settings such as Happy Hour provide relaxed environments for building relationships with business partners before formal meetings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The tradition of Happy Hour is also prevalent, which provides a relaxed setting for informal discussions and relationship building after work."  
  - Location p12===from https://executiveplanet.com/french-business-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French business culture, especially in hierarchical meetings led by a boss, it is crucial to engage in informal lobbying before the official meeting to have any real influence on decisions, as formal meetings often serve only to confirm prior agreements.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In such an environment, it is vital to be actively involved in the pre-meeting lobbying if any influence at all is to be brought to bear."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.worldbusinessculture.com/country-profiles/france/business-meeting-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French business meetings, particularly those chaired by senior leaders, typically follow a predetermined agenda and are used to communicate decisions already made, rather than to debate or resolve issues.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "As management style tends towards the directive, meetings can often be more for the dissemination of information of decisions previously arrived at than for the open debate of perceived difficulties."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.worldbusinessculture.com/country-profiles/france/business-meeting-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Open disagreement with a superior during a formal meeting is rare; instead, dissent or critique is expressed through private, informal discussions prior to the meeting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In such formal meetings it would be rare to contradict the boss openly – this will have been done elsewhere, prior to the meeting in more informal lobbying sessions."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.worldbusinessculture.com/country-profiles/france/business-meeting-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French business culture, it is customary to engage in friendly but professional small talk at the beginning of a meeting to build rapport before transitioning to formal business matters.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Business meetings start with friendly but professional small talk to build a rapport."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://excellentetiquette.com/business-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: During business lunches, actual business discussions do not begin until after dessert, as the host determines when to initiate such conversations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The host will initiate business talk, which happens after dessert."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://excellentetiquette.com/business-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Social interactions during business meetings in France should avoid informal language and require the use of formal titles and respect for hierarchy, with direct communication across hierarchical levels being time-consuming and potentially inappropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French organisations are very hierarchical and communications across these lines can be a time consuming process, if you want to speak to the manager, speak to them directly."
  - Location paragraph 36===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is expected to speak French during business meetings, even with limited proficiency, as starting a conversation in English is considered inappropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t start a conversation in English, try to speak French even if your language knowledge is limited, you will increase your chances of a positive business meeting."
  - Location paragraph 35===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Being on time is important and appreciated in French business meetings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Punctuality is valued and appreciated in French business culture."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Meetings follow a set format and include a detailed agenda.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Meetings typically follow an established format with a detailed agenda."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The seating arrangement in meetings reflects rank, and individuals should wait to be told where to sit.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Wait to be told where to sit, as seating arrangements are in order of ranking."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The order in which people enter the meeting room is determined by their professional rank.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The order in which people enter a room is based on rank."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business decisions are made slowly and outside of meetings, so participants should remain patient and not show frustration.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Business tends to be conducted slowly. Be patient and avoid appearing disgruntled by the strict adherence to protocol. The deliberation and decision-making processes are also quite slow. However, they are done outside of the meeting."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meals, particularly lunch and dinner meetings, are commonly used in France during the initial phase of negotiations to develop a more personal relationship between counterparts and allow for open, less formal business discussions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Lunch and dinner meetings are particularly popular during the initial phase of negotiations. Because of the long term approach in business relationship building, business meals tend to be a way of developing a more personal relationship between counterparts, as well as a way of conducting a more open and less formal business discussion."
  - Location paragraph 12 (Meetings Management)===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Small talk is uncommon during business meetings in France, especially with first-time counterparts, and personal topics such as family should be avoided in favor of focusing directly on business matters.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Small talk during meetings isn't common, especially when the counterparts are meeting for the first time. Therefore, it's important to focus on the subject matter of the deal and not bring up personal matters such as family."
  - Location paragraph 10 (Meetings Management)===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meals are typically held in restaurants rather than cafes or bars, as restaurants are considered more appropriate for conducting informal business discussions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "They are usually conducted in restaurants rather than cafes or bars."
  - Location paragraph 12 (Meetings Management)===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The person who invites others to a business meal is expected to pay for all attendees.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is also important to note that the person who extends the invitation for a meal is expected to pay for everybody."
  - Location paragraph 12 (Meetings Management)===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Handshakes are required when meeting someone for the first time or in business contexts, and it is customary to shake hands again when leaving.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French shake hands almost whenever they meet, and always when meeting someone for the first time or for business. Arriving at work in the morning, it is common to greet colleagues with a handshake and to shake hands again when leaving."
  - Location p4===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/living/integration/french-etiquette-101246/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The formal pronoun "vous" should be used in professional settings; one should wait for the other person to initiate use of the informal "tu".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The choice of whether to use the formal vous and informal tu to say ‘you’ in French can be confusing. But a simple rule is that the more intimate tu is only for family and friends. It is common for work colleagues to say tu, but wait until someone else does it first."
  - Location p5===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/living/integration/french-etiquette-101246/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When meeting someone new in a professional context, individuals should be addressed formally using titles such as Monsieur, Madame, or Mademoiselle, often followed by their last name, until invited to use their first name.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If addressing a stranger, you should always greet them formally before asking anything; whenever meeting someone new, address them with either Monsieur, Madame or Mademoiselle..."
  - Location p5===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/living/integration/french-etiquette-101246/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Arriving punctually, but not early, is considered essential in most formal interactions, including business-related meetings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Arriving punctually, but never early, is also vital in most aspects of etiquette in France."
  - Location p7===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/living/integration/french-etiquette-101246/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meetings in France are not typically used for making decisions, which means meetings may focus on discussion and information sharing rather than concluding with immediate outcomes; thus, additional time should be allowed beyond the meeting for decisions to be made separately.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "On the whole, meetings are rarely used as a place for decision-making. Instead, the meeting setting allows for the sharing of ideas and details, with decisions being made separately outside of this."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Attempting to rush meeting proceedings or push for quick decisions is discouraged, as the detailed analysis and consensus-building process is considered essential and takes time.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "As with detail sharing, don’t try to hurry this process. It’s an important part of French business management and you will only irritate people if you chase outcomes prematurely."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meetings in France tend to proceed slowly, with a strong emphasis on following protocol and detailed deliberation, requiring patience from participants.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Business tends to be conducted slowly. Be patient and avoid appearing disgruntled by the strict adherence to protocol."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Deliberation and decision-making occur outside of meetings, indicating that meetings themselves are not primarily for making immediate decisions, which may influence their duration and structure.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The deliberation and decision-making processes are also quite slow. However, they are done outside of the meeting."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meetings in France, particularly business lunches, are typically long and formal, often lasting up to two hours, as they are viewed as opportunities to build relationships rather than solely for discussing business.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Business lunches are a common and important practice. They are typically long and formal affairs, often lasting up to two hours, and are seen as an opportunity to build relationships rather than discuss business matters directly."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://executiveplanet.com/french-business-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meetings in France are typically scheduled about two weeks in advance and are primarily used for discussion rather than decision-making, which usually occurs after several meetings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Meetings should be scheduled about two weeks in advance. They tend to be held primarily to discuss issues, not to make decisions - which are usually made after several meetings."
  - Location paragraph 8 (Time Management)===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Meetings in France follow a structured and inflexible agenda, with the initial minutes dedicated to reviewing the pre-established agenda, indicating that time is allocated purposefully and deviations are uncommon.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, meeting agendas tend to be structured and fairly inflexible. All attendees are expected to contribute to the discussion, so careful planning and preparation are important, ensuring that all objectives and strategies have been set out."
  - Location paragraph 8 (Time Management)
  - Quoted text "The initial minutes of a business meeting in France are commonly used to go over the pre-established agenda."
  - Location paragraph 13 (Meetings Management)===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Senior leaders are expected to guide discussions in meetings, and subordinates should respect the hierarchical structure by not bypassing authority or publicly challenging senior figures.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In meetings Senior leaders usually guide discussions, but well-reasoned contributions are welcomed and respected."
  - Location p6

- Rule Description Directly challenging senior leaders in public forums is considered inappropriate and may damage professional relationships.
- ===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/french-work-culture-cultural-differences-in-business/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Decisions in French business meetings are typically made at the top levels of the organization, and gaining the support of key decision-makers is crucial, indicating a hierarchical structure where senior leaders hold significant influence.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Understanding the hierarchy within the organization can also be beneficial, as decisions are often made at the top levels, and gaining the support of key decision-makers is crucial."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://executiveplanet.com/french-business-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, it is customary to show respect to individuals in official or professional positions by using their formal titles when addressing them, which reflects deference to their status.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "All sorts of people, and especially politicians, expect recognition of their position. As a courtesy under typical French manners, when addressing the local mayor it is usual to say Monsieur (or Madame) le maire. A policeman is Monsieur l’agent. Academic titles and degrees are also important, and you should know and use them where possible (such as a doctor)."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/living/integration/french-etiquette-101246/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In professional or unfamiliar settings, the formal pronoun "vous" must be used instead of the informal "tu" when speaking to someone, and one should wait for the other person to initiate the shift to informality.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The choice of whether to use the formal vous and informal tu to say ‘you’ in French can be confusing. But a simple rule is that the more intimate tu is only for family and friends. It is common for work colleagues to say tu, but wait until someone else does it first."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/living/integration/french-etiquette-101246/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When meeting someone new or in formal situations, individuals should be addressed with honorifics such as Monsieur, Madame, or Mademoiselle, showing respect and adherence to formal etiquette.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If addressing a stranger, you should always greet them formally before asking anything; whenever meeting someone new, address them with either Monsieur, Madame or Mademoiselle..."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/living/integration/french-etiquette-101246/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In business settings, showing respect to one's superior, such as a boss, is expected; this may include men standing up or making a gesture of standing when the boss enters the room.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In some companies, as a sign of respect, men will get up or make the gesture of standing up when the boss enters the room."
  - Location paragraph 48===from https://www.annieandre.com/french-business-etiquette-infographic/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French business counterparts take a serious and formal approach to negotiations, and attempting to change this approach is not advised.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You cannot change the serious approach that your French counterparts will take and you are advised not to attempt to."
  - Location paragraph 1 (Negotiation process)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Negotiations focus strictly on the subject matter of the deal, and introducing personal topics such as family may reduce chances of success or cause offense.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In your negotiations, you have to focus on the subject matter of the deal you are discussing and at no point should you bring in other matters such as family as this will, if anything, reduce your chances of getting what you want and also possibly offend your negotiation partners."
  - Location paragraph 1 (Negotiation process)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Direct and detailed questions are expected during negotiations, and being prepared to answer them thoroughly is important.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "During business negotiations, be prepared to answer direct and detailed questions."
  - Location paragraph 2 (Negotiation process)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Persistence and tenacity are rewarded in negotiations, as agreements usually take a long time to reach.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Your persistence and tenacity are likely to be rewarded since the longer the negotiations continue the higher are your chances of success, since agreements usually take a long time to reach."
  - Location paragraph 2 (Negotiation process)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Logical reasoning is the main method to persuade French counterparts to change their position; repeating viewpoints indicates they are unlikely to change.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A common sign that you have reached a point where your counterparts will not change their position is when they begin repeating their viewpoints. The main way to persuade your counterparts to change that viewpoint is through the use of logical reasoning."
  - Location paragraph 3 (Negotiation process)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Hard sell techniques or hard bargaining are likely to cause offense and reduce the chances of reaching a deal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Any hard sell techniques or hard bargaining are likely to cause offence and reduce your chances of getting a deal altogether."
  - Location paragraph 3 (Negotiation process)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Even after a contract is signed, re-negotiation may occur due to internal hierarchical decision-making processes within the French organization.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Because of the hierarchical structure of organisations in France, once a decision has been reached between those in the negotiation process, there is a high likelihood that your partners will have to go through a similar internal process and therefore even if you have signed a contract, there is a chance that they will come back to re-negotiate it as a result of internal negotiations."
  - Location paragraph 4 (Negotiation process)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is advisable to identify and engage with the top decision-maker early to speed up negotiations and minimize delays caused by intermediaries.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This is another reason why you should always try and seek out the top decision maker in the organisation to speed up your negotiations and reduce discussions with intermediaries."
  - Location paragraph 4 (Negotiation process)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Intermediaries should still be treated with full respect even if they lack final decision-making authority, as offending them could negatively impact the negotiation outcome.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "However, if you are facing intermediaries treat them with same respect, even though you might be aware that they are not able to finalise the decision on their own. They can help you to reach a positive outcome, but if you offend them this will also be reported and your chances of successful negotiations will be reduced."
  - Location paragraph 4 (Negotiation process)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Deadlines should be clearly communicated and regularly reminded if critical, as they may otherwise be considered flexible by French counterparts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When negotiating be upfront about your deadlines and make sure that your counterparts are reminded of them if they are critical for you, otherwise these will generally be regarded as flexible dates."
  - Location paragraph 5 (Negotiation process)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French negotiators prioritize logical, structured reasoning and expect arguments to be supported by evidence rather than emotional appeals.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French prioritise logic and structured reasoning over persuasion tactics."
  - Location p4===from https://www.negotiationacademy.com/cross-cultural-negotiations/how-to-negotiate-with-the-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Negotiations with the French involve detailed, rigorous debate intended to test ideas and refine strategies, not to create conflict.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Negotiations often resemble a structured debate, with arguments analysed in great detail."
  - Location p4===from https://www.negotiationacademy.com/cross-cultural-negotiations/how-to-negotiate-with-the-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French do not make quick decisions during meetings and prefer thorough discussion before committing, so pressuring for immediate results is counterproductive.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French do not rush decisions. They prefer thorough discussions, exploring all aspects of a deal before committing."
  - Location p6===from https://www.negotiationacademy.com/cross-cultural-negotiations/how-to-negotiate-with-the-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French business culture emphasizes formal behavior, including use of titles and professional appearance, and recognizes hierarchical structures in decision-making.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French business culture places great importance on formality, hierarchical structures, and professional etiquette."
  - Location p5===from https://www.negotiationacademy.com/cross-cultural-negotiations/how-to-negotiate-with-the-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Decisions are typically made after the meeting through internal consultation, not during the negotiation session itself.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Unlike Germans or Americans, who often conclude deals in meetings, the French prefer to deliberate post-discussion before making a decision."
  - Location p7===from https://www.negotiationacademy.com/cross-cultural-negotiations/how-to-negotiate-with-the-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French negotiators expect counterparts to confidently engage in intellectual debate and defend their positions logically, viewing such exchanges as constructive.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Engage in debate, as this is how they test the strength of ideas and refine strategies."
  - Location p6===from https://www.negotiationacademy.com/cross-cultural-negotiations/how-to-negotiate-with-the-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French value recognition of their cultural and business expertise and respond better when proposals are framed as enhancements rather than replacements.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Show an appreciation for French business culture and expertise. Avoid statements that imply French methods are outdated."
  - Location p8===from https://www.negotiationacademy.com/cross-cultural-negotiations/how-to-negotiate-with-the-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French business meetings, hierarchical structure is acknowledged at the beginning, and participants are expected to respect positions within the hierarchy; challenging superiors directly is discouraged.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s important to take heed of this information so that you understand people’s positions within both the hierarchy and the decision-making process. Be aware that in hierarchical cultures, it’s not a good idea to challenge those higher up in the pecking order."
  - Location p3===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Small talk during French business meetings should be brief and focus on neutral topics, avoiding personal subjects due to a strong separation between private and professional life.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Small talk at the outset of a meeting tends to be limited in French business culture. Although pleasantries are exchanged, these should be high-level and unobtrusive. French business professionals tend to keep a strong divide between their private and professional lives, so it’s a good idea to avoid any topics which might be considered personal."
  - Location p2===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French negotiators prioritize detailed, factual analysis over emotional or high-pressure tactics, and expect well-prepared, accurate materials.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French business culture tends to be very detail-focused. It’s rare for the French to make emotive decisions or to be swayed by high-pressure tactics. Instead, time is focused on analysing and unpicking the detail. If you’re preparing materials for a meeting, then make sure your data is sound, as potential flaws are likely to be picked up on quickly."
  - Location p5===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meetings in France are primarily for exchanging information and ideas, not for making final decisions, which are typically made separately after consultation with absent stakeholders.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "On the whole, meetings are rarely used as a place for decision-making. Instead, the meeting setting allows for the sharing of ideas and details, with decisions being made separately outside of this. If the decision-maker and relevant stakeholders are absent from the meeting, then extra time should be allowed for consensus to be gathered between the relevant parties."
  - Location p6===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Junior attendees may withhold opinions in meetings to avoid losing face or contradicting superiors, requiring separate networking to obtain honest feedback.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You may find that more junior meeting attendees are reluctant to offer opinions if their managers are present. They may also fail to speak up due to concerns over maintaining face. If it’s important to solicit input, then you need to network separately with individuals outside of the meeting place."
  - Location p4===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French business negotiations, there is often a deliberate division of roles where a higher-ranking person takes the "good guy" role while someone else assumes the "tough guy" or confrontational role.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The distribution of roles between the ›good guys‹ and the ›bad guys‹ is often apparent in negotiations with the French. Usually, the person in the higher position will take the role of the ›good guy‹ and leave the role of ›tough guy‹ for someone else in the group."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://crossculture2go.com/negotiations-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The final decision-maker may intentionally be absent during negotiations to preserve flexibility and allow for later validation of agreements, enabling diplomatic adjustments without damaging personal relationships.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It may also be a negotiating tactic that the person who eventually makes the decisions, is not present at the talks. In so doing, the delegation’s authority is consciously divided so that there is still room for manoeuvre."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://crossculture2go.com/negotiations-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Agreements reached during meetings are often considered interim solutions that require formal approval from absent superiors, a process known as "faire valider la décision."
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is therefore advisable to ask who is needed for the final decision to be taken... This is called ›faire valider la decision‹ ‒ ›to validate the decision‹."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://crossculture2go.com/negotiations-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Emotional displays such as anger or dramatic behavior during negotiations are used deliberately as a strategic tool and should be taken seriously in form but not necessarily in content.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you experience extrovert moods, anger or histrionics at the conference table, stay calm. It is usually not as dramatic as it seems at first. This behaviour should be recognised as a French negotiating strategy and taken seriously, but the content is not relevant."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://crossculture2go.com/negotiations-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In important negotiations, interruptions are strategically used to increase pressure on the other party.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Good to know in important negotiations in France, interruptions are used as a way of increasing the pressure."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://crossculture2go.com/negotiations-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French negotiators favor a structured line of reasoning based on thesis, antithesis, and synthesis, which underlies discussions even when not explicitly stated.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French have practised the logical three steps thesis, antithesis and synthesis since their childhood. This order can be recognised in negotiations even if not everything is stated explicitly but only implied."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://crossculture2go.com/negotiations-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French negotiators are skeptical of arguments based solely on facts and expect underlying motives or strategic reasoning to be revealed.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "That is why French partners become sceptical when the line of argumentation is of a purely factual nature and they want to know what lies behind it. They start suspecting other reasons and interests behind factual information."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://crossculture2go.com/negotiations-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Initial prices are generally seen as starting points for negotiation rather than final offers, and flexibility is expected through price adjustments or other variables like delivery time or quantity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "No-one expects the price quoted at the beginning of a conference to have been realistically calculated... They assume that the first price quoted is a guide and that more offers will follow."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://crossculture2go.com/negotiations-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Even after agreements appear finalized, additional negotiations may be initiated to gain further advantages, justified by the principle that "that's all part of a fair fight" ("C’est de bonne guerre!").
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Additional negotiations may also be initiated in France even if it appears that everything has been finalised. In this case, it is accepted that you wish to reap the benefits from the situation. If, for example, you have to wait longer for results, you can ask for more. You can then say with a smile ›C’est de bonne guerre!‹"
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://crossculture2go.com/negotiations-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French prefer a calm, logical, and non-confrontational approach during negotiations, valuing detailed explanations over aggressive sales tactics.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French dislike confrontational behaviour or high-pressure sales tactics. They are more receptive to a low-key, logical presentation that thoroughly explains the advantages of a proposal."
  - Location paragraph number (p1)

- Rule Description French businesspeople carefully analyze all details of a proposal during negotiations and appreciate formal, rational discussions that allow for debate and questioning.
- ===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French business culture, decisions are typically not made during meetings; instead, meetings serve as forums for exchanging information and discussing details, while actual decisions are finalized separately among key stakeholders after the meeting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "On the whole, meetings are rarely used as a place for decision-making. Instead, the meeting setting allows for the sharing of ideas and details, with decisions being made separately outside of this."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When decision-makers or key stakeholders are absent from a meeting, additional time is expected to gather consensus among them before a decision is reached, and this process should not be rushed.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If the decision-maker and relevant stakeholders are absent from the meeting, then extra time should be allowed for consensus to be gathered between the relevant parties. As with detail sharing, don’t try to hurry this process."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Decisions are not made during business meetings in France; instead, meetings are intended for discussion, and formal decisions typically occur afterward through internal processes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is important to note that in France, meetings are held to discuss issues, not to make decisions."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Even if an agreement is reached during negotiations, French counterparts may need to undergo internal hierarchical approval processes, which could lead to re-negotiation after the meeting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Because of the hierarchical structure of organisations in France, once a decision has been reached between those in the negotiation process, there is a high likelihood that your partners will have to go through a similar internal process and therefore even if you have signed a contract, there is a chance that they will come back to re-negotiate it as a result of internal negotiations."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meetings involve rigorous intellectual debate where participants are expected to defend their views with logical reasoning, as the French value demonstration of intellectual ability.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French will judge you on your ability to demonstrate your intellectual faculties and this would usually mean discussing polar views and placing you in the middle of a rigorous debate."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French business meetings follow a strict, inflexible agenda, and all attendees are expected to contribute to discussions in a prepared and serious manner.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Meetings follow a rigid format with a detailed agenda."  
  - Location paragraph 3

- Rule Description All participants are expected to be prepared and contribute actively to the discussion during the meeting.
- ===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Decisions in French business meetings are not made during the meeting itself but are deliberated and finalized outside of the meeting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The deliberation and decision-making processes are also quite slow. However, they are done outside of the meeting."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French business meetings follow a formal structure with a detailed agenda and adhere strictly to protocol.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Meetings typically follow an established format with a detailed agenda."
  - Location paragraph 7

- Rule Description Adherence to protocol is strict in French business meetings, and participants should be patient and avoid showing frustration.
- ===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meetings in France emphasize structured, logical debate rooted in theoretical analysis rather than quick decisions or intuition.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Meetings resemble academic discussions, with a focus on precision and well-reasoned arguments."
  - Location p6===from https://birdwellgroup.com/intercultural/what-influences-the-french-decision-making/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French business meetings use a process of thesis, antithesis, and synthesis to refine ideas through intellectual confrontation, where disagreement is expected and valued if logically supported.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Thesis – An idea is proposed. Antithesis – A counterargument challenges it. Synthesis – A refined conclusion emerges, integrating the best of both perspectives."
  - Location p7===from https://birdwellgroup.com/intercultural/what-influences-the-french-decision-making/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Meetings are viewed as intellectual battlegrounds where challenging ideas—provided they are logically constructed—is a core part of the decision-making process.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Meetings in France are more than just decision-making tools—they are intellectual battlegrounds. Challenging authority is not just tolerated but expected, provided arguments are well-structured and logical."
  - Location p9===from https://birdwellgroup.com/intercultural/what-influences-the-french-decision-making/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In business meetings, the French prefer formal, logically supported reasoning rather than informal brainstorming sessions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French value logical, well-supported reasoning over casual brainstorming."
  - Location p14===from https://birdwellgroup.com/intercultural/what-influences-the-french-decision-making/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Decisions in French business meetings are typically not made during the meeting itself but are determined afterward by senior leaders within the company.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Decisions are usually made outside meetings, by those at the top of the company."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meetings in France are primarily intended for discussing issues rather than making final decisions, which require additional time and internal consultation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "They tend to be held primarily to discuss issues, not to make decisions - which are usually made after several meetings."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The decision-making process in French business culture is slow and involves deliberation, requiring patience from external parties.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The deliberation and decision-making processes are usually quite slow. Therefore, patience is appreciated, whereas pressure will be taken negatively."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Even if an initial agreement is reached with counterparts, it must go through an internal approval process with higher-level management before being finalized.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Because of the hierarchical structure of organisations in France, once a decision has been reached in the negotiation process, your French counterparts usually have to go through a similar internal negotiation process with their superiors."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meals, such as lunch or dinner meetings, are considered common and appropriate settings for conducting informal business discussions and developing personal relationships with counterparts during negotiations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is common to hold (or pursue) meetings in a restaurant during lunch or breakfast. Many business people appreciate these meetings, as they allow informal business discussions."
  - Location paragraph 2 (First Contact)

- Rule Description Business meals are often used during the initial phase of negotiations to build long-term relationships and enable more open and less formal discussions between counterparts.
- ===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French business meetings, it is culturally inappropriate to directly challenge or confront individuals who are higher in the organizational hierarchy; doing so may be seen as disrespectful.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Be aware that in hierarchical cultures, it’s not a good idea to challenge those higher up in the pecking order. Instead, show due deference and consider alternative ways of raising potential challenges should they arise."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Junior attendees may avoid expressing opinions or disagreeing during meetings when their managers are present, due to concerns about causing embarrassment or losing face.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You may find that more junior meeting attendees are reluctant to offer opinions if their managers are present. They may also fail to speak up due to concerns over maintaining face."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Direct confrontation or hard-selling tactics are avoided and considered offensive; instead, logical reasoning is preferred to persuade counterparts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Any hard sell techniques or hard bargaining are likely to cause offence and reduce your chances of getting a deal altogether."
