- Rule Description Disagreements are acceptable as long as they are justified with clear reasoning, and maintaining intellectual debate without personal conflict is valued.
- ===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French prefer to avoid confrontational behavior during business negotiations and are more receptive to calm, logical presentations rather than aggressive tactics.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French dislike confrontational behaviour or high-pressure sales tactics. They are more receptive to a low-key, logical presentation that thoroughly explains the advantages of a proposal."
  - Location paragraph 1 (Negotiations section)===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The text does not provide evidence that French business culture avoids confrontation during meetings; rather, it indicates that discussions are often intense and involve rigorous debate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Discussions can be intense and are usually treated as intellectual exercises."

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is important to begin a follow-up communication with an expression of appreciation for the meeting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Use the phrase “Comme convenu” (as agreed) to confirm and restate points that were previously agreed upon during the meeting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Use expressions like “Je vais …” or “Je vous recontacte …” to clearly communicate the next actions you will take after the meeting.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Conclude the follow-up message with a polite offer to provide further assistance, which helps maintain professionalism and reassurance.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: After a business meeting, it is important to quickly distribute meeting minutes and follow up on action items to reinforce the meeting's importance and prevent memory errors.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Prepare and distribute minutes within 24 hours. Quick action on this reinforces the importance of the meeting with the French and also reduces errors in memory."  
  - Location paragraph number (p1)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A few days after the meeting, making a follow-up phone call is appreciated by French colleagues and considered a valuable personal gesture in business practice.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A number of days after the meeting, your French colleagues will appreciate a follow-up phone call. This personal touch and effort is important in French business practice."  
  - Location paragraph number (p1)===from https://businessculture.org/western-europe/business-culture-in-france/meeting-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Follow-up communication after a business meeting in France typically involves internal discussions within the French company, as decisions are rarely made during the meeting itself and instead require approval from higher-level executives.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Decisions are usually made outside meetings, by those at the top of the company."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is important to be patient after a business meeting, as the decision-making process is slow and requires multiple meetings and internal negotiations before an agreement can be reached.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The deliberation and decision-making processes are usually quite slow. Therefore, patience is appreciated, whereas pressure will be taken negatively. It usually takes several meetings to reach an agreement."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Once a decision has been made following internal discussions, agreements are typically formalized through comprehensive and precise contracts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When an agreement is reached, it is usually formalised in a comprehensive, precise contract."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://santandertrade.com/en/portal/establish-overseas/france/business-practices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Decisions are not typically made during meetings but are instead reached separately after the meeting, requiring follow-up to gather consensus among decision-makers and stakeholders who may have been absent.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "On the whole, meetings are rarely used as a place for decision-making. Instead, the meeting setting allows for the sharing of ideas and details, with decisions being made separately outside of this. If the decision-maker and relevant stakeholders are absent from the meeting, then extra time should be allowed for consensus to be gathered between the relevant parties."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Decisions are typically not made during the meeting itself; instead, the French prefer to deliberate and consult internally after the discussion before finalizing any agreement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Unlike Germans or Americans, who often conclude deals in meetings, the French prefer to deliberate post-discussion before making a decision."  
  - Location paragraph 4  

- Rule Description Following up with detailed documentation is essential, as initial agreements are rarely final and further refinements or counterpoints may be introduced after the meeting.  
- ===from https://www.negotiationacademy.com/cross-cultural-negotiations/how-to-negotiate-with-the-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meetings in France are primarily for sharing ideas and details rather than making final decisions, with actual decisions being made separately after the meeting by decision-makers and stakeholders.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "On the whole, meetings are rarely used as a place for decision-making. Instead, the meeting setting allows for the sharing of ideas and details, with decisions being made separately outside of this."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When key decision-makers or stakeholders are absent from a meeting, additional time must be allowed for them to consult and reach consensus after the meeting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If the decision-maker and relevant stakeholders are absent from the meeting, then extra time should be allowed for consensus to be gathered between the relevant parties."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Final decisions and deliberations in French business culture are typically made outside of formal meetings, even though discussions may occur during the meeting itself.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Decisions are typically not made during meetings but are finalized afterward through internal discussions among senior leaders; therefore, negotiations effectively continue after the meeting concludes.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French culture, politeness and formality are highly codified, with the use of honorific titles and formal expressions being essential in communication.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.mister-mikas-classroom.com/2024/09/30/les-differences-culturelles-dans-les-styles-de-communication/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French communication relies heavily on non-verbal cues and interpersonal relationships, where the meaning of messages is often derived from the social context rather than explicit words.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Cultures à contexte élevé (comme la France, l'Italie)  La communication dépend fortement du contexte non-verbal et des relations interpersonnelles. Le message est souvent compris à travers le contexte social et les relations."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://altraductions.com/blog/les-differences-de-communication-a-travers-les-cultures

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French culture, messages are often conveyed implicitly, requiring listeners to interpret meaning based on context rather than direct statements.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Dans une culture à contexte élevé, le silence peut être significatif et porteur de sens, alors que dans une culture à contexte faible, il peut être perçu comme embarrassant ou incompréhensible."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://altraductions.com/blog/les-differences-de-communication-a-travers-les-cultures

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French people tend to be less direct when communicating positive messages, preferring indirect methods over straightforward expressions of approval or praise.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Et s’ils sont très directs pour parler de sexe ou de politique, ils le seront beaucoup moins pour parler d’argent…"
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://gestion-des-risques-interculturels.com/risques/la-communication-indirecte-exemples-observations-et-reflexions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French use indirect communication when addressing topics considered sensitive or uncomfortable, such as money, avoiding direct language to maintain social harmony.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Et s’ils sont très directs pour parler de sexe ou de politique, ils le seront beaucoup moins pour parler d’argent…"
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://gestion-des-risques-interculturels.com/risques/la-communication-indirecte-exemples-observations-et-reflexions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French culture, communication relies heavily on non-verbal cues and interpersonal relationships, where the message is often interpreted through social context rather than explicit words.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Cultures à contexte élevé (comme la France, l'Italie)  La communication dépend fortement du contexte non-verbal et des relations interpersonnelles. Le message est souvent compris à travers le contexte social et les relations."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://altraductions.com/blog/les-differences-de-communication-a-travers-les-cultures

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In high-context cultures like France, messages are often conveyed indirectly or implicitly to preserve politeness and social harmony, with meaning derived from context rather than direct statements.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French humour often involves mocking the country, its culture, regions, and people, but this criticism stems from affection rather than disdain.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La France, les humoristes l'ont autant dans le viseur que dans le cœur. Qui aime bien châtie bien."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.france.tv/documentaires/documentaires-art-et-culture/7770921-l-humour-a-la-francaise.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French comedians use exaggeration as a tool to reflect societal realities, acting like a magnifying glass that shows people what they truly are.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "leur humour est une loupe grossissante qui nous renvoie à ceux que nous sommes en poussant plus ou moins le trait."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.france.tv/documentaires/documentaires-art-et-culture/7770921-l-humour-a-la-francaise.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Comedians from popular backgrounds who are deeply connected to their regions are seen as particularly skilled at mocking France and the French due to their authentic regional ties.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Il existe même une tradition d'artistes issus de milieux populaires qui, parce qu'ils sont attachés à leurs régions, savent mieux que personne se moquer de la France et des Français."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.france.tv/documentaires/documentaires-art-et-culture/7770921-l-humour-a-la-francaise.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, humour is considered a culturally significant way of expressing oneself, often aimed at making others laugh through jokes or ridiculing situations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "L’humour est une manière de s’exprimer qui tend à faire rire son interlocuteur en l’interpellant avec une histoire drôle ou un fait tourné en dérision."
  - Location p1===from https://www.accentfrancais.com/fr/blog/humour-des-francais

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Irony is the most prominent and characteristic form of humour in French culture, distinguishing it from other national styles such as British black humour.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "En France l’ironie trône en maitre sur cette discipline."
  - Location p2===from https://www.accentfrancais.com/fr/blog/humour-des-francais

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A sense of humour is regarded as an essential intellectual quality in France and plays a key role in social integration across all stages of life.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "En France, il est aussi important de noter que l’humour est reconnu comme un trait d’esprit important, nécessaire à l’intégration sociale."
  - Location p3===from https://www.accentfrancais.com/fr/blog/humour-des-francais

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French children are introduced early to simple, accessible forms of humour, such as short jokes found inside candy wrappers (e.g., Carambar) and animated films.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Dès son enfance, après-midi confiseries et films vont rythmer ces weekends... les carambars possèdent une blague courte, facile à comprendre inscrites au creux de leurs emballages."
  - Location p4===from https://www.accentfrancais.com/fr/blog/humour-des-francais

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: During adolescence and young adulthood, French audiences engage with humour through stand-up comedy and imitation-based shows like Jamel Comedy Club, which targets youth and promotes suburban ("banlieue") humour.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Vient ensuite l’époque ensuite de l’adolescence et le début de la vie d’adulte... Stands Up et imitations sont le maître mot de cette émission, qui par sa promotion de l’humour dit « de banlieue » vise seulement un public jeune."
  - Location p5===from https://www.accentfrancais.com/fr/blog/humour-des-francais

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: With the rise of digital platforms like YouTube, young French people create and share humorous videos featuring themselves, exemplified by personalities such as Norman and Cyprien.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "L'entrée dans l’ère du digital et d’internet fait également exploser Youtube et des jeunes qui s’en empare afin de partager des vidéos à but humoristique, où ils se mettent en scène pour égayer leurs audiences, comme Norman ou Cyprien."
  - Location p6===from https://www.accentfrancais.com/fr/blog/humour-des-francais

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: As individuals become adults, their engagement with humour shifts toward more refined, sophisticated forms such as clever wordplay, nuanced jokes, and intellectual wit, replacing simpler childhood humour.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Adulte, tout devient plus sérieux, plus sobre, plus spirituel également. Adepte des traits d’esprits les plus marqués, jeux de mots et blagues travaillées remplacent films d’animations et blagues Carambar."
  - Location p7===from https://www.accentfrancais.com/fr/blog/humour-des-francais

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Stand-up comedy is highly popular in modern France, with performers using observational and situational humour to critique everyday life, and top comedians like Gad Elmaleh gaining international recognition.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Le stand-up connaît en France un énorme succès, avec des têtes d’affiches qui s’exportent maintenant à l’internationale, comme Gad Elmaleh. Maîtres dans l’humour situationnel, ces artistes captivent leurs auditoires en tournant en dérision leurs quotidiens sur scène."
  - Location p8===from https://www.accentfrancais.com/fr/blog/humour-des-francais

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Traditional French humour placed greater emphasis on artistic expression, theatrical performance, and mastery of language, as seen in comedic theatre and figures like Molière and Coluche.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Il est important de préciser que l’humour d’antan était plus artistique, plus porté sur le théâtral et la maitrise de la langue de Molière qu’aujourd’hui. Pièces de théâtre comique, maîtrise des jeux de mots, l’humour se voulait plus « travaillé »..."
  - Location p9===from https://www.accentfrancais.com/fr/blog/humour-des-francais

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French humour includes various styles such as situational comedy, wordplay, character-based comedy, and repetitive comedy, each relying on specific comedic techniques.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "L’humour français est riche et varié. On y trouve plusieurs styles qui ont chacun leurs propres caractéristiques."
  - Location p2===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Situational humour in France is based on absurd, unexpected, or hilarious situations, often used in comedies and TV series focusing on everyday interactions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Le comique de situation repose sur des situations absurdes, inattendues ou hilarantes. Ce type d’humour est souvent utilisé dans les comédies de boulevard et les séries télévisées."
  - Location p3===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wordplay, including puns and double meanings, is highly valued in French humour and requires creative use of language.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Le comique de mots, ou le jeu de mots, est très prisé en France. Il s’agit d’utiliser la langue de manière créative pour créer des calembours, des double sens ou des rimes humoristiques."
  - Location p4===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Character-based humour relies on exaggerated or stereotyped personalities, often seen in caricatures and impersonations by comedians.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ce type d’humour repose sur des personnages exagérés ou stéréotypés. Les caricatures et les imitations en sont des exemples typiques."
  - Location p5===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Repetitive humour uses the repetition of a phrase, gesture, or situation to create a comic effect, exemplified by sketches from humorists like Raymond Devos.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ce type d’humour utilise la répétition d’une phrase, d’un geste ou d’une situation pour créer un effet comique. Les sketches de l’humoriste Raymond Devos, où il répète des expressions de manière absurde, illustrent bien ce style."
  - Location p6===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Understanding idiomatic expressions is essential for appreciating French humour, as these fixed phrases are often used to create jokes or humorous situations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Les expressions idiomatiques sont des phrases figées dont le sens ne peut être deviné simplement en comprenant les mots individuels. [...] Ces expressions sont souvent utilisées dans l’humour français pour créer des jeux de mots ou des situations comiques."
  - Location p8===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French humour frequently incorporates historical references, with figures like Napoleon or events like the French Revolution being common subjects for jokes and parodies.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "L’histoire de France est riche en événements et en personnages qui sont souvent la cible de l’humour. Par exemple, les blagues sur Napoléon ou sur la Révolution française sont courantes."
  - Location p9===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French culture—including film, literature, music, and cuisine—provides abundant material for humour, especially through clichés such as the French love for wine and cheese.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La culture française est également une source inépuisable d’humour. Les films, la littérature, la musique et même la gastronomie sont souvent utilisés comme thèmes humoristiques. Par exemple, les clichés sur les Français et leur amour pour le vin et le fromage sont fréquemment exploités."
  - Location p10===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Political satire is a popular form of humour in France, with comedians and shows mocking politicians and political events, requiring audience familiarity with current affairs.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La satire politique est un genre très prisé en France. Les émissions comme « Les Guignols de l’info » ou les sketches de certains humoristes comme Coluche ou Nicolas Canteloup se moquent souvent des politiciens et des événements politiques."
  - Location p11===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Humour varies across French regions due to linguistic and cultural differences, with local accents and regional stereotypes commonly featured in jokes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La France est un pays de régions, et chaque région a ses propres particularités linguistiques et culturelles. Les blagues qui sont populaires à Paris peuvent ne pas être comprises en Provence, et vice versa. Par exemple, les blagues sur les accents régionaux ou les stéréotypes locaux sont courantes."
  - Location p12===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Humour changes over time, with younger generations finding modern topics like technology and social media funnier than older generations might.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "L’humour évolue avec le temps, et ce qui fait rire une génération peut laisser une autre de marbre. Les jeunes Français d’aujourd’hui ont des références culturelles et des styles d’humour différents de ceux de leurs parents ou grands-parents. Les blagues sur les technologies modernes ou les réseaux sociaux, par exemple, sont plus populaires chez les jeunes."
  - Location p13===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The acceptability of humour depends on social context, and some jokes may be considered offensive depending on the social environment, requiring awareness of audience sensitivities.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

  - Location p14===from https://voyagelinguist.com/fr/comprendre-lhumour-francais-a-travers-la-langue/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French humour is characterized by the ability to laugh at everything and everyone, without exception, making it powerful and explosive.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French humour frequently embraces transgression and lacks moral boundaries, often mocking established values and norms.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French humour can be deliberately provocative and outrageous, challenging societal norms and expectations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Some prominent figures in French humour reject being labeled as comedians, distancing themselves from traditional notions of clownish or slapstick comedy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French humour encompasses a wide range of styles including tender, absurd, crude, ironic, and incisive forms, reflecting its polymorphic nature.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Cheek kissing, known as "la bise," is a common and culturally significant form of greeting among acquaintances in France, expressing warmth and affection.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The number of cheek kisses exchanged during greetings varies by region in France, with no universal rule, such as two in Paris, three in the south, and four in Normandy and Brittany.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Two kisses are common in Paris. In Normandy and Brittany, four kisses greet you. The south of France often opts for three. ... No universal rule dictates the number of kisses."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Physical contact, including gestures like cheek kissing, is a normal part of daily social interactions in France.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Physical contact is a part of daily interactions, so be prepared!"
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Standing close to others during conversations is a cultural norm in France, reflecting warmth rather than intimacy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Close proximity during conversations is a common practice that enhances the intensity of interactions."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Men generally engage in less physical contact than women in social settings, with women often perceived as more affectionate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

  - Location paragraph 8===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Due to the impact of global events like the pandemic, traditional cheek kisses have shifted toward alternatives such as fist bumps in some contexts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Post-COVID, traditional kisses have shifted to fist bumps, illustrating how global events influence local habits."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The acceptability of physical contact depends on context, familiarity, and setting, with home visits and intimate gestures reserved for close friends and family.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Home visits are reserved for close friends and family, highlighting privacy."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The cheek kiss ("la bise") is a common and expected form of greeting among friends, family, and acquaintances in social settings, symbolizing warmth and connection.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La bise is usually exchanged between friends, family members, and acquaintances."
  - Location p7===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The number of kisses during "la bise" varies by region, with two being most common, but three or four possible depending on the area.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The number of kisses can vary by region, with two kisses being the most common, but in some areas, three or four kisses might be customary."
  - Location p6===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: "La bise" involves only a light touch of the cheeks with a kissing sound, not an actual kiss, and is meant to convey friendliness rather than intimacy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s important to note that la bise is not a full kiss but rather a light touch of the cheeks with a kissing sound."
  - Location p6===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In professional environments, "la bise" may be used only if there is an established close relationship between colleagues.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

  - Location p6===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Handshakes are the standard greeting in professional contexts or when meeting someone for the first time, preferred over physical closeness like "la bise".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Handshakes are the standard greeting in professional settings or when meeting someone for the first time."
  - Location p8===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A French handshake is typically brief and firm, with one or two movements, and prolonged handshakes are considered awkward or overly familiar.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A French handshake is typically brief but firm, with one or two up-and-down movements. Unlike in some cultures where extended handshakes are common, the French prefer a quick and efficient handshake."
  - Location p8===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In informal interactions, touches such as pats on the back, touches on the arm, or light taps on the shoulder are used to express warmth or emphasize points, especially among friends and close colleagues.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In informal settings, the French might use casual touches, such as a pat on the back, a touch on the arm, or a light tap on the shoulder, to convey warmth or emphasize a point."
  - Location p9===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In formal or professional environments, touch is generally limited to handshakes, and excessive touching (e.g., back pats or arm grabs) is seen as unprofessional or overly familiar.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Excessive touching, such as back pats or arm grabs, is generally discouraged in formal settings, as it can be seen as unprofessional or overly familiar."
  - Location p11===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is essential to observe non-verbal cues and respect individual comfort levels regarding physical touch, stepping back if someone appears uncomfortable.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Always pay attention to non-verbal cues, such as body language and facial expressions, to gauge whether someone is comfortable with physical closeness or touch. If someone steps back or seems uncomfortable, it’s important to respect their personal space and refrain from further physical contact."
  - Location p13===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When uncertain about physical greetings like "la bise", it is appropriate to ask for consent to ensure mutual comfort.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When in doubt, ask. A simple question like, 'Is it okay if we do la bise?' can go a long way in ensuring that both parties are comfortable."
  - Location p13===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, cheek kissing (bises) is a common form of greeting in both social and professional settings, with the number of kisses varying by region.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Bises sur la joue  courantes dans de nombreux pays européens — la France bien sûr — avec un nombre de bises variable."
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://www.berlitz.com/fr-ca/blog/langage-corporel-different-cultures-monde

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: While not directly about physical contact, the text notes that in France—like other European countries—smiling is less common with strangers, which may reflect a broader cultural norm of reserved physical and emotional expressiveness in public interactions.

However, since the mention of smiling is not specific to France beyond being grouped under "Europe," and does not pertain directly to physical contact, it is provided only as contextual support but does not meet the strict requirement for a rule specifically about physical contact based solely on explicit evidence.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, cheek kissing (bises) is a common form of greeting in both social and professional settings, with the number of kisses varying by region.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Bises sur la joue  courantes dans de nombreux pays européens — la France bien sûr — avec un nombre de bises variable."
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://www.berlitz.com/fr-ca/blog/langage-corporel-different-cultures-monde

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French maintain greater personal space in formal or professional settings as a sign of respect, but stand closer in informal settings among friends or family to express warmth and closeness.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Generally, the French maintain a certain distance when interacting with others, especially in formal or professional settings. This distance is a sign of respect and professionalism."  
  - Location p2  
  - Quoted text "However, this dynamic changes in more informal or social settings. Among friends, family, or in relaxed environments, the French are more comfortable with closer physical proximity."  
  - Location p3===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/understanding-french-body-language-and-gestures-a-guide-to-non-verbal-communication/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Individuals should observe the other person’s body language during interactions; if they step back, it signals a need for more personal space.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Pay attention to the other person’s body language. If they take a step back, it might be a signal to give them more space."  
  - Location p4===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/understanding-french-body-language-and-gestures-a-guide-to-non-verbal-communication/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, people stand closer together during conversations as a cultural expression of warmth and connection.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Close proximity during conversations is a common practice that enhances the intensity of interactions."
  - Location p4===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Maintaining personal space is important in public settings such as public transport, where boundaries should be respected.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Keeping personal space in check shows respect, especially on public transport."
  - Location p1===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Cafe seating arrangements in France are typically closer than expected, reflecting more intimate social settings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Cafes usually have closer seating arrangements than you might expect."
  - Location p8===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Urban areas like Paris tend to have closer interpersonal interactions, while rural regions may maintain more traditional and private personal space norms.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Regional differences in personal space among French people reflect urban versus rural dynamics. Cultural influences shape perceptions, with urban areas like Paris exhibiting closer interactions compared to the more traditional and private views found in rural settings."
  - Location p13===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Weather conditions affect personal space, with warmer weather encouraging closer contact and rainy or cold weather leading to greater distance between individuals.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "During warm, sunny days, people are more likely to engage in physical contact and closer proximity... Conversely, rainy or chilly weather often leads to more distance between individuals..."
  - Location p15===from https://thecuriousvoyager.com/understanding-french-personal-space-and-physical-contact

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Le haussement d’épaules, accompagné d’une légère secousse de la tête et d’un pincement des lèvres, est un geste courant en France pour exprimer l’ignorance ("Je ne sais pas") ou l’indifférence ("Ça m’est égal"), sans que cela soit perçu comme impoli.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Imaginez  vous demandez où sont les toilettes dans un restaurant et, en guise de réponse, on hausse les épaules, pince les lèvres et secoue légèrement la tête. Ce n’est pas de l’impolitesse. C’est simplement une manière de dire « Je ne sais pas » ou « Ça m’est égal »."
  - Location p4===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Les Français utilisent fréquemment leurs mains pour illustrer leurs propos, comme si elles dessinaient dans l’air, afin de renforcer le message verbal et y ajouter de l’émotion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Les Français utilisent leurs mains comme des pinceaux pour dessiner leurs propos dans l’air."
  - Location p5===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Joindre les paumes puis les écarter brusquement signifie que quelque chose est terminé ("c’est fini"), tandis que tourner le doigt près de la tempe indique que quelqu’un n’est pas complètement sain d’esprit.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Par exemple, pour dire « c’est fini », ils joignent leurs paumes avant de les écarter brusquement, comme pour trancher quelque chose. Autre exemple  lorsqu’ils veulent suggérer que quelqu’un n’a pas toute sa tête, ils approchent leur main de la tempe en tournant le doigt."
  - Location p5===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: La bise, consistant en un effleurement des joues accompagné d’un léger bruit, est un geste de proximité sociale, dont le nombre de baisers varie selon les régions, mais elle doit être évitée dans les contextes formels ou avec des inconnus.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ce fameux bisou sur la joue n’est en réalité qu’un effleurement accompagné d’un léger bruit. Le nombre de bises varie selon les régions  une, deux, parfois même quatre. Ce geste traduit une certaine proximité, mais attention, dans un cadre formel ou avec des inconnus, il vaut mieux s’en abstenir."
  - Location p6===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Former un cercle avec le pouce et l’index tout en souriant signifie en France "Parfait" ou "Excellent", et non "OK" comme cela peut être interprété ailleurs.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Si quelqu’un forme un cercle avec le pouce et l’index en souriant, ne pensez pas qu’il vous dit « OK ». En France, ce geste signifie plutôt « Parfait » ou « Excellent »."
  - Location p7===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Un nez froncé accompagné d’un « bof » exprime une incertitude ou un désintérêt poli, équivalent à "Je ne suis pas convaincu", sans avoir besoin de l’exprimer verbalement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Un nez qui se retrousse accompagné d’un « bof » ? C’est une manière discrète d’exprimer l’incertitude ou un désintérêt poli. En somme, cela signifie « Je ne suis pas convaincu », mais sans avoir besoin d’en dire plus."
  - Location p8===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Poser un doigt sur les lèvres signifie "Silence" ou "Tais-toi", mais ce geste peut être perçu comme impoli selon le contexte, donc il doit être utilisé avec précaution.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Un doigt posé sur les lèvres peut avoir plusieurs significations  cela peut vouloir dire « Silence » ou « Tais-toi », selon le contexte. Ce geste, chargé d’intensité, est à manier avec précaution, car il peut facilement être interprété comme impoli."
  - Location p9===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Secouer la tête de gauche à droite, parfois avec les paumes ouvertes vers le ciel, exprime la perplexité, l’impuissance ou une légère résignation face à une situation compliquée.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Secouer la tête de gauche à droite, parfois les paumes ouvertes vers le ciel, est une manière typiquement française de dire « Je ne sais pas quoi faire » ou « C’est compliqué ». Cela traduit la perplexité, l’impuissance, voire une légère résignation."
  - Location p10===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Frotter le pouce contre les autres doigts comme si l’on comptait des billets indique que le sujet est l’argent, pouvant signifier un prix élevé, la cupidité ou simplement le coût de quelque chose.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Frotter le pouce contre les autres doigts comme si l’on comptait des billets signifie qu’il est question d’argent. Cela peut désigner un prix élevé, la cupidité, ou simplement le coût de quelque chose."
  - Location p11===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Montrer les paumes vers le ciel, souvent accompagné d’un soupir ou d’un regard désabusé, exprime la frustration, la perplexité ou la résignation, équivalent à "Que suis-je censé faire ?"
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Accompagnées d’un soupir ou d’un regard désabusé, ce geste exprime la frustration, la perplexité ou la résignation. Une façon silencieuse de dire « Que suis-je censé faire ? »."
  - Location p11===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Les expressions faciales, telles que le haussement de sourcils, le clin d’œil ou le sourire en coin, sont très expressives en France et ajoutent de la nuance et de la profondeur aux échanges verbaux.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "En France, le visage est tout aussi expressif que les mains. Un haussement de sourcils, un clin d’œil, un sourire en coin, tellement de nuances qui ajoutent de la profondeur à l’échange."
  - Location p12===from https://www.lutece-langue.com/fr/blog/maitriser-les-gestes-francais-un-guide-culturel/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A subtle shoulder lift, often accompanied by a sigh or pout, is used to express indifference, doubt, or a sense of not caring about the situation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The 'Bof' Gallic Shrug is when someone slightly lifts one or both shoulders with a faint sigh or pout."
  - Location paragraph 1

- Rule Description This gesture conveys meanings such as “Whatever”, “not my fault”, or “so what?” and is more understated than the full shoulder shrug used in the U.S.
- ===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Puffing cheeks and blowing air through tightened lips to create a soft, fart-like sound expresses indifference, cluelessness, or lack of concern.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French people will often puf up their cheeks and blow out air through their tightened lips, creating a soft, fart-like sound. This is commonly used to express indifference, cluelessness, or that you’re not bothered by something."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Making a loose fist and mimicking the motion of shaving against the cheek expresses boredom or annoyance with someone or something, equivalent to saying "c'est chiant".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The 'What a drag!' hand gesture involves making a loose fist and pretending to rub the top of it against your cheek, like you're mimicking the act of shaving. It means 'c'est chiant', expressing boredom with someone or something."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pulling down the lower eyelid of one eye with the index finger signals disbelief or skepticism, often accompanying the phrase "mon oeil!" ("my foot!").
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This gesture involves using your index finger to slightly pull down the bottom lid of one eye. It's used to express disbelief or skepticism, like saying, 'Yeah, right!' sarcastically. It usually goes with the person saying 'mon oeil!' ('my foot' in U.S talk)."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Sweeping the hand over the top of the head indicates being completely fed up or having reached one’s limit with a frustrating situation, often paired with saying "Ras le bol!".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You sweep your hand over the top of your head to signal that you've had enough, that you're completely fed up or done with a situation. It usually goes with the sentence 'Ras le bol!' (fed up)."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Holding the hand palm-down and twisting it side to side slightly indicates that something is only somewhat true, just okay, or slightly off.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This French gesture involves holding your hand palm down, slightly opened, and twisting it side to side in a small motion. It’s used to indicate that something is just a little bit or somewhat, like when you’re saying something is just okay or slightly off."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Raising the hand near shoulder level and shaking it loosely at the wrist expresses surprise, shock, or exaggerated disbelief, often while saying "Oh la la!".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This one involves raising your hand in front of your shoulder with your elbow slightly out, and shaking your hand loosely at the wrist while saying 'Oh la la!' It’s used to express surprise, shock, or sometimes disbelief, often in a exaggerated way."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Twisting a closed fist back and forth near the nose suggests that someone is drunk or tipsy, referencing the expression "Avoir un coup dans le nez".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This gesture is done by making a fist and twisting it back and forth near your nose, as if you're screwing something in and out. It’s used to suggest that someone is drunk or tipsy - the French expression is 'Avoir un coup dans le nez' (litterally being hit in the nose)."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Lightly touching cheeks and making a kissing sound, typically on both sides, serves as a common greeting among friends, family, and sometimes acquaintances.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It involves lightly touching cheeks with someone and making a soft kissing sound, often on both sides. It’s a common greeting in France, used among friends, family, and sometimes even new acquaintances."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Flicking the thumb upward with a slight wrist motion is a casual way to indicate agreement or approval, meaning "It’s all good" or "That works".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The 'ça marche!' gesture involves flicking your thumb upward, usually with a slight wrist up and down motion. It’s a quick way to say 'It’s all good' or 'That works' in a casual setting."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Rubbing palms together shows eager anticipation for something enjoyable, such as food, money, or an exciting event.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This one involves rubbing your palms together in anticipation, as if you’re getting ready for something exciting. It’s used when you’re eagerly expecting something great, like a delicious meal, making good money, or any exciting event."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Kissing the fingertips and then spreading them outward is a gesture used to express that something, especially food, is delicious.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This gesture is done by bringing your fingers together, kissing the tips, and then spreading them away and outward, as if releasing the kiss into the air. It’s used to show that something, usually food, is absolutely delicious."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Greeting or saying goodbye to friends and family involves exchanging nonromantic air kisses on the cheeks, typically two (right cheek first), though it may vary by region.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Greeting or saying goodbye to friends and family with a sweet (nonromantic) exchange of kisses is perhaps the most essential French gesture. In most parts of France, two cheeks are kissed, right cheek first."
  - Location p10===from https://www.thoughtco.com/top-french-gestures-1371410

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The Gallic shrug ("Bof") expresses indifference, disagreement, doubt, or lack of concern through raised shoulders, palms facing out, protruded lower lip, and raised eyebrows.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Bof, aka the Gallic shrug, is stereotypically French. It is commonly a sign of indifference or disagreement, but it could also mean It's not my fault, I don't know, I doubt it, I don't agree, or I don't care. Raise your shoulders, hold up your arms at the elbows with your palms facing out, stick out your lower lip, raise your eyebrows and say 'Bof!'"
  - Location p11===from https://www.thoughtco.com/top-french-gestures-1371410

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French handshake is firm, brief, and consists of a single downward motion, used among male friends, business associates, and coworkers during greetings and farewells.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A French handshake is a single downward motion, firm, and brief. Male friends, business associates, and coworkers shake hands when greeting and parting."
  - Location p12===from https://www.thoughtco.com/top-french-gestures-1371410

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French start counting on fingers with the thumb as number one, differing from English speakers who typically start with the index or little finger.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French start with the thumb for 1, while English speakers start with the index finger or the little finger."
  - Location p13===from https://www.thoughtco.com/top-french-gestures-1371410

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To express discontent, distaste, or boredom, the French push their lips forward in a pout while squinting their eyes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To show discontent, distaste or another negative emotion, pucker up and push your lips forward, then squint your eyes and look bored. Voilà la moue."
  - Location p14===from https://www.thoughtco.com/top-french-gestures-1371410

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The gesture for "Let's get out of here!" involves holding both hands palm-down and smacking one hand onto the other; it is familiar and should be used cautiously.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French gesture for 'Let's get out of here!' is very common, but it's also familiar, so use it with care. To make this gesture, hold your hands out, palms down, and smack one hand down onto the other."
  - Location p15===from https://www.thoughtco.com/top-french-gestures-1371410

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Tapping the side of the nose with the index finger indicates cleverness or quick thinking, referencing a “good nose” for sensing things.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When you tap the side of your nose with your index finger, you're saying that you are clever and quick-thinking, or you've done or said something smart. 'J'air du nez' literally means that you have a good nose for sensing something."
  - Location p16===from https://www.thoughtco.com/top-french-gestures-1371410

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Sliding the thumb back and forth across the fingertips signals that something is expensive or that money is needed; "du fric" is colloquial for money.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This gesture means that something is very expensive, or that you need money. People sometimes also say du fric! when they make this gesture. To make the gesture, hold one hand up and slide your thumb back and forth across your fingertips."
  - Location p17===from https://www.thoughtco.com/top-french-gestures-1371410

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Twisting a loose fist in front of the nose while tilting the head indicates someone is slightly drunk, symbolizing alcohol (glass) and a red nose from drinking.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To produce this gesture, make a loose fist, twist it in front of your nose, then tilt your head to the other direction while saying, Il a une verre dans le nez."
  - Location p18===from https://www.thoughtco.com/top-french-gestures-1371410

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pulling down the lower eyelid of one eye with the index finger while saying "Mon oeil!" expresses disbelief or skepticism, equivalent to saying "Yeah, right!"
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "With your index finger, pull down the bottom lid of one eye and say, Mon oeil!"
  - Location p19===from https://www.thoughtco.com/top-french-gestures-1371410

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French cultural context, the concept of "beckoning" is used metaphorically to describe something that invites or attracts people through its appeal, promise, or allure—such as opportunities, places, futures, or ideas—rather than referring to a physical gesture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A soundtrack provided a background of nature sounds, including bird songs and animal calls, and fired the imagination, beckoning people to visit the featured locations."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/a+beckoning.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: "Beckoning" can signify a deep spiritual, emotional, or visionary call, such as from ancestors in dreams or from a divine mission, suggesting an invitation to join or move forward toward a higher purpose.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Many people relate a dream where a mother or departed family member is beckoning the elder to join them."
  - Location paragraph 8
- ===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/a+beckoning.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Future possibilities such as careers, knowledge, business improvements, or societal progress are culturally framed as "beckoning," indicating they are inviting or calling individuals toward action or engagement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The first problem facing these young graduates is raised by the fact that the careers beckoning to the individual have increased a thousandfold."
  - Location paragraph 10
- ===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/a+beckoning.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Physical locations, especially desirable or symbolic ones like islands or natural settings, are described as "beckoning," reflecting their attractiveness and pull on human desire or imagination.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "For my dream to become reality, all I'd need is a plane ticket and a TT waiting for me on that beckoning British island."
  - Location paragraph 12
- ===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/a+beckoning.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Abstract concepts such as loyalty, challenges, or even negative outcomes (like aid cuts) are personified as "beckoning," suggesting they actively draw individuals toward them, whether positively or negatively.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "There are several loyalties-beckoning to every person loyalty to his group, his firm, his family, and his country."
  - Location paragraph 11
- ===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/a+beckoning.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The pursuit of scientific or intellectual advancement is culturally associated with being "beckoned" by new knowledge, framing discovery as something that calls to researchers.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is the beckoning finger of new knowledge for the scientist."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/a+beckoning.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, the beckoning gesture using the index finger (with palm facing the face and the finger bent inward) is not mentioned as a cultural practice; instead, raising the index finger is associated with requesting to ask a question.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "France Requesting to ask a question"
  - Location paragraph 3

(Note The text does not provide any information about a French cultural rule related to the act of beckoning someone using hand gestures. It only states that in France, extending the index finger signifies a request to ask a question, which pertains to classroom or formal settings rather than calling someone over from a distance. Therefore, no actual beckoning rule for interpersonal summoning is supported by the text.)===from https://zhidao.baidu.com/question/1826353774473678868.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Maintaining eye contact is considered a crucial element in interpersonal communication, symbolizing confidence and creating a connection with others.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Abordons aujourd’hui un élément extrêmement important dans nos relations avec les autres."  
  - Location p1===from https://blogeloquence.com/eye-contact-limportance-du-contact-visuel-dans-la-communication-interpersonnelle/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A direct and steady gaze is perceived as a sign of strength and self-assurance, while avoiding eye contact (a "fuyant" gaze) may carry negative impressions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A l’inverse vous avez peut-être déjà eu le sentiment que certains individus avaient l’air plus fort, plus confiant, et cela se manifestait justement par leur regard, franc et direct."  
  - Location p2===from https://blogeloquence.com/eye-contact-limportance-du-contact-visuel-dans-la-communication-interpersonnelle/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Sustaining eye contact without looking away or blinking excessively is challenging, indicating that it is not an innate behavior despite being one of the earliest forms of human communication.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ce n’est pas si facile de soutenir le regard, de ne jamais détourner les yeux. Il est plus difficile encore de les garder bien ouvert, sans cligner des paupières trop souvent. A vrai dire le eye contact est loin d’être inné…"  
  - Location p3===from https://blogeloquence.com/eye-contact-limportance-du-contact-visuel-dans-la-communication-interpersonnelle/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French culture, maintaining steady eye contact during conversation is seen as a sign of attentiveness, sincerity, and respect, particularly in formal or professional settings. Avoiding eye contact may be interpreted as disinterest, evasiveness, or dishonesty.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Eye contact is a powerful tool in French communication. It signifies attentiveness, sincerity, and respect."
  - Location p1

- Rule Description While eye contact remains important in casual settings, it can be less intense and more relaxed, with natural breaks being acceptable during friendly conversations.
- ===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/understanding-french-body-language-and-gestures-a-guide-to-non-verbal-communication/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Sustained eye contact with strangers in public spaces is generally considered inappropriate or impolite in French culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Si vous dévisagez quelqu’un sur un trottoir, ce sera immédiatement perçu comme un signe d’inconvenance."
  - Location p5===from https://www.psychologies.com/mini-site-Gentillesse/La-gentillesse-dans-la-societe/Eye-contact-experiment-regarder-un-inconnu-les-yeux-dans-les-yeux

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Prolonged eye contact is culturally accepted and even encouraged in close relationships such as family or between partners, but not in public or with strangers.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ce n’est pas le cas en famille, ou avec son conjoint, au contraire."
  - Location p5===from https://www.psychologies.com/mini-site-Gentillesse/La-gentillesse-dans-la-societe/Eye-contact-experiment-regarder-un-inconnu-les-yeux-dans-les-yeux

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In professional interview settings, it is expected to maintain eye contact with each interviewer, including shifting focus periodically among panel members.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you are interviewed by a panel of interviewers, make sure you maintain eye contact with each person from time to time."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/eye+contact.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is appropriate to make eye contact while greeting someone formally, such as during a job interview, along with a firm handshake.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Shake their hand firmly and make eye contact when greeting your interviewer."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/eye+contact.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Eye contact should be established with drivers or pedestrians before crossing their path to ensure they have noticed you and intend to stop.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Make 'eye contact' with motorists or pedestrians before crossing their path to confirm their intention to stop."
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/eye+contact.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is beneficial to make eye contact with each participant before starting a meeting to establish connection and engagement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Before starting a meeting, take one minute to make eye contact with each participant."
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/eye+contact.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Direct and strong eye contact is considered an important element of clear and effective communication.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Simply put, strong, direct eye contact is an important part of straightforward, effective communication."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/eye+contact.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: People can understand each other nonverbally through eye contact and body movements.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "They also make themselves understood nonverbally, by eye contact and movements."
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/eye+contact.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: While listening, maintaining eye contact and using appropriate body language helps demonstrate focus on the speaker.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "While maintaining eye contact, and with body language, stay focused on the speaker."
  - Location paragraph 19===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/eye+contact.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Making eye contact with drivers ensures that individuals (such as children) are visible and acknowledged for safety purposes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Make eye contact with the drivers and ensure that they are visible to them."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/eye+contact.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Inability to maintain eye contact may be perceived as a sign of nervousness, discomfort, guilt, or shame in formal situations like interviews.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "They may affect your approach to the mission and interview in the following ways nervous and uncomfortable feelings and body language, inability to maintain eye contact, sense of guilt and shame."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/eye+contact.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Good eye contact during interactions is associated with being well-prepared and engaged, particularly in evaluative contexts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You made good eye contact and were well prepared."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.linguee.fr/anglais-francais/traduction/eye+contact.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, eye contact is expected during interactions and is seen as a sign of interest and respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "France and Canada Eye contact is expected and conveys interest and respect."
  - Location p6===from https://www.storytellercharles.com/post/the-impact-of-eye-contact-in-different-cultures

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: An idiomatic expression in French is a linguistic construction whose overall meaning cannot be understood literally by analyzing individual words, and it carries a figurative and culturally specific meaning unique to the language.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Une expression idiomatique est une construction linguistique particulière dont le sens global ne peut pas être compris littéralement en analysant chacun de ses mots individuellement. C’est une expression propre à une langue qui possède une signification figurée et culturelle spécifique."
  - Location p1===from https://apprendre-reviser-memoriser.fr/expressions-idiomatiques-courantes-en-francais/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Understanding French idiomatic expressions requires contextual and cultural knowledge, as they are deeply tied to the culture and usage of the language.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Les expressions idiomatiques en français nécessitent donc une compréhension contextuelle et culturelle."
  - Location p2===from https://apprendre-reviser-memoriser.fr/expressions-idiomatiques-courantes-en-francais/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Idiomatic expressions enrich the French language, add character, and enable more nuanced and expressive communication.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Les expressions idiomatiques enrichissent la langue, lui donnent du caractère et permettent une communication plus nuancée et expressive."
  - Location p3===from https://apprendre-reviser-memoriser.fr/expressions-idiomatiques-courantes-en-francais/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: French idiomatic expressions are often used to convey ideas in an imaginative and humorous way, enhancing expressiveness.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Ces expressions idiomatiques enrichissent le français et sont souvent utilisées pour exprimer des idées de manière imagée et humoristique."
  - Location p4===from https://apprendre-reviser-memoriser.fr/expressions-idiomatiques-courantes-en-francais/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: French people frequently use idiomatic expressions in daily conversations, and these expressions are considered essential to understanding French culture and language.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "French idiomatic expressions can be hard to understand [...] and French people love to use them all the time."  
  - Location p2===from https://french-iceberg.com/french-idiomatic-expressions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Learning and using French idiomatic expressions helps non-native speakers better understand French media such as movies and music, and enables them to sound more like native speakers.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Learning French expressions will help you to understand better French movies or French music."  
  - Location p2===from https://french-iceberg.com/french-idiomatic-expressions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Understanding idioms is key to enhancing communication skills and deepening cultural appreciation in the context of French language learning.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Understanding idioms enhances communication skills and cultural appreciation."  
  - Location p4===from https://french-iceberg.com/french-idiomatic-expressions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: French idioms often reflect a cultural tendency to tease or joke, particularly evident in expressions that mock absurdity or neighboring nationalities.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "The modification represents French humor from my point of view, the French love to tease and joke."  
  - Location p30===from https://french-iceberg.com/french-idiomatic-expressions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The French commonly use idioms in everyday conversations, and these expressions are intended to be understood figuratively rather than literally.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "The French love to use these idioms in everyday conversations. And like the rest of the idiomatic expressions across the world, these expressions are not meant to be taken literally."
